RATING: 8.8
My favourite worker placement game (I find Agricola too dull and Le Havre too strategically overwhelming, although arguably better it isn't for me, at least on iOS), Lords of Waterdeep uses fairly basic mechanics to create a stripped-down euro that encourages interaction and blocking without spite, and demonstrates decent replay value through quests and buildings.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
My first few plays of this was with 2, and I liked it alright. But it became rather stale, and I was debating on lowering the score to an alright #6.

But after having played my last 5-6 games with 4 or 5, it really have to stay at 8, or 8,5 if I could rate it that. It is so well put together and with the right group it is just plain fun and hectic to get the resources you want.

We have also used it to introduce some friends to the hobby, and 2 of them bought it on a whim, and are actually our main gamepartners now. The others also caught up on the game really quick, and enjoyed the sessions.

A great recommendation as a gateway euro, that might be a weenie bit heavier than Ticket to Ride and stuff like you normally consider a gateway game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
For what it is, that is to say a readily accessible eurogame with flavourful theming, it is astonishing. The production quality is to the standard one would expect of a Hasbro subsidiary with such a history, and the game even develops positively as an experience with the inclusion of the expansion (an enviable quality most designers cannot match). 

As such it is an excellent gateway game, but one that harbours replayability.

RATING: 8.5
Very fast and streamlined worker-placement. I love that everyone "gets it" within two turns, and once you know the rules you never need to look at the rulebook again (there's basically no rules confusion or disputes). The theme is a bit tacked on, but the production quality is fantastic. You get a lot of game for your 75 minute investment.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Rated after one play.  A fun worker placement game, although I'd probably pick Caylus over this one.

---

Another play in and this one's rating is already starting to drop.  Unlike other worker placement games that I've played, this one only seems to have one path to victory (complete quests).  As such, Lords of Waterdeep turns into an optimization game of who can complete their quests in the most efficient manner.  Compare this to Caylus or Agricola where players can get points through a variety of means.  Waterdeep is a game that I probably won't turn down, but will never suggest to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Easy to teach and intuitive, but with some strategy. But the "take that" elements of the game are just a total drag. Leads to ganging-up and king-making way too easily. Also intrigue card draw and quest turn create a pretty luck based game.

RATING: 9
Played this three times now and it's a really good game, pretty much everything I hoped Ankh Morpork by Martin Wallace would be. A very pleasant game with solid euro mechanisms and rules that are fully understood by the end of round one. Enough theme and flavour to give the game a slight D&D feel, although meeples instead of cubes for the adventurers would have been a nice touch to support the imagination if you're that way inclined. As for me I'm perfectly happy to be collecting cubes! Overall, strongly recommended, and I've just acquired a copy.

This is a contender for one of the best eurogames of 2012 imo.

RATING: 7
This is a solid worker-placement game with nice aesthetics, and a not-overpowering theme - minimal flavour text etc. The engine-building aspects are not complex, and the game is primarily set-collecting, but it all works nicely, and in a good shortish time-frame. The curse of many Euros, the cubes never get called by their real titles and hence the theme is never fully realised.

RATING: 7
7+ plays / 4,5,6 players

Mostly played with the expansion.

LIKE: A relatively fast worker placement. Secret goals offer variety. Multiple paths to victory. Quest cards are fun. Buying buildings adds a bit of engine-building fun.
DISLIKE: Can feel a bit repetitive, some intrigue cards are overpowered/swingy. The 40-point quest cards ensure victory. Can be cruel and cutthroat at times.

OVERALL: Fun game, but a bit swingy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
As everyone has said, this game is quite good. It isn't remarkable, however, but it is very well constructed and produced. The fantasy theme is completely pasted on as only titles and pictures tell you anything - mechanically, it is bone dry Euro - and yet still sits well. As with all ramp up the selection games (Agricola, Caylus, Endeavor, etc), the game tends to slow and creak as analysis settles in and options fan out. Our game had a king-maker situation at the end in which I had two options for my last play - either one of which determined the victor. There is also some aspects of upstream player order sniping off the parts you need - especially so if you are playing along similar strategy lines. And I could imagine some random roll out of buildings, Lords cards and Quests making the game miserable for some. But other than that, there isn't much to dislike. A solid work and I'd play it again, but I doubt it has much staying power.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
2013/09
A solid 6er.
Almost flawless mechanics and fast gameplay. Nice components, too. Why not to give a higher rating then? Well, the game leaves very little room for longer term strategies. I'd also like to see the game evolve into something spectacular towards the end, but no. You just keep completing a quest after quest in no particular order of significance and having no or very little effect on your future actions.

Ok, game. Just do not expect too much from it.


2015/01
6 -> 5
The lack of dramatic arc ruins the game. Your first mission may be the most valuable one while the last has no significance for the outcome of the game.

RATING: 7

It could be about anything.  The theme does not come though - which sounds boring.  But it isn't.  It's an interesting engine and a good game of about the right length.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A typical worker placement Euro with an Ameritrash theme pasted on.  It plays well, but doesn't have anything original about it.  Those who dislike direct conflict will be turned off by the Intrigue cards, some of which can be used to directly attack opponents.

UPDATE: After a second play, I've lowered my rating a half point because I feel like there is too much luck involved in the game with regards to Quest cards and Intrigue cards.  Drawing the right Quest cards to match with one's Lord card plays too big a factor for my liking, and it's a largely random factor.  Sure, there are ways to bury Quest cards that other players may need, but taking an action to set back a single opponent at some cost to yourself is a net loss for you in games of 3+ players.  The same is true of the Mandatory Quests.  Playing a Mandatory Quest on one player doesn't affect any other players, and costs you an Intrigue card play.

All in all, it's an okay game, but a bit too random and confrontational to make a good Euro game.

+Fun theme that may appeal to those turned off by the usual Euro game themes.
+Nice gateway to Euro-style games.
+Easy to learn.

-Lots of direct attacks on other players.
-Possibility of king-making.
-Large degree of randomness involved in Quest cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
IMHO the best mix between fantasy and worker placement games. You don't have to have read or played anything in the Forgotten Realms universe. The idea I like the most is that you are a manager of adventureres, you have to hire rogues, mages, clerics and warriors in order to fulfill quests. I am the only one I know that reads the flavor text on the quests, it is a plus for the ones familiar with the universe...and doesn't affect the others or the game play. I played it over 20 times, even though I have the expansion, we never felt that we had enough of the base game. The thing I like most is that was easily accepted by all people in our group... no one disliked it and it is always the group's first choice. I rate it 10 because of that.

RATING: 7.78
Rating together with its expansion, [I]Scoundrels of Skullport[/I].

This is one game where the expansion substantially improved the base game.  Absent the expansion, the base game is not bad, but it is sort of dull.  There aren't a lot of interesting choices, though arguably it is still better than a lot of other gateway games out there.  

It's sort of a collect cubes, spend cubes kind of game, with a little bit of "take that" in the form of Intrigue Cards.

RATING: 7.75

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Worker placement with a really well integrated theme. Unlike many typical "soulless euros", in Lords of Waterdeep You aren't just placing meeples on spaces and trying to optimize a cube economy with a pretty vague reason as to the why. No, in lords you are placing members of your lords house/faction (meeples) in different districts of the city of water deep in order to build certain buildings or take actions that involve sending different groups of clerics, Warriors, Wizards, and Rogues on quests. The more quests you complete, the more points you will earn for end game scoring. This game is a really well put together experience. According to the lore, wotc staff had to make the game on their lunch breaks and then pitch it to the executives after the fact because they initially thought it was a terrible idea. This was a labor of love and it shows in the design. Bravo.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Many plays, and always a good time!

RATING: 9
This is truly one outstanding game. There is a lot of variety and the game scales magnificently with more or less players. The number of options avaliable to the players are perfectly matched with the number of workers given per game and the "Take That!" mechanics aren't friendship-ruining. A competitive game that isn't so fierce as to ward off new players.

RATING: 8
Lords of Waterdeep is a simple worker-placement game with a nice twist - named intrigues.
Although the theme is just pasted onto the game and the mechanism is pretty simple (go there, take this) Lords of Waterdeep is actually quite fun to play. Not a game to play again and again and again, but worthwhile in between. Its refreshing nowadays to have a worker placement game that simple when other games of this genre try to beat each other with overly complex rules and options.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good worker placement game, that can also be used as an introduction to worker placement, and that doesn't need knowledge of D&D to play so anyone can pick it up. Bonus, if you enjoy the setting.

Great family game. 

Fun and can be played in an hour (maybe a bit longer) with experienced folks.

Has surprising amount of tension as resources become scarce and well-played intrigue cards can hinder the best laid plans.

I like uncovering the various abilities of cards that can work together to create nice timing effects. A simple example: using a building to get a face-up quest and completing it in one turn when both spots at Cliffwatch Inn (which give the ability to take a quest card) have been taken.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

$25

Why it's previously-owned:

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I bought this game hoping that it would be a good substitute for Settlers of Catan, as I have played the heck out of that game and was ready for a change. It was an excellent step up from Catan, while it is still resource management, it also has the awesome lore of D&D to back it up. Some Catan never came close to competing with.

The game-play is relatively simple and easy to pick up, making it an easy game to teach to new players. The artwork is phenomenal, and the D&D themes are incorporated very well into the game. I especially appreciate the variety of cards in this game, whether they be quest or intrigue cards there are very few repeated cards and I have to draw to identical cards in a game. The card variety makes for a a fresh game every time I play. 

My only complaint for this game is that it may be too simple for it to continue to be challenging each game. Otherwise, I loved it.

RATING: 7

RATING: 10
Absolutely fabulous. Everyone loves it, and even the littles can play
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Lords of Waterdeep is a good worker placement game that shines for its simplicity and ease of play.

The game-play is extremely straight-forward. All you do is gather resources as efficiently as possible and trade them for points. There's very little that deviates from the classic worker placement/resource management game recipe. You can build new locations that allow to take better actions or you can play intrigue cards, that introduce some take-that moments. Both mechanisms increase the player interaction significantly (especially for a title of this genre) and it's for sure one of the biggest strengths of the game.

Yet, even if I consider Lords of Waterdeep to be a fun game, it's not a title I would describe as exciting. It might be the very reason of its success, but the same simplicity and ease of play keep this title from being a great game... at least for me of course. I like it, but I don't find myself thinking about it when the game has been put back in the box. Some worker placement games draw you in with many different strategies and possibilities, other offer difficult choices and a very deep game-play. Those are the worker placement games I love. Lords of Waterdeep is a good game, but I traded cubes for points this time and I will do the same next time I'll play it... just hopefully more efficiently than before.

Therefore I consider Lords of Waterdeep to be a good game and I can see how it's so successful. It's probably a great gateway title for the worker placement genre. It's intuitive to play and offers a lot of interaction... it just isn't as exciting as some other games of this kind. Middle of the road for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Good, but want to play with expansions to see if that makes the experience more complete.

RATING: 5.9
:cry: :) :D :) :yuk: Too much direct attacking for my taste; an inferior version of Stone Age. Still fun, in small and sporadic doses. Also it takes exactly one hour EVERY TIME, so if you start with this, you'll usually get to play more games after! Another game whose rating baffles me. I mean it's relatively brief, it's simple to teach, and oh yeah, it's also completely mindless, because the best decision is usually obvious even if you're looking at the board from the moon. Between this and Netrunner, I think maybe some people will just rate any old scifi/fantasy game really high. This isn't horrible, but it's just so bland and drab, and I just don't get what makes so many people go completely freaking apetits over manufactured mediocrity.

RATING: 8
A surprising game. 

Don't get fooled by the cover, this is a rather typical Euro worker/resources management game, dressed up - rather well - in a D&D theme. It's not as tight as most games in the genre, thanks to random objective and action cards. In exchange, it's much for fun and replayable.

It feels a bit weird to be giving a 8 to this game, as I'm not a fan of the genre. But the game just has had that much success around our table. It's easy to learn and quick to play, and ever since I bought it, the box keeps coming off the shelf on a regular basis whenever we want something a bit easy for 4 or 5 players.

RATING: 9
I can see why this gets compared to Stone Age often. I enjoy Stone Age, but I like Lords of Waterdeep more. The different intrigue cards, quest cards, buildings, and lord cards offer so much variability from game to game. While it probably plays best with more players, I enjoy it as a two-player game. Now that we have played with the expansion, we plan to always use at least one of the modules from now on, though most likely we will use both. Undermountain gives the same "big money" feel that the Prosperity expansion gave to Dominion...bigger actions, bigger quests, bigger points. Skullport really changes up the game with corruption, another resource to manage, and one that adds even more interaction to the game, as you can affect the consequences of corruption in the game if you want, depending on your own corruption in relation to other players. 

+Scoundrels of Skullport

RATING: 5
Played "Lords of Waterdeep" twice.  Easy to play, nice quality components.  The game itself doesn't work for me.  Place an 'agent' on the board, collect cubes.  Collect enough cubes, turn in for victory points.  That's about it.  Yes, you can buy buildings or play 'intrigue' cards for various effects, but the basic game is as I described it above.

The theme didn't stand out at all.  I didn't feel as though I was hiring buff warriors for a noble quest, I was just collecting little orange cubes because my 'quest' cards said I needed four of them for X amount of VP.  I think I can see how someone could have fun with the game, but I also think it's more hyped up than it should be.  It's not a bad game, it just feels very limited to me.

I'll be selling/trading "Lords of Waterdeep" sooner than later.

RATING: 8.7
When I first read the rules, I thought, "At last! A worker placement game where the mechanics perfectly marry the theme!" Then I played it. No, the theme is NOT pasted on; but the link between theme and gameplay is certainly looser than it might first appear. This could have been considerably alleviated if minis had been used instead of cubes for the various adventurers, like in Empires:Age of Discovery; but then the retail price would have skyrocketed.
Not that any of that matters: it's a fun game, regardless! The art is great, except for the somewhat bland board. Player interaction is fairly strong....and often cutthroat. Gobs of luck for a worker placement game! Perhaps Lords of Waterdeep is the gateway game to worker placement games?

RATING: 6
Light but engaging worker placement game. I bought it on a whim with all of the positive buzz surrounding the D&D theme on a Euro game. The fantasy setting does complement the worker placement skeleton nicely. The design is tight and well balanced (except sort of the forced mission attack cards). It's just not that deep of a game.

Great for playing with new players. Base game has gotten a bit meh for me. Definitely improved a bit with more options. I would potentially give the game 7/10 with the expansion. It has really helped keeping the game fresh for me. But I try to reserve playing LoW with new(ish) gamers so I can still enjoy it in small doses and enjoy seeing light bulbs go off in people's heads as they figure out the strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pros
- Excellent gateway game and accessible 
- Simple, accessible, and the board is intuitive 
- Cool insert
- Halfway through, you get another meeple so the game feels like it ramps up
- Some direct interaction with mandatory quests
- Great decisions to make with scarcity of cubes
- Buildings add variability 
- Hidden scoring done at the end adds tension for endgame
- Low key game for people who do not like direct interaction 

Cons
- The theme is very dry and feels tacked on, but it's fun and accessible enough where that doesn't matter

RATING: 6
Serviceable. I find the engine building a little too straightforward and the game too unthematic to really compete against other games.

For worker placement, personally I'd rather play Viticulture or Vanuatu. But for something accessible to new gamers or people who might not be able to take in a bunch of rules, I think that Carcassonne is a more interesting game from a strategic standpoint, more visually appealing, and more space conscious. (Something about the real estate used by Lords of Waterdeep, compared to the abstract play, sort of annoys me. It feels like it should be a cute, abstract game from Japan. Instead, it's a thematic game that got streamlined to hell without cutting down on the board size to match.)

RATING: 7

After a few games, however, it starts feeling a touch samey. Enjoyable, but not high art.

City guard player had a card that allow search of quest deck looking for skulldiggery quest.  This burned up half the deck (of which were of course mostly warefare/piety quest).  Lots of rogue again due to buildings.  The most useful building is Three Pearls that allow covert 2 of any to 3 of any.

From Amazon for $31 on 6/23/12.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fun, if simple, worker placement game, with a pasted-on theme of intrigue in D&D's most famous city.  Easy to teach, and I've never played with anyone who dislikes it.

You compete to place your Agents around the city, constructing buildings (and the buildings create a rather interesting subsystem of the game), playing cards, gathering adventurers and gold, and completing quests.

The action cards are the only part of this game I especially dislike, but I can't rate it higher because while I enjoy it, I'd always choose Agricola or Stone Age if I was to play a worker placement game, and LoW doesn't really do anything new.

Comes with dozens of uniquely illustrated cards, wooden agent meeples for each player, and a big pile of wooden cube and cardboard chip resources.  The general aesthetic is consistent, but for a reason I can't quite put my finger on I don't much care for it, though I was never a Forgotten Realms player so maybe there's something I'm missing.

Special note must be made here of the box, for several reasons.  The box insert is fantastic, with room for each type of piece, rather than the sort I've started to see with other publishers which consists of a single large cardboard compartment. As usual for these types of inserts, (and perhaps one of the reasons for the single-compartment inserts) no consideration is made for card sleevers, so a portion of the insert goes unused while the cards slide around under the insert. Such is the life of the obsessive sleever.  The box lid, unlike most other box lids in games today, doesn't extend the whole height of the box.  I'm sure there must be some reason for this beyond just a unique look, but I can't think of what, and it means it tears more easily along the corners and will never stay on if the game is stored sideways.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.95
An interesting worker placement game with quite a few interesting angles.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Baseline acceptable worker placement game. Perfectly fine. Not super exciting, but it's decent.

RATING: 7

RATING: 7
July 2013:  Third time playing the game, it seems like the game, at least when played with the existing intrigue cards, has a noteworthy problem.  In particular, the mandatory quest cards seem to invariably cause the player or players who have them played on them, to really dislike the gaming session with this game.  They feel picked upon.  These cards are too powerful, and invariably in our sessions, if played in the closing rounds of the game, lead to glaring king-making problems. (I would assume that playing the game by removing these cards from the intrigue deck would remedy this problem which has plagued the game the three times I have played it.)  

Unfortunately, this conspicuous problem with the mandatory quest cards seems to underscore a broader unease with the game.  When the game is played between very evenly matched players, the final scores are wonderfully close, which generally shows that the designers have balanced the game very nicely.  

However, in this game, such a result raises an uncomfortable question:  did the winner win because everyone gave that much loved player the very small (eg extra cube) "extra benefit" that some intrigue cards provided?  Alternatively, did someone lose by one point because that player happened to have a white cube that was eliminated from their tavern by another player's mindlessly directed intrigue card. In this way, one is left with the uncomfortable feeling that the game was decided by who gave what favor to which player with an intrigue card. In order to restore the connection between game outcome to thoughtful effort, are players supposed to evenly distribute card effects?  

Thus, card play favoritism, randomness, or maliciousness almost seems to decide this game between evenly matched players. From a game design stand point, this is not ideal.

Dropping the rating to a 7 of 10.

May 2012:  First time playing Lords of Waterdeep...I thought it was an excellent, well designed worker placement game that owes much of its inspiration and appeal to mechanics first introduced into the game world by Caylus.  

Lords of Waterdeep overflows with euro gaming style decision making: anticipating other players' actions, engine building, resource management and conversion, rule tweaking card play, play sequencing analysis, turn order considerations, secret goals, and VP condition satisfaction. 

And it does all this within the context of a relatively short game (at least by euro standards) which is nevertheless, satisfying...and that may be it's most impressive game design feat. It packs a lot of gaming punch into a very short game.  Wow, well done.

Is this the best game ever?  Perhaps not, but it is rock solid in design and execution, plus this game is going to introduce a lot of Dungeons and Dragons players (a respectable portion of the 5-8 million people in the world who play D & D) to boardgaming.  And for that reason alone, this game is distinctively good for board gaming and the future of board gaming.  

As I see it, Lords of Waterdeep is likely to make its way into the BGG top 20 very soon, and stay there for quite some time. (A definite early favorite to win the Spiel for games released in 2012, i.e. next year's Spiel.)      

What has Caylus done?  It has spawned a number of new classics like Agricola, Stone Age, Carson City....and now...Lords of Waterdeep.  Welcome to the family...whippersnapper! :p  I give it an 8 of 10.

RATING: 8
Heavy? No. Thematic? No. Fun? YES. Lords of Waterdeep is another entry into the worker placement genre that successfully meshes strategy, accessibility, and fun. 

The game is really easy to teach, especially since everything is so well labeled on the map - worker spaces let you know how many people can use a building and then they clearly show what you can do in there.

Plays fast and is both light enough for new 'gamers' to enjoy and strategic enough for 'gamer-gamers' to get into as well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
With some minor houseruling (and with expansion gives even more varierty), this is the best gateway worker placement (far better than Stone Age, no dice here). Maybe even best WP (it beats overrated Keyflower) And maybe even best gateway in general. It have been the favourite game of my group with 100+ plays, and we never seem to get bored with it yet.

The only con is the theme, which is laughable for an euro and may detract potentional gamers. But luckily there is no miniatyres here.

RATING: 9
 This is one of our favorite worker placement games. With its easy game play and top rate quality components it should be near the top of everyone's list. But we will say one thing about it. Let's be honest. The D & D theme is pasted on. Don't get us wrong it is still an awesome game despite that. But we have to disagree with certain people (Richard Ham. we're talking to you) who believe this game can get RPGers into board games. We have been part of die hard RPG groups in the past and there is no way they'd consider this D & D. Reasonably certain they would all just look at us in a very cross manner were we to even suggest such a thing.

RATING: 6
One play, 5P.  D&D-themed Caylus, essentially.  Inclined to think that 3P is the sweet spot for my tastes, because I found the downtime almost entirely uninteresting.  That's usually not the case for me with worker placement, because I'm concerned about contention, but with this game there always seemed to be so many outs (buildings to let you re-use other spots, cards that let you re-use other spots, plot quests that let you re-use other spots, cards that can provide the same thing you need, duplication of needs on buildings, etc.).  Enjoyed it still, and would play again.  Oh, also disappointed with the sameyness of the Lords - although I'm sure I prefer it to grossly unbalanced asymmetry.

RATING: 7.5
Some folks have spoken poorly of the theme, but I thought the theme worked out well. The one thing that would have helped would have been some greater variety in bulding functions. The game tends to descend to figuring on the most efficient exchange rate for adventurers.  The notion that you have to benefit one other player slightly for more intrigue cards was neat. It provides internal balancing since you'd try and give it to someone who would benefit least from it.  I'd say it's about the best entry-level euro for most people who might be leery. Settlers is too random for me. Ticket to ride is go-fish. This game is the basics in an approachable fantasy theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
5P

Outstanding...WOTC has a gem here!
Dungeons & Dragons theme on a strong euro based mechanic game. Game play is similar but not the same as caylus due to the intrigue cards. It adds a conflict dynamic i have not seen in other worker placement games that really adds tension and proper planning to accomplish ones goals.

As a Bonus, the wife likes to play it as well, a 10 in my book, period.

RATING: 8.9

RATING: 8
My favourite worker placement game. Simple yet has lots of layers. Much better with the expansion included as well. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.8
I had a lot of negative preconceptions about this game going into my first play.  I was pleasantly surprised.  The depth surprised me, given its reputation as a gateway game.  And regarding the theme, which many have called "pasted on".  Well, I guess I love hoarding colored cubes so much that I didn't care.

After one play at 3p, it does seem that there is a slightly excessive luck factor, particularly due to the intrigue cards.  For example, the 'sample wares' card allowed me to get 10 rogue cubes, which no one prevented because of course they didn't know I had that card...  However, through dogged blocking, mandatory quests, etc., another player managed to close the gap, which imo is a testament to the game's interactivity.  I love games that let you slap down a runaway leader.

The waterdeep harbor mechanism was a standout feature of the design, allowing you to postpone your turn in order to play a card.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
I love comparing it to Agricola which is my most played WP game. LoW has done several things better than Agricola despite being a more gateway WP game:
- Much more player interaction
- Clear cut currency values
- Accessibility to newbies of WP
- Variability in starting condition
- New players that have some experience in WP actually have a chance at beating experienced players

The theme is horrible though.

RATING: 5

This isn't too bad though. The production value is nice and high, everything is fairly pretty, and it seems like there's a fair bit of screwage as well. I think I might like Dominant Species a little better for worker placement, but I don't think Dominant Species translates as well to two player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The meat and potatoes of the worker placement genre. Rudimentary economy, overpowered gotcha cards, an overabundance of randomness and excessive downtime between actions with a high player count put this game low on the list of worthwhile worker placers. The game also seems to have more turns than is needed - by the end of the game, the various virtuous and vicious cycles are irreversible. It's often recommended as an introductory WP game, but I'd say it's dullness argues very strongly against it.

RATING: 5
This is I think the highest ranked game I've played that didn't do much for me. I felt I was playing a game solo, just that other players were simultaneously playing the same solo game. I got on with my quests, sometimes other players might get in my way but I think that was accidental not tactical. In this sense, the lack of player interaction reminded me of Ticket to Ride. I rated that 5.5 and am rating this lower because at least with TtoR you sense you are building railway lines, with LoW deep I had no feeling of sending people on quests. In fact, it is so abstract that it was halfway through the game before I bothered asking what the different coloured cubes represent (answer: it doesn't matter). Nice board though. 
Just to be fair, I should point out I've only played once and had a cold so was feeling a bit jaded.

RATING: 10
HOLY SHIT THIS GAME IS MY JAM
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Played loads of games - about an equal amount of 2p & 3p, with a few 5 and six players.  All very good, but subtly different and interesting experiences.

We like worker placement games (Notre Dame, Stone Age, et al), this one differs by having a stronger and more direct 'take that' element, though it is not overpowered, nor too confrontational.  

It's nice to have a well designed and produced worker placement game that provides this.  

I'm not a massive D&D fan (I played with the red/blue boxed sets, many, many years ago) but it's nice to have a compelling theme - it makes a change from the somewhat dry subject matter many worker placement games explore.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Thanks SS'12 for such a wonderful game!!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Lords of Waterdeep qualifies as a light-to-medium euro game, with the novel aspect of being set in the D&D world of the Forgotten Realms.
The designer chose to add some player interaction (apart from the usual "I take that spot that you truly need" interaction level of every worker placement game...) in the form of Intrigue cards.
The game feels quite straightforward, with the completing of quests as a rather direct way of turning resources (adventurer cubes) in victory points.
Lords of Waterdeep lacks the depth of many favorite euros: there's no real deep choices (like building an engine vs making fast points), but everything is so smooth that it plays fast and don't overstays its welcome.
Rating after the first three plays (with 2, 5 and 4 players) is a 7.5.

Update, august 25th, 2013: after more than a year, I find myself returning to the game and enjoying it a lot (it is the to go light worker placement game), so the rating goes up to 8.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

FAVORITE MEDIUM WEIGHT WORKER PLACEMENT GAME

Type: Strategy

RATING: 7
First play: A very clean and straightforward game to explain. Few if any fiddly rules and we launched in after 20 mins which included set up time. 

A rinse and repeat experience over 8 rounds the game ticks over with players trying to add to their scores by improving on basic abilities, by completing special quests or increasing their income by buying buildings that offer additional actions and payment to the shop owner.

Not quite short enough to be a filler but a very simple mechanic and strong nostalgia for those with a D'n'D background. Not a game I'd buy but I'd be happy to play again.

Second Play: Ditto the above. Strangly I was given the 'Collect buildings' again Lord card and won (again) by a country mile after collecting 9 buildings and scooping an extra 54 points. Maybe worth removing this card?

RATING: 7.5
Solid worker placement game. This and Stone Age would be my go-to introductory games for the genre but ones that even seasoned gamers would enjoy. The variability is reasonably high since the kinds of quests and buildings that come out will be different every game. In the end, it's a pretty straight forward gather-resources-and-convert-them-to-points Euro but the various quests, buildings and cards present a different puzzle to solve each game. Bonus points for good component quality and a nice box insert.

RATING: 9
One of the all time great worker placement games, with a D&D theme! There is so much to like in this game. The building mechanic is great as you get VP or people or money as people use your buildings. Also, the secret Lord card can be the turning point in a close game. Finish those quests that they want you to finish! Beautiful components, easy gameplay, great theme. IMO, most people should have this in their collection if they consider themselves a gamer.

RATING: 8
I liked this more actually playing it then I did when I first did a run through on my own. You can really foil a guys plans with a well played intrigue card - which is the major difference here between this and other worker placement games. Other than that wholly derivitive. Not a single unique mechanism in the whole game.

Its too bad I am totally burned on worker placement or I'd've liked this more. If I only owned three worker placements this would be one of them:

Agricola
Caylus
Lords of Waterdeep
...possibly alien frontiers. but thats it!...and glen more? too many good games.

I really wish this had come out before stone age. To think of all the worker placement fatigue i got from that game when I could have been playing this.

RATING: 8
Man, what a difference a little theme makes.  And by "A little," I mean "Vast glorious treasure chests stuffed with."  Remove the Dungeons and Dragons elements and you're left with a good-but-not-great worker-placement Euro.  But with them -- and note that they only require a basic understanding of fantasy RPG archetypes to make sense -- a damn fun story emerges.  Gather up adventurers, send them out on missions to do your bidding, look for ways to screw your neighbors out of doing the same.  Good times.

RATING: 7.25
Family game rating.

Have the DnD Painted Custom Meeples, Skull Upgrade kit, upgraded coins and the larger DnDeeples that replace the caravan tokens.

A light medium worker placement game that has a place in my collection for family game nights. It is easily explained, doesn't overstay it's welcome (plays rather quickly) and holds your attention for what it is. 

Yes, the Mandatory quests can add a randomness and screwage factor, but it brings out the theme and flavor. Take it for what it is and have fun with it.

I'm not a DnD guy, but the artwork and theme are great and having the DnD painted custom meeples enhances the experience. 

I'm looking forward to seeing what the expansion adds.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
If pre-calculus is required before calculus, then Lords of Waterdeep is pre-Caylus. Or Caylus for dummies. Or Caylus for people that aren't hardcore gamers. The mechanics were simple to pick up, but allowed for some decent depth. A few of the cards/quests are overpowering (one plot quest lets you play on an occupied space and another grants you an additional agents). In most cases, the players with these benefits have won the game despite being delayed by Mandatory Quests and the like. Overall a good mid-complexity game for players of all depths.

Setup - 5
Rules - 5
Simplicity - 4
Fun Factor - 4
Interest in Playing - 5
Depth - 3

X-Factor - 3

RATING: 10
I really enjoy the combination of Euro worker placement mechanics (including the harbor twist), American take-that mechanics (Intrigue cards), and the hidden role mechanic (Lords/target quests).  Building and quest variety provides plenty of replay, and the building ownership bonus makes extending the game board worthwhile.  Very nice blend, very accessible, quick to play, and fun.  Theme is great, so much happier with this than planting seeds, raising sheep, or trading stone and barley.  Questing FTW!  They're rogues, clerics, fighters, and wizards dammit.  Not cubes.  :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This game is quickly becoming one of my favorites. It is incredibly easy to teach, people are eager to play it again. It has a nice middle weight feel to it, and it can be played in about an hour and half. Now if they would just to something about the awful box which has fallen apart at the seams in less than a month - the inserts are great, but more attention to the outside packaging would have been helpful.

RATING: 7
5 player game.  I like worker placement.  Was competitive with two players to have a chance to win.  7th round I picked up a 25 point quest which really the only way I had a chance, barely to win.  The end of round 7 I had 2 mandetory questions placed on me.  I don't have a problem with 1 being played as it does slow you down.  But, 2 in a row was a crushing blow that was unrecoverable in round 8.  I don't mind screwage buy boy two mandatory quests in a row was not fun.  I feel that there should be a limit of one at a time to be played.  The worst part was that I wouldn't have won with the 25 pt quest.  Should have some way to remove these.  Good game otherwise.  Without this kind of ending play I would rate as a 8 to 8.5.  I smell an expansion to have a way to nullify this.  Maybe bank some type of tokens (insurance in invest in) through the game to allow you to pay off without have them count as one of your quests for a turn.

RATING: 10
VERY fun game!  I realize it is a D&D themed cube-pusher, but I LOVE THAT!  I love the added segregation and luck-of-the-draw elements of the Quest deck.  I like the limited availability of the buildings and the escalating VP accumulation on those available for build.  I even like that some of the Intrigue cards are MUCH better than others.  It all boils down to a FUN game... definitely not as optimally balanced and strategic as Caylus, but way more fun!  I can't wait to pick up a copy of this game and play with Mark and Harry.

In fact, my impression of this game just displaced Caylus in my list of 10's.  Now _THAT'S_ something!

RATING: 9
This game is a wonderful gateway to multiple game mechanics.  It will appeal to your friends who like property owning games, it has quest completion for those who like instant gratification, it offers an excellent introduction to the worker placement style of gaming, for your friends who like to mess with everyone else; intrigue cards will be their directional choice, and lastly, it has a D&D theme.  Probably about the most universal game in my library.

RATING: 7
This essentially replaced Stone Age for me. It's a light Euro with easy little optimization decisions. It's definitely not a brain burner and the level of immersion isn't high. The theme is the thinnest of frosting (the fact that I do like fantasy themes helps a little) that wears off quickly. It's got a little "take that" and a little VP chasing and a little strategy. It seems like a good selection when you have about an hour and want something pleasant but not consuming; my favorite review of LoW called it "mostly harmless." I am glad to have it in my collection for these occasions.

Growing Strong, halfman!

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This, along with Pandemic and Viticulture, are currently my "holy trinity" of games. Which basically means that these are the games I'm ALWAYS down to play. LoW is a fast, breezy entry into the worker placement genre. While the theme may run a little thin (it can easily turn into, "I will now turn in these cubes to gain victory points"), if you allow yourself to be immersed into the world of LoW, the game becomes supremely more fun.

Things I love about the game:
- Intrigue cards range from mildly annoying to extremely helpful, keeping every round fresh and exciting.
- There is no "one way" to play the game. Wanna buy a bunch of buildings? Go for it. Wanna focus on simply completing quests for victory points? The option's open.
- A novice player always stands a chance against a more experienced player.

Things I don't like so much:
- While the different role cards try to add an element of asymmetry to the game, every role card in the base game is basically the same. Skullport alleviates that, but only if you're willing to pay $30 more.
- Some of the building and quest actions are WAY overpowered. For example, one quest allows you to have an extra agent for the rest of the game. In a two player game, this action alone tilts the scales WAY too drastically.

All in all, LoW is a great game. It plays fast, allows you to employ strategy to your liking, and generally speaking gives everyone a chance to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Still a favorite!

RATING: 9.5
This game is so good and one of my all time favorites. With the expansion this game is easily a 10 for me. Even the base game gives you tons of replay value with the different lords, the different quests and how they feel to play, the variation of how to achieve certain strategies it's just a fantastic game. There is something very simple and elegant about the board and mechanic design that is very pleasing to play through. I am becoming a big worker placement fan and this is my favorite worker placement that I have played so far. I have Caverna on the way so that may change but right now I'm in love with this game after over 20 plays. The intrigue cards add so much depth and complexity and can really mess with an opponent's strategy. If you see this game absolutely buy it. The value you get for the $40 to $50 dollars is so much more than many other games at higher price points. An easy buy for me and one of my top 5 games ever.

RATING: 7.5
Fairly light euro worker placement game. Nothing ground breaking in terms of mechanics but it's all fairly solid. I think I'd like it more if the theme were a little more prevalent: the fighters, clerics, etc., you recruit are strictly 'resources'. It would be very very easy to rebrand this game into a typical middle-ages trading or commerce game. Still though, pretty fun and not a huge time sink even with 5 people.

04/08/2013: Played with 4 people, more fun. Bumped to 7.5. 

04/04/2014: Well here I am a year later bumping it back down to a 7. Still a 'good' game but definitely not in the upper tier.

03/27/15: First play in a year. Good fun. Back up to 7.5. Predicting bumping it down to a 7 this time next year based on an emerging pattern seen in my comments above.

RATING: 9
Another game combining familiar elements, but does so in a crisp way and with a new theme. Competition for resources is at just the right level. If you find yourself short of acquiring them, then Intrigue cards can help out. Neat element with Intrigue cards allows for a late attempt at another action to make up for action, in player order. Seems very well balanced overall. Only complaint is why the Quest cards come up randomly with the wide variation of victory points, instead of in stages. Need to grab these early when they appear and hang on to them until they can be paid for, even though it might seem like wasting a precious action. UPDATE: Bumped down one point after second play. Seems that building a building may not be a good strategy, as others will use it before yourself, even though you get a small payment for it. Have to play again to see how it balances. UPDATE: Expansion enhances play tremendously.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This game is the poster child for "more than the sum of its parts."  The theme in this game is completely pasted on - it is a standard cube collection and efficiency worker placement Euro.  You can build buildings, and there is a mild take-that element, but basically you collect cubes to fulfill orders (er, "quests"), score points, rinse, repeat.  And yet... the game is incredibly fun to play.  The components are a treat, and the gameplay is buttery smooth.  In fact, this might be the gateway worker placement game bar none (eat it, Stone Age).  And while simple to play, it does have variety, as the buildings provide extra action opportunities, but likely only eight or so will get built in any one game.  So, strategies will shift based on what's available (and also based on what type of quests are being collected for endgame scoring).  The game scales very well.  There's really no reason not to get this one, unless you're looking to flay a litch or something...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Lords of Waterdeep is a beautiful game. It's a cube-pusher, yes, but with the DnDeeples, the game feels like it's more than just a collection, but rather does feel like it harbours the mystery and intrigue that the game advertises. A great pickup and I don't regret it in the slightest.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Easy little Euro, almost like a kid's version of Agricola with a D&D theme. I can see why people hate it for its simplicity, but come on, it's not like Agricola is rocket science. I hope the expansion adds some much-needed complexity to the gameplay.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
It's good, it's breezy.  I'm not sure what the ideal number for this game is, but it's not 2, and it doesn't feel like it's 5.  I need to play it with 4 and see how that strikes me. It has theme, but it's a bit pasted on, though they did a better job than other euros do.

RATING: 8
A very solid Euro game, even more enjoyable if you like D&D (included in my rating).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A faster and simpler Caylus.  Adds some random elements (intrigue cards, quest cards order) that can result in interesting situations.  Good for what it is, but I would rather play Caylus (or Stone Age or Tribune).  The D&D theme is completely superfluous, so don't let that stop you from trying it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I like this game less every time I play it.  See below for a more positive initial impression, from when I rated the game a 7.

The game feels like it has no room for strategy and is dominated by luck in card draw.  If you can't get quests of your type, you have little chance of winning.  For most of the game, the decisions are extremely easy: what is the scarcest available resource you need for your quests?  Get it.

Sure, there is a bit of strategy about when to acquire quests, build buildings and in which order to complete things.  But it feels like drops in the bucket.

The game doesn't have any significant problems - it's easy to teach and quick to play.  I just don't like it.

-------

This is a great introductory worker-placement game.  I think it makes a better introduction than Stone Age, even.  And I like it enough to have picked up the "DnDples" that a BGG user is making. :)

That said, I don't think it's a fantastic game.  Quite a bit seems to be determined by luck.  Do you starting quests align with your Lord?  Did someone else get the quest that gives them an extra player early?  Do you have the Piety/Commerce Lord but no extra cleric or money buildings have come out?

It's a fun game to play, but I'm not sure there are enough tough, strategic decisions.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Impressed. Plays really cleanly and smoothly, without grit. This is what a worker placement game should look like. Not a dynamic or dramatic game, but a lot of legitimate choices and well-done flavor coupled with an elegant design.

There is probably more chaos here than you might think, just from the feel of the game - plot quests with good powers can be swingy, intrigue cards can be strong or not at the right time or not, and there is some random screwage at times. So it's not a game you'd want to play for blood. But it works and is fun and I can add it to Pillars of the Earth and Tribune as worker placement games that actually work for me.

RATING: 9
Pure excellence
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A good introductory-level worker placement game, but I'm not sure it's really of much use beyond that.

Basically, Lords of Waterdeep strips the worker placement genre down to a very simple level.  Almost every available action space is to get yourself cubes (which represent clerics and other typical fantasy band members) or money.  You then turn in those things in for points (fulfilling quests).

Borrowing from Caylus, players can also build buildings, which are new action spaces players can use to get cubes and money, but also give their owner a bonus when used.

And since this is a D&D property after all, of course the game had to have a more Ameritrashy element to it!  There are three action spaces you can use to play special cards from your hand, many of which are of a "take that" variety, some of which are rather game breaking, frustrating, and un-fun.  I actually think the base game mechanics are solid (I guess they kind of have to be since everything here is directly borrowed from other games, and then simplified), but the "take that" cards are pretty annoying.

Some how, some way, this is a completely generic worker placement game that has won over a lot of the Ameritrash crowd, which I really find incredibly entertaining.  The game is straight up "get cubes and money, make a set, cash in for victory points" and almost nothing more, but slap D&D on it, and voila!  Ah, gotta love it.

Overall, while I don't think it's a great game, Lords of Waterdeep is a very valuable game to the gaming community as a solid intro to a popular game genre.  The simplicity is probably good in this case, as I assume the game is appealing toward the RPG sector who may be more unfamiliar with this style of game.  However, as a gamer, I only found it mildly interesting, mainly having utility as a gateway game into the more interesting worker placement games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I would have rated this higher, but I found it similar to Dungeon Petz in playstyle and prefer the mechanics and theme in that game to Lords of Waterdeep.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Played with Scoundrels of Skullport expansion

It isn't terrible and it wouldn't kill me to play it or anything, but for me nowhere near the top of the mounting pile of available worker placement games. I like worker placement, but there is really nothing here that feels new. 

Standard resource conversion - Gather resources, use those resources to acquire points or the ability to generate more resources. There are Caylus like buildings that are owned by players and available as additional actions to the players. The skulls seem like a necessary addition, adding some downside to taking powerful actions and creating another layer of risk/reward decision making. 

Aside from the standard grab the spot first type of player interaction, what little there is poorly implemented - I hated the 'mandatory quest' cards you can lay on other people. I don't mind take-that style stuff in games, but it seems awfully arbitrary and pointless here, and most importantly not at all fun. It is a drag to both play them on others, and get them played on you. They are nothing but a nuisance. You are constantly losing a cube here or a few bucks there to intrigue cards, which in a snowball engine game like this can really ripple through the game. 

It works and plays smoothly. But with so many worker placement options out there, I don't see how this displaces the myriad better options.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I definitely understand the hype surrounding this game â itâs a very elegant eurogame which plays rather fast, scales well and offers you interesting decisions! Itâs a light/medium eurogame which can be played in around an hour with 2-3 players. I like it the best with 3 players as you have 3 workers available compared to only 2 with 4-5 players (and with 2 players I would probably play another game). 

The most interesting part about the game is definitely the intrigue- and quest cards which add a nice twist and variety! However, that is also my only gripe with the game: the intrigue cards called mandatory quests are devastating... If you are attacked with some of those, itâs extremely hard to win as you only get 2 points for 3 cubes â it severely hampers your plans and is a very vicious âtake thatâ element in the game, especially if played in the last round before you can complete one of your big quests... In some of my games Iâm pretty sure it was a classic example of kingmaking, so thatâs a little sad, but otherwise the game is a joy to play and the rest of the intrigue cards are perhaps imbalanced but not as bad as the mandatory quest cards (which I, being the most experienced player, typically receive...)

I think the theme is refreshing in a eurogame â itâs not about shipping goods in the 15-16th centuries! However, how people can claim that the game is thematic and even D&D-like is beyond me â this game could be rethemed in various ways and you could e.g. be a chef instead of a lord and then the cubes were various vegetables and you should complete recipes... Anyway, I donât really care about themes, so it doesnât detract from my rating â I still like the game quite a lot!

My primary gaming group has really embraced this worker placement game and I'm almost always glad to play it, though it lacks a bit compared to the "big" WP games like Agricola and such. After about 18 games I sold it, but have had to buy it again simply because it was so popular among guys who don't play a lot of games - and, as I said, it's a great intro to bigger WP games, so hopefully I can lure some of the players into playing Caylus or even Agricola...!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pretty fun, liked the strategic options such as cards that can be used to remove adventurers from other players or gain them yourself (or a combination) or using your own building versus hoping someone else will use it.

Felt it was heavily random in many areas.  The Lord you receive is supposed to shape your strategy to some extent, and definitely gives you a direction to head, but can't be counted on too heavily.  You may have difficulty finding quests of the correct type, or the right adventurers to complete those quests.

The buildings that come up are random, may not show up in a game, and may not get built, and may not provide a certain type of adventurer.  That adventurer type, being rare, will cause a backlog of quests.  The bonus VP on buildings is intended to force buildings to cycle, but with 3-4VP on it in a game where quests are worth 8, 11, 15, 25, the extra VP from building is pretty negligible.

Finally, the quests are random, although the ability to cycle them is supposed to alleviate this it didn't seem to do well at that in our game.  Quests that were not ideal for the Lords in play or required a rare adventurer kept clogging the quest board up.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game made us love Worker Placement and Euro games and introduced us to opening up to playing more complex Euros like Brew Crafters, Puerto Rico and Caverna

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Rated 5 after one play. Well, I've had the chance to play a number of worker placement games prior to this one. So a rating is difficult without weighing this game against some other solid titles.

I supppose Lords of the Waterdeep is supposed to be different because of the theme and the card play. But, man... that theme is totally absent in the actual game play. The game is grab cubes, grab cards that tell you what cubes you need, turn in cubes for points. We were laughing at the total disconnect between game play and the "flavor." This strikes me as an attempt to coerce Ameritrashers into Euro game mechanics. 

At the same time, those mechanics are still subpar compared to other worker placement game. The "take that" aspect of intrigue cards is more annoying than anything, and the random draw of quests and buildings feels a bit too random. I mean, the game is not bad, but there's plenty of other options. It did make me want to play Carson City though!

RATING: 5
An entry level worker placement game, but the DnD theme has no interest for me so I could care less to play this again. Like most entry level games you go to spots to get cubes, turn those cubes in to complete quests (score points), and that's about it. I will say Waterdeep has really good variety with quests and buildings that will be different every time and give you a different strategy each game to pursue. However, the game just felt so dry to me since the theme is lost on me. That means all the flavor text and the art while looked fine doesn't appeal to me so I felt like I was just pushing cubes around. Similar gateway worker placement games like Stone Age and Raiders of the North Sea pulled me in more and that makes those games far more enjoyable to me.

Reminding:
"You can complete a quest after moving an Agent out of Waterdeep Harbor - it is another turn."
"The game is made up of eight Rounds. In each round, players take a number of Turns. You can complete multiple quests in a Round, but only one quest each Turn."
[url]http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/773725/waterdeep-harbor-and-quests[/url]

RATING: 2
I played [thing=110327][/thing] once, and with a table of people who thought it was the best thing since sliced bread no less -- as they kept exclaiming through the game.  My recollection is of a thing, a sham, a mockery of a game which contained almost no decisions and almost no gameplay, but which required the players to go through the overt and rather demonstrative motions of playing a game, of continuously making game-like choices and actions without actually ever making any significant game decisions or doing anything interesting or competing in any non-trivial ways, all the while making the other players wait on faux tenterhooks in the suspenseful event that one of your non-decisions also affected them in a way they couldn't actually do anything about.  But maybe I was being charitable and so thought too well of it.

RATING: 10
Perfect example of theme and mechanics tie-in.  There are very few games in my collection that I would play every session and this is one.

Nothing new whatsoever, but everything makes sense, is a ton of fun and is well thought.  The game is almost perfectly balanced with a few power tiping depending on what buildings you draw making some quests more powerful, but overall, no game will be the same and the power tip can be compensated by hate picking quests.

My favorite game of 2012 so far... and probably will stay as is.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
:sugar: Preliminary impression:

Well, for good or for ill, this is where boardgaming is going, it seems.

It's a lite-with-a-"te" worker placement resource-gathering game where the resources are ostensibly people. It's quick, it has a light overlay of fantasy theme that's just enough bait for the hook to entice those with a close personal interest in owlbears into playing a Nerf-ball version of Caylus.

Like the old ads for Nerf balls promised, LoW will not harm lamps or old people.

In a lot of ways, this harkens back to the misty first days of the Euro boomlet ... Settlers, Carc, et al ... there's some strategy, there's some luck, it's not hard to explain and it's over before bedtime. That was what was intended and that is pretty well delivered. That said, if the collective judgement of the BGG Community is that this is [i]the twenty-somethingth best game in human history,[/i] I respectfully submit that the collective judgement of the BGG Community is smoking hashish.

Quibbling about ratings (especially as regards the new hotness) is a mug's game, of course, but still -- day-umm, peeps. This?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Ignore the doubters, this game is a classic!

What makes LoW fun is, of course, the card play. The simple backdrop of a generic D&D fantasy worker placement euro recipe filler is a perfect way to facillitate a super-fun, vicious, chaotic mad dash of a card game. That the game is the Intrigue cards was not at first apparent to us. It was only after several plays and after the card play really took off that we really went, hell ya, this is a game. Easily dismissable but, for us, some of the most fun we've had gaming.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game bring back dungeon and dragons to boardgame with a eurogame feel. The gameplay feels a bit like agricola in a sense that we allocate "agents" to perform one of the actions on the board and try to gather enough ressources to finish one of the quest. The addition of quests drawn at random and the intrigues cards gives a good replayability and not all games will be the same. There are also buildings you can add on waterdeep that allow additional actions for every player, giving a bonus to the owner if another player uses it. In that sense I never really felt like I was playing a lord in waterdeep sending adventurers on a mission. It felt more like I pay X ressources to complete the quest that gives me 10 points. However this taken apart the game itself is very well done and very fun to play. The gameplay will always be mixed between completion of quests and moves made to block the opponent and 1 wrong play in the last turn can cost you the game. Overall that game was a very good surprise, a well build strategy game that brings together elements that mixes very well, and yeah... I just forgot... it is in waterdeep.

RATING: 10
This is the game that made me realize I dig worker placement games. I'd always avoided games like "Agricola" and their ilk because they seemed so horribly bland and theme-less, but then here comes this theme-rich game with its lovely board and intricate strategy, and suddenly I'm hooked. Other worker placement games have impressed me since, but I'll never need my arm twisted to return to this classic. It's a master class of "easy to learn, hard to master" game design.

Also own metal coins and class-specific meeples.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
After 8 plays, still loving this game and bumped my original rating from 9 to 10. My wife loves Stone Age, but she now asks to play this instead, and she never asks to play games. No die rolling and in our two player games she's 2 for 3. Highly recommend for couples. Easy to play, theme is good but not too overbearing that non-gamers need to concern themselves. 

The 8 rounds make it long enough to develop some strategies but short enough to keep everyone's attention that the end is near, if that makes sense. This is not a heavy or even medium complexity game so don't look to this for a brain burner. Gateway game to other worker placement, resource management games with more complexity? Definitely! Good for families with kids. Yes. 

This definitely needs to win some awards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Lords of Waterdeep was a very fun and engaging game. After listening to the Dice Tower top games of 2012 I went out and got the game. It was described as a straightforward worker placement game with no revolutionary mechanics, but an overall well put together game. 

The box design is beautiful in my opinion. The artowrk is pretty nice (if not a bit bland). All of the components are nicely made (the DnDeeples would make for an excellent addition, however).

I played two games with a friend. I have not played many worker placement games, only having Puerto Rico as a basis for comparison, which is arguably not a worker placement game anyways. It took about 15 mins to get going, but we soon got the hang of the game. The gameplay is simple but engaging; I was worried the Lords would feel limiting, but they served as guidance as to which missions I would prefer over others. The Intrigue cards are great, adding another level of thought when playing the game.The game ended with a slight victory by my friend. 

From there, we dove into another game. This gameplay was more more confrontational (due in large part to the Intrigue cards drawn). I was able to deny my friend enough cleric resources to ultimately put myself ahead by a slight victory. The buildings drawn this time were also less helpful, leading to a game with lower scores all around. 

All-in-all a fun game. It is a nice introduction to Eurogames, and has my friend a lot more interested in designer games than he ever was before. I would give it a solid 9/10, and look forward to checking out the expansion to see what it might offer.

EDIT: After many plays, this game holds up for me with the expansion. It is fun, not too heavy and keeps me engaged every time. Great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Back to the basics. Simple mechanics intertwine to form an excellent game with both eurogame and amerigame traits. It has just the right amount of theme and randomness, without rendering any decisions meaningless. It's excellent.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Excellent game - is easy enough to learn and introduce new players, but has good depth of strategy. After playing with 5 people I found your ability to influence the game is much reduced, and if you lose the momentum then you can become a passenger for the rest of the game. In my view the game becomes less balanced with more players (particularly if you are the last to play on the first round and the first player marker continues to be taken early for a couple of rounds). Nevertheless it is a good game that is very fun to play. 

18/8/13 - Played again with the new expansion in two player mode. Playing again reinforced my view that it is much tighter game with two players. Whenever I have played with large numbers I have felt that whoever is able to build momentum early (possibly through a good combination of early quest cards) can run away with the game and be very hard to peg back. If you lose momentum early you will lose. I think the two player mode removes much of this and the game is much tighter with less players.

RATING: 4.555

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the first "modern" board games I played before getting back into the hobby.  Was put off at first by the idea of a D&D board game, but that alone shouldn't turn people away.

Quite a basic, easy to grasp, worker placement game.  This is one of a few that I show to people that don't play board games regularly, or who are new to the hobby.  Fair amount of player interaction involved with Intrigue Cards, but not to the point of being mean that will put non-gamers off.

Fun at all player counts, particularly larger groups (and always longer game variants).  Some of the best experiences I've had with this game have in a 2-player game, and scores have ended close each time.

RATING: 8
A solid favorite in my family gaming groups.  Easy to lose the theme of the game, although it can be played with a role-playing type of flair which can add to the fun.  Some have complained that it is just cube collecting and pushing, and this complaint is well-founded.  The redeeming quality of this game however is that it has successfully combined (although in a simpler form) many of the best elements of the various worker placement games.

RATING: 6.5
Post Wheaton effect buy. I like this game for it's easy...puzzle? I can enjoy this game with my Dad who was a D&D player in is youth. Though the main reason I keep this game is that Waterdeep reminds him of Brighton, and so I affectionatly call it "Lords of Brighton".

Being a Lord of Brighton is...satisfying, I think? The times I've played it I've enjoyed ticking and tocking away at the challenge. The worker placement is fun and I liked the decent blocking strategies, though I don't feel it was crunchy. 

I'd bring this out if my Dad asks me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I am revising my rating of this game to a '10' after about a dozen plays.   I currently have over 200 games and as of this time,  this game is my only '10'.

This game is fun, easy to teach, and plays in an hour.  Standard mechanics similar to Agricola or Stone Age, but in a bit simpler presentation.  The Intrigue cards offer a chance to mess with opponents by taking resources, etc.
The D&D theme is there, barely, but it's not a deal breaker or maker.  You may find yourself saying " I need an orange cube and a white one", rather than " I need a Warrior and a Cleric...".   
The box is a unique, 3-piece design, but the insert/storage tray is by the far the most functional and well designed I have in my collection.
Great game, great components, great value.
Dbro

acquired 3 2012 A $31.49

RATING: 8.5
My wife initially scoffed at it because "it's Dungeons and Dragons" but instantly became a cracked out maniac for it after that first play.  Now she'll play Agricola/Dominion/7 Wonders etc and has expressed interest in titles like Power Grid/Puerto Rico/Troyes without me steering her towards them.  

Although by no means the best thing ever, I think it would be fair to say that Lords of Waterdeep is the most important gateway game in my collection.  Everyone I have introduced it to loves it, and that stokes their interest to try out more and more of the gamer's games that have been sitting on the shelf collecting dust for so long.

RATING: 10
Like it for the same reasons the hardcore Euro people don't, just Euro enough without the excessive, place these guys, get something, trade in, to build something else bigger, trade that in, for bigger, repeat and lacking the overload of options found in many Euros. OK they did a D&D theme so what? Had to have some theme, excellent game, theme works. And yes it is not a true D&D as you know it, I guess that theme was hijacked and it can't be used in another type of game without upsetting the Fanboys. It does need something other then cubes for people, 25 x 4 colored meeples or disc with character embroiled would have been the icing on the cake. Guess they wanted to keep down cost. Only minus, very, very slightly cutthroat, somewhat like Mission Red Planet, less than Ticket to Ride. Shouldn't stop you from buying it.

Purchased Danny's aka Relax wooden meeple replacements.

http://boardgamegeek.com/image/1379043/lords-of-waterdeep

After playing this game more have to say it is well worth buying, very enjoyable. My only complaint with it is where they places the four upright quest cards on the board. If they do a reprint I hope they move this to the center of the board. The player at the opposite end of the board can have a hard time seeing the four quest cards laid out, other than that a prefect game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
+ Skullport
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
It's hard to explain how a game that's so straight-forward and simple is still satisfying for a gaming geek.  But maybe that's just it - some streamlined simplicity in a marketplace of over-complicated point soup games?

In LoW players are simply sending out their workers (agents) to various board locations to get resources (adventurers) to complete goals (quests) and gain victory points or other benefits to help in the game.  One smart addition to the mix are buildings that you can chose to build and open up new worker locations - and when other players use your building, you get a small benefit.

You might notice above that the theme here is a bit thin, but everything looks good and there are bits of D&D lore woven into the quest cards.  So that will satisfy fantasy enthusiasts, while keeping the game accessible enough for anyone that couldn't tell a halfling from a bugbear.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Components: Great artwork. A lot of care went into how to distinguish all the various components so they didn't just blend together in a sea of pieces. The box insert is expert. I wish the cubes were little fighters, clerics, rogues, and wizards.

Experience: Great worker placement game. Always something juicy to do on my turn. Lots of exciting opportunities, and only toward the end does it feel like counting cubes, trying to get in that last quest or two. More joyful and less punitive than Agricola, which this game has replaced for me. I really enjoy the quests; moreso than the lords cards, they ensure that each player has different motivations and value actions differently.

The more I play, the more I'm seeing different strategic options, ways to build mini-engines, maximize points, etc. Sometimes certain powerful quests come my way, but when they don't, I still have options.

First Played: 2013-12-14
Last Played: 2015-04-18
Plays (6):
2 players: 3
3 players: 3

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
A light, very simple worker placement game.  The reliance on random quests, and the occasional ability for a few lucky draws to skew the game does not ruin the experience, but leaves room for improvement.

There is a lack of variety in the worker spaces, and more actions alongside the 'get a resource/gold' or 'grab a quest' would be nice.  

Intrigue cards add decent flavour, and increase strategic play (with reassignment) and add an interesting factor.  Additional ways to acquire further intrigue cards would be beneficial (quests, starting player or grab quest seems a bit limiting). 

Overall for a light worker placement it plays very nicely, and keeps everything reigned in without overpowering new players or spoiling the experience.  Enjoyable for forgotten realms fans, or otherwise.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

The expansion really kicks the game up a notch; a great intro worker placement game that families can enjoy as well.

RATING: 7
A solid worker placement game, great for introducing players new to the idea.

You don't need to have any prior knowledge or experience with the theme (the Forgotten Realms setting for Dungeons & Dragons) to play. In fact the theme doesn't impact on play at all.

While the resource cubes represent warriors, wizards, clerics etc. People tend to refer to their colour more often, "I'll take 2 orange and a purple please."

The expansion adds some new stuff, I prefer playing the expansion over not.

Overall this game doesn't blow me away, but a good solid reliable game I've enjoyed many a time.

RATING: 7

RATING: 7.75
Lightweight worker placement with a fun theme. Gotta love domesticating them Owlbears. Building mechanic does a pretty decent job at injecting variety into the game, but building cost and abilities seem a little unbalanced, and intrigue cards vary greatly in utility and value. Some quest cards seem only "worth it" if you're lucky enough to get them early. The game is otherwise well-balanced and tends to be relatively close.

Highly elevated by the expansion, Scoundrels of Skullport, which has several mechanics to mitigate my complaints.
