=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Over the months that I've owned this game I've played it far and away more than any other game that I or any of my friends own. The rules are easily learned, which makes each successive game more streamlined, the randomness of what buildings are up for grabs makes each game different (to varying degrees) and the fact that each round is broken up into different workers matched with the building owner bonuses lessens downtime to negligible. The theme has been flamed for being "paper thin" by many users and I completely disagree, but in a way they wouldn't predict. At times, the theme *is* paper thin and at others, it's deep enough to warrant a battlecry for your faction. It all depends on how much D&D you've played before, how the game is going, what actions are being paired up with what locations, your playgroup, etc. etc. etc. At its worst, it's a worker placement game that's always different enough to keep you coming back for more. At its best, it's a romp through a crazy, ever-expanding city vying to screw your neighbor and emerge victorious.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Solid game with some things I like & some that I do not.  The rules are simple, making it a great game to teach to rookies.  I could see this going over well on my family game nights.  The theme is thin enough that I don't think it would scare anyone away who doesn't like the idea of D&D.  There is competition for resources, but there is always usually another way around the block to get what you need.  It's a great way to keep things friendly, while still being able to slow down your opponents if that is what you like to do.  It is a light game, but still lets you plan a few moves ahead.  It is a pretty good mix, but just a little too light for me to want a lot of plays.  I would like one more play to see if I change my mind, however.  The only thing that really bothered me was the lack of a hidden scoring element.  Ya, ya, I know there is one there, but it is too limited.  Your chance for hidden scoring is predetermined before you start playing, and all players are going to get roughly the same bonus unless they are sleeping.  So there is really no way to be sneaky.  With all that said, I would play it again if asked.  I might also buy it for the family gaming group.  But I wish it had just a little something more to pull me in.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

with meeples!

RATING: 5.11565
Played twice. Perfectly functional worker-placement/action-drafting game with balanced actions. The 'quests' to be completed are not always balanced, though, and nor are the cards to be picked up. 

In one game, I caused one played to drop out of contention. Probably the best move for me - putting me one spot higher - but I don't think that screwage has a place in this game.

Perfectly functional and a game I'd be happy to play repeatedly and explore. But at the same time, it just doesn't excite me in the slightest.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Whether you are collecting purple, white, black, and orange cubes or acquiring the services of Wizards, Clerics, Rogues, and Warriors, this game is fantastic for all types of players.  With a Dungeon & Dragons theme, you might expect a game that is dripping with a fantasy theme, but it's really only there if you look for it in the flavor text, card titles, and locations.  Aside from that, you have an engaging worker placement with a splash of interaction in the form of Intrigue cards.  But that little bit of interaction and take-that provided by the Intrigue cards prevents this game from being just another dry Euro.

It plays in an hour, and feels really fulfilling throughout.  Three player games are more open, but still fun, whereas five player games are crowded and cut-throat--and require new buildings to be added in order to have something for all agents to do.

It's just a great worker placement game with plenty of variability provided by the different Lords, the different Quests, the Intrigue cards, and the random additional buildings.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A strategy game based on worker placement and resource management, Lords of Waterdeep is a must have game if you are a D&D fan. Set in the city of Waterdeep along the Sword Coast of Faerun, LoW is played in turns where you try to gain the most points possible. You do this by buying buildings, setting adventurers out on quests, and playing cards that help you in certain ways. After 8 turns are over the person with the most points is the winner. Lords of Waterdeep is a favorite of most D&D players like myself and should be on the shelves of any D&D enthusiast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Nice, simple worker placement game with a D&D theme, but it really requires the Skullport expansion to make it interesting.  Don't let people 'get cubes' instead of recruiting a Mage! Without at least trying to bring out the theme the game can get a little dull. We also make people read their completed cards to help keep it interesting.   

Includes D&Deeples, just so it at least looks like you have a band of adventurers in your pub.

DNDeeples
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Worker placement in a Dragons and Dungeons environment, a succesful marriage in my opinion. There are a lot of cards in the game which immerse the players in the theme, without actually crawling through dungeons and fighting monsters. The players can choose quests from a display, and complete them by gathering a combination of money and 4 differently coloured blocks, representing fighters, magicians, clerics and rogues. They gather these resources by placing their workers in different parts of the city. During the game extra buildings can be built, each with their own properties. Every player can use these buildings, and each time this happens, the owner of the building also gets a reward. One can also obtain intrigue cards. These cards introduce an exciting surprise factor in the game.
The game is played over 8 rounds, and halfway through the game the players receive an extra worker. Game play is fluent, especially during the first half of the game, but as more buildings are placed on the board and more intrigue cards are collected the options grow and the action choices become increasingly difficult.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Super easy to teach, yet the story has a lot of depth and playfulness, especially if you take the time to introduce some of the quests you're running and add the broken token dndeeples.  This is my favourite light game to play casually.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A decent worker placement game (though you don't really get many workers to place unless playing with 2-3 players). It's a great gateway game, but it's a bit lacking for anything else; with quests being the only way to score points, it really just comes down to finding the most efficient way to acquire the cubes you need to finish the quests your lord card gives you bonuses for.

Still, it's pretty fun, easy to teach, and the components are nice -- though I would've preferred plastic figures to wooden cubes; it never really feels like you're amassing warriors, wizards, etc, just colored blocks.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
+Skullport Expansion

When played as the base game only, LoW is a simplistic worker placement gateway that has a useless theme slapped on in the hopes of attracting the RPG gamer to the world of euro board games.

I hated it.

1st change was to replace the cubes with DnD meeples and now it feels like you are playing with agents instead of souless wooden blocks. I didn't think it would matter, but it does.

Adding the expansion really helps because 1) Use of corruption markers create a new level of tension that was sorely needed, and 2) the expansion boards offer some really useful locations that let you pursue your quests instead of getting locked out places you'd like to go when you're finding the built buildings less than useful. Now it's much more of a strategic, efficiency race.

It's still simplistic, but now it's more interesting and does a better job of rewarding smart play.

RATING: 7
Strategically straightforward but tactically deep, the difference between winning and losing is maximizing each turn. Hence, despite the obvious worker placement rules, it really is an action efficiency game. The blocking is less of a factor than doing the best thing with your action, which is why my opinion went from average-low to higher.

RATING: 8
I used to play DnD with some friends and so that made the theme more enjoyable.
If your group is the kind of people that would bash on the theme they might not like the fact of playing but that doesn't mean they wouldn't enjoy this solid game.
It was my first worker placement game I played and I liked the feel of the game.
It is easy to learn and every time you play it can bring a different strategy that can be played depending on your Lord,buildings & quests that appeared.
While the rulebook & cards can be really thematic the Adventurers components lack it and are just colored cubes.
If you like/love this game I recommend investing in some DnDeeples.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
If you enjoy the D&D theme, it does add something to the fun-factor, particularly if you're willing to buy into it - to trade in warriors and clerics rather than oranges and whites - and are playing with others who are.

Theme aside, the game perhaps doesn't offer anything that couldn't be found in other basic worker-placement games - however, it does it in a really streamlined and elegant way. With experienced players, it flows really well and offers engaging choices without being AP-prone.

There are perhaps some slight balance issues, with regard to the luck of the initial draws, and the hidden Lords are a little dull in the base game but overall this is an excellent light-medium euro.

PS: Worst box ever - too big, too flimsy and the insert is way too fiddly to be worth bothering with.

RATING: 8
Great simple worker placement. I used to play a lot of D&D so the theme (as pasted on as it may be) appeals to me. 

Place your dude and get your cube. I prefer Stone Age's resource acquisition by rolling dice which makes things a bit more risky.


I wish there was more incentive to figuring out who other people's lords are other than knowing (rather than assuming) the other player has 20-30 hidden points.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A decent worker placement game with some take-that opportunities for player interaction. It's fun and (for this sort of game) nicely fast-paced.

The hype, of course, is the Dungeons & Dragons theme. Does the theme actually shine through in the game? Nope. I tried pretty hard to get my RPG-loving kids to call the cubes "adventurers" and to say what "quests" they were completing... but instead they just said "I'm turning in two white cubes and a purple cube for 4 points".

Because that's what the game *is*... it's not an adventure or questing game, it's just drawn that way.  ;-)

(Check out Tom Vasel's review... he tries so hard to call those cubes clerics, rogues, etc.)

EDIT: The expansion (Skullport) adds enough elements to this game to make it worth keeping.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Probably one of the lightest worker placement games around, which is not a bad thing at all.  Leans more on luck than heavier games like Agricola.  In the same light, your decisions aren't nearly as damning, as your strategy can quickly and intuitively be readjusted.  The focus on instant scoring over end game scoring makes your turns more satisfying.  The variety in the cards and quest rewards opens the doors for many different strategies.  The game takes nearly no time to learn and you will have fun during even your first game.  Highly recommend the Skullport expansion. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Simple to learn, and with lots of possibilities for player-player interaction to give it an edge on an otherwise Euro-style game. The theme is very well implemented, as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Middling action selection game that fans of D&D will no doubt enjoy. Unfortunately, I felt that players who get the cube generating buildings and/or the plot quests in the early part of the game have a substantial advantage over those that don't, at least in games with 4+ players. It might not guarantee you victory but it sure helps, especially if those plot quest bonuses happen to line up with your character's bonuses. The same holds for a player who gets an extra action marker early. Also, you're pretty much toast if a couple players team up on you with early mandatory quests.

The net result is yet another game with a rich-get-richer problem which, while not severe, is probably going to affect the end game. And frankly there's really nothing particularly original about this game. The theme is thinly pasted on. The high rating is yet another example of how a good theme tends to blind the BGG community to mediocre mechanics.

So [i]Dominant Species[/i] still stands as king of the action placement games IMO, and even [i]Lancaster[/i] is far more interesting.

Update: A bunch of games on the iPad pretty much confirm my initial misgivings about the game. I've heard the expansion helps, though. We shall see. In the meantime, this is relegated to the iPad only.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My favorite game.  Extremely well balanced.  Own it in digital form as well.  Stellar game.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is an elementary, engaging worker placement game, although not really an innovative one. The mandatory quests, though, are too unbalancing; those need to be removed or their use limited through house rules. In fact, the attack cards in general invite retaliation. The game can devolve into an unpleasant affair in which the players' plans become nearly useless, and the prime 'strategy' is fending off attacks and completing mandatory quests.

RATING: 2

The insert is so perfectly organized you can literally be playing within one minute. The rules are likewise extremely streamlined.

However there is NOTHING original in this game to explain its meteoric rise through the ranks.

Edit: I hate this game. I recently bought the iPad version, no idea why. Playing it reminded me why I sold the board game years ago.

I had heard expansions fix the problems of balance and luck vs length. They do not. They seem to make it worse. Will not play again, ever, in any form, for any reason.

RATING: 7
I went into this thinking "Oh great, another weak effort to port AD&D to a boardgame."  Well, I was wrong.  They've taken the fairly tried and true, if stale, mechanic of worker placement, and really snazzed it up with the Quests and Intrigue cards.  The little touches of theme are just enough to flavor the game nicely, without being to heavy-handed.  A very solid game that has quite a bit of replay possibilities.  I would compare this very favorably to Pillars of the Earth, another WP game that I enjoy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of my favourite games. 
+ Worker placement
+ Player interaction through cards
+ Changing goals during play (quest cards)
+ Extra bennefits through buildable buildings
+ Hidden goal end-scoring
+ Plays well with two players. The buildings however are more usefull with three or more players. Both game experiences are different, but are unique in their own way. (More space on the board vs more income).

The Scoundrels of Skullport expansion is a musthave if you own this game. It adds new pathways to the game where you can gamble your luck if you fall behind. It makes the game perfect in my opinion. Risk vs reward.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Players are lords of Waterdeep, recruiting parties of adventurers to complete quests on your behalf.  Standard worker placement where players alternate taking an action, denying it to the opponents.  Most actions gain cubes in four colours (clerics, wizards, warriors and rogues), after which these can be paid back to complete a quest card. Quests rewards players with points and other stuff, and often an ongoing ability.  A deck of Intrigue cards enables mild road blocks to be tossed at the opponents, which can hinder them but isn't as outright nasty as other games of this genre (Caylus, Manhattan Project).  All in all, a good, tight game that retains a nice sense of theme, and produces close finishes.  Classy. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I also have the Android app.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Meh. Not a bad game, as far as Worker Placement games go, but nothing great either. Lots of luck as to what Intrigue/Plot/Lord cards are concerned, so you may be in for an easy ride if the right combo comes up, or more likely will have an uphill fight in the other case.
It's fairly easy to play, with straightforward decisions to take most of the time.
It's not bad, it's just that there are much better WP games out there.

RATING: 7

Felt less stressful and more fun. Not having to worry about "I must get x amount of food by turn y" was nice.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
A lot of people seem to regard this as an amazing awesome game.  I don't.
Don't get me wrong, it's a solid little worker placement title.  There's very little in here I actively dislike.  Ironically, I'd like it more if everyone else liked it less, since the biggest strike against it is how overplayed it is.

There are a couple rough edges, like the wildly varying power of cards.  Getting a plot quest that matches your type on the first turn can be crucial, as that gives you an advantage from the turn you complete it.  Having an extra flow of cubes, points, or actions can be the edge that lets you win the game.   Getting a plot quest late, though, is crappy, since you won't have time to make use of the power and it provides fewer points.  Intrigue cards also have a lot of useful ones, some situational ones, and a few that are really weak.
You get no control over your initial 2 quests, and there are few things in the game that let you discard uncompleted quests for any effect.  So, one player may get 2 that dovetail exactly with his lord's goal, while another will have to spend early actions fishing them out of the inn display, if there are even any there.  
All of the goals are really the same, except one.  You just have 2 flavors of quest that you like, and that's it.  The one that's the most different (buildings) is also the most swingy.  If you can get it rolling, you can crush with it, but it's tough to do.  The more players, the less likely you'll be able to camp on the start player and builder's hall spots, and whether you see any quests that give you buildings as rewards is totally random.  It's also very obvious and easy to block, so even if you're not winning, people may go out of their way to stop you.
For these reasons, winding up as start player on the first turn can also be a huge benefit.

It feels like a few tweaks or house rules would sharpen this one up a lot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
The first time I played this I loved it.  Every time Ive played since I've liked it less and less

RATING: 8
Wow, a great little worker-placement game that has never failed to impress. We're big fans of this one, and it works great as a two-player game. 

The expansion adds corruption, which I really like. Unfortunately, adding a sixth player really increases our play time. We tend to play games where we just about always have to teach them to new people, and a 6-player Lords took about 2 1/2  hours to play. It's fun, but there isn't enough there to keep me interested after 2 1/2 hours. Now, five players is excellent, usually about 1 1/2 hours. Especially if everyone knows how to play already.

RATING: 6.64
Easy worker placement game in a fantasy setting, placed in my favorite fantasy world: Forgotten Realms. 
My longest lasting and all time favorite D&D character, Grima Ravenlitch, which I am playing for more than 7 years now, is born in Waterdeep. When I saw this game on Tabletop I just knew I have to own it.
I enjoy this game more than it probably deserves, but overall it is a decent worker placement game I like to call "fantasy Agricola", although it is much much simpler, but with some player interaction.

[b]Update:[/b] Upgraded to 7 with Scoundrels of Skullport expansion, mostly because of cool corruption mechanic and risk of high negative point count in the end.
[b]Update:[/b] Rating modified according to a custom rating system.

[b]Favorite mechanism:[/b] Plot quests that give you additional options for the rest of the game when you complete them.

edit: play without mandatory quests, and it's a way better game. Also, draw more quests in the start, and choose which to keep, to minimize luck-impact on the game (you don't get any Q for your char, someone else gets both Qs).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Probably the easiest worker placement game to teach and learn.  I almost feel as if it's too easy.  I'm used to games taking a few, if not several plays, to mentally digest.  The design on this game is so good, that I understood how everything fit together from the first play.  I like my games to feel a little hard to get.  Lords of Waterdeep bared it all the first game.  If you've played other worker placement games, especially the Rosenberg games, this one is going to feel real easy.  You're going to be scoring points like Kareem Abdul-jabbar.  You're going to slam dunk so many quests, the backboard is going to shatter, which can be a little anti-climactic if you're used needing a few plays to get your head around a game, perhaps a little disappointing.  I like the game fine.  It plays super smooth and I alway love the tension that in game scoring tracks provide.  It just moved a little too fast for me to actually fall in love with it.  

A lot of people compare this game to Agricola and Caylus, but I actually think it has the overall feel of Ticket to Ride.  You basically throw down your workers to get resources (that feel like train car cards) that enable you to complete quests (that feel like destination tickets).  You're also doing some set collection a la artifact cards in Stone Age.  I'm going to go against the grain and say this game feels like a cross of Stone Age and Ticket to Ride.  It's a good time!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

would not refuse to play if strongly requested but i wouldn't seek it out either.

RATING: 9
Traded 6/18/13 for Antiquity
Reacquired in 2015 for $22 @ Walmart
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Lords of Waterdeep is a worker-placement game set in the D&D city of its title.  Players act as secretive Lords vying for control/influence over the city.  Utilizing agents (workers) players will recruit adventurers (warriors, rogues, clerics, and mages) to complete quests and score points and gain benefits.  The basic buildings at the start of the game provide players with the different types of adventurers, allows a player to build, pick up a quest, or gain money etc.  

In addition to the basic starting buildings , there are many other buildings that offer rewards often greater than the basic buildings.  A player claims ownership over the buildings they build and will gain a side perk everytime another player uses that building.  This is a nice feature of the game and makes decisions to use other players' buildings an interesting one since it provides its owner with a benefit.

The game also features Intrigue cards that can be used to give you (and often another player) a utility, an attack, or a mandatory quest that forces the target player to complete it at a very inefficient cost before other quests.  Some people don't enjoy the take-that aspect of the cards, but I enjoy the added player interaction and the ability to prevent a runaway leader.

All in all, Lords of Waterdeep is a fun lighter medium weight worker-placement game.  Definitely recommended.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Played 4 times now, just love everything about it.

RATING: 10
One of our favorite games. So simple, yet has a lot of deep strategy decisions involved. With the custom meeples, makes it even better experience. Gets a play a week, and still never gets old. Can't wait to see what the expansion will bring.

Any game I can teach my mom and she picks up in turn 2 and starts throwing evil cards my way is a win in my book. Its not as deep as some would like, but any game you can teach people easily in 10 minutes, and they pick it up and enjoy themselves is a win in my book.

It is a superb gateway game, and many fans have this featured on their family game night.  I actually know of one family that has 3 generations playing it together.

This game will have a presence in the gaming industry for some time, and hopefully there will be more games that make attempts at doing what LoW does well.

RATING: 5
Waterdeep has just about everything a gamer should expect, without anything additional to set it apart. Erecting new buildings, and subsequently owning them, is the most interesting aspect of the game, but the game still boils down to collecting cubes and completing quests, which makes the narrative incredibly linear. Had I played it earlier in my gaming career maybe my opinions would differ, but it terms of modern board games it is decidedly average.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Played once, and was surprised by how good this was.  Yes, it's not very original, but it's good to see a D&D themed game with modern design.  Also, while I like adventure games, it's good to see WOTC break out of that mold and try something new with a very adventure-focused intellectual property.  I'd happily play this again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I have played this soooo much on the ios so was hesitant to purchase physically.  I found a great deal on it, played it, and it's still just as fun.  Wonderful game.

RATING: 8
I typically enjoy the base game at different player counts, although I do not like to play with Mandatory Quests with only 2 players. This is a solid gateway game and an excellent introduction to worker placement games. The theme is pasted on, but with the theme and the nice components, it is a good way to get someone with fantasy interest to try a euro. In general, the components and storage tray are great, although I dislike the art on the lord cards. When played with the Scoundrels expansion, the game goes up to a solid 9 for me.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Simple and fun worker placement game. Nice Euro design all around... themed into Dungeons and Dragons. It is the game I pull out when discussing "hybrid design" and *why* the board game community *needs* more games like this.

Intuitive, easy to teach, easy to play. All those things describe Eurogaming at it's finest. Beautiful artwork, confrontational card play, solid theme. That's what American gamers enjoy.

Lords of Waterdeep brings it all together in a great mix. The essence classic Euros with *the* classic American theme. 

Oh. And the insert doesn't suck.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Beautiful, simple, elegant worker placement. With more players it gets interesting having to be more creative in figuring out how to get your resources. Intrigue cards and balancing time VS total number of actions taken add a huge dimension of strategy to a game that initially seemed a little flat. Very excited to try it with the expansion.

Location: Kenthorpe

RATING: 7
I like Lords of Waterdeep. But I can't help feel a tinge of disappointment because I really wanted to like it. It's a good worker-placement game. It is much more forgiving and friendlier than other worker placement games. There isn't the sort of tight worker placement situations you get in other such games. (You know the ones I mean, where if you don't place properly, you're screwed.) But this also means that at times, the game will feel slow and boring. Components-wise, I thought the artwork was evocative of Waterdeep but  cubes do not equal adventurers to me! (Maybe it's the RPG player in me.)

RATING: 8
(Rating including expansion: [thing=134342]Scoundrels of Skullport[/thing])

A great light weight and streamlined worker placement game that has a low setup time. Great as an introductory game to worker placement and maybe even as a gateway game (provided the theme appeals). Really like the buildings and the Intrigue cards and Quests that set it apart from other worker placement games. Okay with 2 players, much better with 3, probably best with 4, a bit too long with 5.

RATING: 9
This light worker placement game gets high marks due to its stellar track record as a gateway game. It has brought more people into "our" kind of boardgaming than any other game I've ever had or played.

Yes, it is light. Yes, the random elements make it less an euro than you think it is. Yes, you can start play and have all the players realize the mechanics within a round or two, making long rules explanations uncecessary. It can replace the usual line-up of dull as dishwater trivia games played with the family or friends and open their minds to a larger world of gaming.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Broken Token Insert, D&D Meeples, in one box w/ expansion

This one used to be one of the higher rated games in the collection.  It was our first worker placement.  The theme, while thin, worked since I've known about the Lords of Waterdeep since D&D 2e and Undermountain.  

The base game got better with the expansion, but the game eventually started wearing thin.  Game play boils down to the same formula (unless you're the builder) for each player every turn.  After that it's up to the random elements to help the game along, which ends up being pretty dull.

This game went from a high 8 or low 9 to a solid 6.  I'm keeping it around as it's a good introduction to worker placement games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
I love, love, love:
- the Intrigue cards and getting more actions if you play them
- the simple, straight-forward worker placement mechanism
- the upgraded adventurers we bought on Etsy
- the buildings benefiting both the user and the owner

I dislike:
- that the theme is rather pasted on, and even with our upgraded components, it still ultimately feels like I'm just getting resources, putting them back, getting points, repeat
- that some of the buildings that just aren't that wanted during a game end up sitting for a few rounds because no one wants to pay for them or use them, so no more good buildings come out till someone gives in and buys one
- some of the Lords don't offer bonuses that are as good as others
- the Lords don't really offer anything special; even if someone figures out you're after Arcana and Piety, they probably won't sacrifice their own chances at more points just to take those cards from you, so they might as well not be secret unless you really like to pay attention to the scores
- the Mandatory Quests--were those really a thing in DnD?

Final verdict: It's a decent Euro game with some take-that moments, a pasted-on theme, and a meh feeling of accomplishment at the end.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This game is a hot mess.  Worker placement games are typically about action efficiency and engine building.  In Lords of Waterdeep, there is very little engine building, and too many random elements.

Things they could have done better:
1.  The buildings are terrible.  Split the buildings into an A stack and a B stack.  The A stack should be all those long term use buildings used for building engines.  The B stack should focus more on double-use tiles.  How many times has a building come out near the end when you've gone "Oh, well that's useless."?  Answer: too many.

2.  You should have more control over your quests.  Either have one stack per faction, or split them into A/B stacks again.  This brings me to

3.  Faction leaders are boring.  Having them as hidden information is not terrible useful, as they're easy to deduce.  It would be better to give people open information and some bonus for having that leader instead (maybe get +1 warrior when taking warriors, those types of things).

4.  Remove the Mandatory Quests, or at least give people some reward for them.  The "Take That!" element of the game is tacked on and used for a quick laugh; it adds nothing to the game proper.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Sleeves: Ultra Pro (penny)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Includes:
* Lords of Waterdeep - Scoundrels of Skullport
Almost required expansion to the base game. Skullport and Undermountain add interesting and powerful location to the board, usually shaping the course of the game or at least influencing plays (Q + play I is a powerful effect).

6th players adds depth to the game altough it can be a bit long, expecially if players are good (lots of thinking time).

Corruption is for me the best mechanic. Choosing between risking to loose point in order to rush quests or buildings are play conservatively can make or break a strategy, and corrupted effect are very powerful. Without it, the game might become a bit streamlined (actually never played without skullport, could consider playing without undermountain). Overall almost mandatory expansion
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A simple, yet satisfying worker placement game. My geek friends found and enjoyed a plethora of Forgotten Realms references. The only quarrel I have with this game is that, despite what the box says, it's nearly unplayable with 5 players: you WILL find yourself with nothing useful to do more than one time, if someone who played before you has an agenda similar to yours. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Here's my problem - theme. As others have stated here, it's a fairly standard worker placement game, which is fine, and no doubt mechanically sound. What annoys me though is how opaque the theme is. I'm a Lord of a what now? Doing something with Wizards and buildings and missions and what? All just to get Victory points. I generally dislike Euro games and Worker placement games, and this is a good example of why. Many gamers say they dislike Abstract Strategy Games, since there is no theme. Well, I dislike dry, pointless mathematical excercises that pretend that they have a theme that matters.

RATING: 8
This is one of my favorite games that came out in recent years. Is it perfect? No. Is is a deep game? Not really. Is it a lot of fun regardless of the outcome? Yes. It might be my favorite worker placement game. I love the fact that more places come out where you place your workers as the game progresses, and that there are sometimes opportunities to re-use the spaces other workers have already taken. The use of Intrigue cards in Waterdeep Harbor gives a variable number of worker placements and more opportunities to fulfill quests. I'm not so keen on the Mandatory Quests; they can be really nasty at the end of the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.09
Lords of Waterdeep is a Euro-styled worker-placement game that, although on the light side, offers a plethora of choices and depth. The theme makes it feel a little more "fun" than other Eurogames, and it is the perfect game when you want to just relax and have some fun without resorting to more arbitrary, goofy games like King of Tokyo. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Easy to pick up and love the theme.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Lords of Waterdeep in my opinion is unique since it combines D&D theme with worker placement mechanic. The art is very beautiful and invoke a strong theme, however this theme is somewhat reduced by the publisher's decision to put in the workers's meeples as "cube" instead of adventurers/D&D characters as they should be. You can buy the customised meeples to improve your gaming experience, but that is more money spent.

The gameplay is interesting, with lots of player interactions through Intrigue cards, denying your opponents important workers etc.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.4
Lords of Waterdeep is the sort of game that can be very swingy, and very dominated by the luck of the draw.  The theme is severely pasted-on, but if you're an old timey D&D nerd like I am, and you put some effort into role playing and enjoying the theme, it can really pop out.

DnDeeples (and forcing other players to call adventurers by their proper titles and not just colors) are an absolute necessity to get the most out of this game.

Despite the fact that, objectively, I think this is not a particularly [i]good[/i] game, I manage to immerse myself in the thin theme and really enjoy the process.  Sometimes a balanced, elegant game system is less important than having some fun placating the walking statue.

Update: decided to give the ios app a try (to support board game apps) and it's mildly entertaining to play on my ipad, but I still feel no need to otherwise own the game.

RATING: 8
A good, light worker placement game.  Great for introducing new people to Eurogames or to hobby boardgaming in general--this could be the next rung up from "Ticket to Ride".

While my heart is with its heavier brothers (Agricola, Le Havre, etc.), LoW offers a lighter, faster romp that's often perfect for a low-stress game night.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
I have never really liked worker placement, except this game.  The main thing that makes this game a great worker placement is that you do not need to pay for your workers in any way. In fact, there is a way to extend your workers AND get a bonus by using waterdeep harbor. 

It's great that you can directly hurt and help other people via card play. The take that element must be used judiciously and as a potential target, you must plan for your situation to change quickly.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Wizards of the coast take on a euro game, yet still set in the D+D universe.

You collect cubes to complete quests for victory points in this worker placement game, where the number of options increases through the game with the building of additional places to put your workers, but the number of workers you have remains very low (2-3).

Secret identities at end of game for bonus victory points are a nice touch however the game gives you far to many intrigue cards which you then can't use.

Its all just a bit bland, not enough workers (and no scope to increase your worker pool) for it to really be worker placement, too many options on placement so effectively no blocking your opponents, just a bit bland and uninspired really

I want to like lords of waterdeep because its a cool and interesting theme however I just dont. I don't like it
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Simple, clean entry level worker placement with a D&D / Forgotten Realms / Neverwinter theme. I am definitely interested in the expansion.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Rating history: 9|8|6|4

Played 3 times for 3.75 hours.
2p - 1
4p - 2

Stone Age was beautiful, but the game never really grabbed me. Lords of Waterdeep is the light-medium worker placement I've been waiting for. Euro sensibilities, with quests, action cards - very nice.

2013AUG30 - 2 players wasn't as enjoyable, but still fun, and moved very quick. Dropped rating a pint to an 8. Still my favorite light worker placement game.

May 2014: Reflection rating. One of the better cube-flipping point-salad games, but just...no. This one is simple, fairly symmetrical, and too much over and over.

July 2014: Another play of this game confirmed my reflection rating from May. In fact, after my third playing of this game, I actively do NOT want to play it again, and so am rating it a 4. If I'm going to acquire things and flip them into other things, I'd rather play Ora & Labora or Le Havre. It's true those games are much heavier, which means I'm still waiting for a good middleweight conversion game.

LoW is very abstract - just grabbing colored cubes to make simple sequences. The game is almost two short to get a real feeling of accomplishment (Glass Road does more in less time). The game is fairly symmetrical in the resource distribution (purple/white at 1 cube per grab, black/orange at 2). Many of the buildings are slight variations on each other.

Rather play...
...a heavier similar game: Ora et Labora, Le Havre
...a middleweight with some flipping: Glass Road
...a shorter abstract: Splendor
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What a gem and what a surprise!  Don't let the name Dungeons & Dragons in huge letters plastered across the box fool you--this is NOT Dungeons & Dragons, not even close.  This is a resource game with quests.

Rules are simple and easily learned.  The game lasts 8 rounds, play is relaxed and fun.  Each player's unattained quests and resources are common knowledge so strategy is important when a player deals out attacks or rewards.  Switching positions on the score track is common, and game end can reveal an unexpected winner.

The game also has one of the really nice inserts.  It is a bit fiddly putting away, but there is a place for everything and when the box is closed & even transported, and the quality contents stay put.  

All really liked this game.  Looking forward to some obvious expansions.

EDIT: I have played a lot of games now with a lot of people.  I haven't begun to tire of it, and everyone has liked it.  Increased the rating.

Increased the rating again.  How appreciative we all are for the simplicity of this game.  There is no question what to do on the board; All the quests and their rewards are clear; The building benefits are obvious; and the Intrigue cards are all unambiguous and easily understood.  The rules are easy to remember--don't play it for a year (unlikely) and pull it out and start playing.  How nice it that?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

For instance the plot quest reward that makes you gain a rogue (black cube) everytime you gain some gold.

Mathematical optimization & resource management to the max !

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I've only played the iOS version of this game--and only against computer players--but from what I've read it's an accurate adaptation so I feel okay about rating the boardgame version. I don't have much experience with worker placement games, but this one seems very solid. You have more on your mind than just placing cubes, for example, with quests and "intrigue" to take into consideration. Also, you have essentially two types of workers:  one type actually do the work and occupy spots on the board, and one type are essentially currency that helps you complete objectives. This is a high scoring game but so far it seems very balanced. Commonly I'll have a game where the winner has, say, 120 points and the next two highest players are within 5 points of that. Definitely a good sign.

Since my game group doesn't have any real worker placement games in our rotation I'm thinking about this one, especially since the group is also our D&D group.

RATING: 8.5

Well, this game is pretty light by worker placement standards, and having tired myself with boring brain burners like Agricola and Caylus, this was a positive thing in my book. That's not to say it's a shallow game. It's a simple game that is as frivolous or deep as you make it. Casual gamers can dive in and have fun, but there's enough meat for serious gamers looking for a serious challenge.

RATING: 8
I've had people complain that it borrows too much from other games, but that is fine with me because it borrows stuff that works and works well together.

Ignoring the theme, it is still a classic Euro game. Yes, not the first worker placement by far, nor the best, but still great. The theme is worked into it in many little ways that you don't realize how much it is integrated with the logic of things like the quests. So good.

I bought this when it came out and I've taught this game to dozens of people over the years (would not doubt it is in the triple digits by now), and many have gone out and immediately bought it afterwards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Owner : sven
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A great, accessible, entertaining worker placement game. Everyone seems to pick this up easily and everyone I have played with has enjoyed it.

Yes, some of the decisions and penalties aren't that heavy - you're family aren't going to strave a la Agricola - but it just plays really well, is quite breezy and then picks up in intensity towards the end when you work out that you can't do everything you want. It's nice to start looking at some of the none VP benefits of completing quests and start chaining these into other quests. Players seem to love getting the combos to work.

It isn't the heaviest of games but it is fun, it plays at a good pace and doesn't overstay it's welcome, and it keeps you interest until the very end as there are nearly always options to mitigate certain actions having been taken without losing out too much.

Our games have always seemed to finish fairly close which also keeps all of the players interest high.

It's not the BEST.GAME.EVER. but I do find that when I'm playing this game I am enjoying myself more than I do playing certain, more respected worker placement games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I'm not sure I will ever understand the appeal of resource optimization games coupled with random take that elements and both targetted and untargetted mayhem.

Ignoring this part for the moment, Lords of Waterdeep cobbles together various elements from other games in the worker placement genre without actually adding any new ideas of its own. That integration work isn't badly done, and the resulting game is a little flat but otherwise a nice enough entry-level worker placement game - excepting the hooliganisms mentioned at the beginning. But maybe those are what is requested by the game's target audience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Great game suffers from running long (esp. at 4-5 player).

Das thematisch in der Welt der Adventure Quests angesiedelte LORDS OF WATERDEEP ist ein angenehm einfacher und geradliniger Artgenosse ohne Hirnverschraubung: Worker setzen, Aktion machen. Fertig. Thematisch natÃ¼rlich genauso  aufgeklebt wie die Auftragskarten, die hier eben halt Quests durch das Spiel gehen mit genretypischen Namen und Fantasy Flavour Pics in fiktivem Mittelalter Ambiente. WATERDEEP gewinnt durch seine SchnÃ¶rkellosigkeit, die einen schnellen Einstieg in das Spiel fÃ¶rdert und es einem leicht macht. Es braucht die Windungen und diverse Ebenen komplexer Strukturen nicht, um ein Spiel zu sein, das in Ã¼berschaubarer Spielzeit auf simple Weise SpaÃ macht. Es braucht auch nichts Neues. Das ist WATERDEEP. Nicht mehr, aber auch nicht weniger.

RATING: 10
One of the first games I have even owned that I felt was underpriced for the value it gives. The components are excellent, wood pieces, solid cardboard, excellently designed box interior as well.
The gameplay is amazing. Worker placement with amazing options.  The quests add a level of excitement, with some having a lasting effect on the game. Balancing victory point options against each other, short term gain or long term plan. It's well balanced for all players.  And it has excellent replay.  The DnD flavor is amazing as well, each card has its own piece of flavor.  I can't say enough about it, it has immediately risen to my top five, and I don't see it leaving any time soon.

Again, familiarity and seemingly the single strategy is the winner who gets more 25 point quests has dragged the game down for me, but that said, it is such a clean obvious clear design of a game which is so nice. Still an excellent game to introduce newbues to worker placement, and the variability of buildings and quests still make it interesting for occasional play (Rating 8.088, Feb 17)

RATING: 6
Finally got to try LoW, which I've wanted to for awhile before taking the plunge on buying it. I'm glad to have played it, but don't think I'd buy it myself. There really isn't anything new here: collect cubes through worker placement and resolve Quests by cashing in those cubes. Of course, there's a bit more to it than that, and it is these extra elements that make it an enjoyable game. But I wouldn't say LoW is a great game - I'd much rather play Caylus, which has certainly inspired some of the mechanics here. I will say, the cubes really do hurt the theme of the game. I know this is a Euro-mechanic game with a very Ameritrash theme. But I would have so much rather used plastic figures to represent people than cubes. Hell, even graphic cardboard counters would have been better!

RATING: 7
A nice worker placement game with a well done theme that makes it more attractive to those who might not otherwise be interested in euro-style games.

The only complaint anyone had was with the art on the Lords of Waterdeep cards.  The portraits didn't seem to match the quality of the rest of the presentation.

Update:  after three plays (admittedly not a lot), where two included the lord that gives bonus points for building control, there's some concern that that lord may be underpowered.  It's also possible that it simply requires a different strategy to win with that lord.

Update:  and on the fourth play someone finally won with the lord that gives bonus points for building control (somehow that lord has ended up in three of the four games I've played).  Not to take away from his victory, but it did require some luck, mainly being able to grab and complete the plot quest that lets you use a location already used by someone else by the end of turn two.

Still not entirely sure it's balanced, but willing to keep playing with it for now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I like the base Lords of Waterdeep game well enough, but after a number of plays with the expansion, I would prefer to only play including it and not go back to the base game if I can possibly avoid it, the expansion just makes it so much better in every way.

RATING: 6.005
Light worker placement, prelim rating.  While there is a strong attempt at theme, when have you ever felt cubes were actually wizards, rogues, and fighters going on quests?  It's really an oxy-moron to even try this type of game, but so be it.  The game has a strategy element, but also a fair amount of chaos.  The direct interaction comes from a placement where up to 3 workers can use a card effect, which hurts or benefits one or more players.  For those who aren't fans of worker placement games, I can't see this theme-dressed version having any more appeal than a straight-up cube pusher.

RATING: 10
A dynamic mix of Stone Age and Agricola. Nothing really original though as the game borrows from the best worker placement games without innnovating - but it does so very efficiently.

The only negative IMO : in spite of all the efforts of the game designers, the theme will quickly become absolutely irrelevant. It is a matter of collecting then discarding cubes of different colours, not about recruiting wizards or clerics and sending them for epic quests... 

It does not prevent LoW from being very good and one of the most enjoyeable worker placement games - maybe the best ? LoW calls for more and more plays and does not wear with time. Deserves a 10.

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good game, easy to play and easy to teach!  Very gateway. I agree with most that the theme doesn't feel pasted on, the sending out of agents to do the dirty work is very in keeping with how the "real" Lords of Waterdeep works, reading out loud the title of the quest cards and calling the cubes by their character class adds to the theme quite a lot. I really don't know why WotC went with cubes, they could have made chits or something more representing instead.

The various functions of the location also makes sense, its not the sort of game where you can pre-plan your strategy, to win you have to leverage & respond to the quests & buildings available in the game as well as your hidden objective.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Caylus light with a nice fanatsy theme pasted onto a fairly typical cube pusher euro. This is one of the resourse rich style games more common of late - get as many cubes as you can and convert them to VP as efficiently as you can in the limited 8 turns of the game. Intrigue cards provide some limited player interaction but this is mostly about grabbing the action spot that you need and deniing it to the other players. Components are very good all round.

Rating dropped after adding the Scoundrels of Skullport expansion - added "take that" Intrigue cards mean that a player can be targeted and set back arbitrarily - not ideal (for me) in an efficiancy race game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The best introductory worker placement game out there in my opinion. There are enough options that you don't feel like you're getting completely screwed too often (like in Agricola). At its heart it's a solid mechanical eurogame with just enough D&D theme slathered on the top to carry it through. Excellent component quality, nice box, top notch (if fiddly) insert.

Mandatory quests may end friendships though. Just saying.

RATING: 8
This is such a nice, clean worker placement game, a genre which generally doesn't do much for me. Quick-playing, nothing fancy and nothing extraneous. Very well developed and pruned game.

While the theme itself is neither a positive nor a negative for me, I really appreciate how it all makes sense, even if it might be a little thin. That's a direct contrast to so many games where the overall mechanics and goals just don't make any sense at all.

For straight worker placement, this is a good starter, but ultimately I'd prefer to play Manhattan Project or Viticulture. The theme works better in those.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]Lords of the Waterdeep[/b] [i]Rodney Thompson-Peter Lee 2012 [/i]
This is a game I did not like that much the first time I played it. I compared it with Caylus, my favourite eurogame ever, and this is an unfair match since both games are different although the mechanics are similar. Waterdeep is an easier game, very well suited for newbies since it is very easy to explain and the players know from the very beginning what they have to do to get resources and money, something that is not present in more subttle games like Agricola or Caylus. This could be a drawback, but somehow the game is not shallow and provides meat for the experienced gamer. This is a very special game in this matter, and acts as a fantastic gateway game and also a good game for skilled eurogamers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

+ Scoundrels of Skullport

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
The best worker placement game ever!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a fantastic and highly interactive worker placement game. The hidden end game bonuses, the buildings that add spaces on the board with benefits for the owner and the quests that give you permanent bonuses add up to a very fun game. The intrigue cards gives even more interaction. The expansion does a lot for the game, but it's still fun without it. A lot of people complain that it's too simple, but there's a difference between easy to play and lacking of depth. Sure there's plenty of more complex WP games with even more depth, but the depth-to-complexity ratio is best in this game.

Also, best inlay ever made!

I'll add a recent comment:
[q] In my experience, LoW is the best streamlined worker placement game. Sure it doesn't quite sell you on its theme with a bunch of cubes pretending to be warriors, but it's so very friendly in its ways. It's simple to teach and it helps new players by nudging them so slightly with the lord mechanic. "Oh, I like Skulduggery quests! I see one there, I'll go pick it up. I see it needs some black cubes, I'll just head there next. Oh, there's a nice building that I can build that all the other players will use, that seems like fun." It's also the worker placement game I've played with the fewest spots. I think this is a strength of the game, because it makes the game less intimidating and the competition more fierce. As the game goes on, new locations are created by the players, increasing the complexity with a nice pace dictated by the players.

The expansion adds a lot to the game as well, the corruption mechanic is a favourite of mine. You can take better rewards on certain spots with the penalty of taking corruption. The more corruption that the group collectively takes, the more negative points are awarded in the end. This gives the game an interesting group dynamic and is very thematic.[/q]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Best Worker Placement game there is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Perfect for when I want to play a worker placement game but I don't feel up for a worker placement game. Contradiction? Yes. But so is this game - euro mechanics (light, admittedly) - with a tasty ameritrash coat of paint. A bit simple, but for some reason it hasn't gotten old. The quality of the game - from components, to the plastic insert, the box, the theme - I think it elevates what could have been a very mediocre game into something that I'll keep coming back to.

RATING: 8
Comparisons to Caylus make a lot of sense.  I don't think the strategic depth is the same here, and hence, it's going to be easier to get to the table with a broader audience.  For me, in my collection, that's the appeal of it, more than the fact that I love it.  But I love that it's easy to teach, and easy to understand, and easy to not feel like you're getting your butt kicked, and that most people I know will want to play it more than they will play Caylus (which I really do love).

RATING: 8
While it really is just a bland cube collector game underneath, there's just something about this game that makes it good. Ease of play, and fantasy theme make this an easy one to get non-gamers enjoying.

I don't know why, but exchanging the cubes in this game is very cathartic. Normally I'm bored by worker placement or cube-pushers, but LoW just somehow does it for me.

I highly recommend this one for anyone looking for a themed Euro that's a good gateway game, yet won't bore the gamer geeks in the group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Played on iPad. This is a little bit different worker placement game than I'm used to (because of quests). The more I play this game, the more I like it. The theme of the game may seem odd, but that's not a big problem. This game has nicely balanced strategy, luck and player interaction together. Lords of Waterdeep has some "back-stabbing" player interaction elements like giving mandatory quest to particular opponent, making some minor "bad things", which can distract some people from game, however, majority wouldn't have much problems with that, I suppose. Mandatory quests as player interaction element is balanced as well - they are easy to complete and still gives you some victory points. Great game, just the theme could be better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Absolutely LOVE LOVE LOVE this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The theme really adds nothing to the game. Lords of Waterdeep just feels like a generic, paint-by-numbers Euro worker placement game. There's approximately zero originality here. However, I did enjoy the game and would be willing to play again. The most enjoyable part is the logistics of sequencing the quests you hope to complete, making sure you have enough money and adventurers at the proper times. The intrigue cards also add a welcome splash of flavor and unpredictability that isn't always present in this style of game.

Overall, a solid and workmanlike game. I would like to have seen more opportunity for tactics and planning. But if you're looking for a lighter style of worker placement game and aren't put off by the lack of originality, go ahead and check it out. I think Lords of Waterdeep is aimed at fantasy gamers who probably aren't as immersed in the tropes and lexicon of Eurogames as I am, so the makers have (understandably) emphasized conformity and smoothness rather than innovation and subtlety.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

There isnât something inherently wrong with the game, but there is not enough distinctiveness and tough decisions for my taste. The spots where you can place your agents are crowded, but only a few times it was hard to know where to place it. What I really like in the game is the plot quests. There is no strong snowball economy building element of the game, but if you complete plot quests you get abilities which help you throughout the game barring that you sacrifice other rewards.

RATING: 7.5

RATING: 6

Opinion may improve with repeat play and properly calibrated expectations. Would benefit from a fairy dust sprinkle of RPG mechanics -- maybe powers for faction leaders, and the ability to level them up? As it is now, the mechanics of the game could as easily be applied to rushing around a warehouse preparing orders for shipment ...

RATING: 8
A eurogame with a Dungeons and Dragons theme. What a weird mix, but I like how it worked out. It's not the deepest worker placement game but the gameplay is very smooth and it's a really nice introduction to the genre. It's insanely well produced, as you can see right when you open the box and gleam at that amazing box insert.

iOS version but I have access to the physical version because I gifted it to my gaming buddy :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I'm not sure that it will have the longevity of something like Caylus, which it, ahem... resembles, but it's a great game nonetheless. Easy to play, so I should be able to get to know the various strategies.

August 2012 update: I'm starting to suspect that with 2 players, going for quests under 20 points is a waste of time, unless there are specific situational rewards that you need. Not sure if this realisation reduces my rating or not... probably not. In fact, I'm bumping my rating up for now, as the game's still very enjoyable after several plays.

October 2013 update: It's a very, very smooth game - the game's interface is superbly designed so that you're focusing on the strategy and not the rules.

August 2014 update: it's still excellent.

RATING: 7
Really awesome theme, quests are interesting and the worker placement is enjoyable. Nice balance of just having few enough options to make the game feel interactive but not cramped. Feels like you're never out of it: largely because of the hidden lords. Definitely feels like a gateway into the worker placement genre and makes me want to go deeper. 

If I could tear at this game for anything it'd be the setup/takedown, which as well organised as it is can feel like a drag relative to the complexity of the actual game. The insert is also kinda annoying now that I've moved to vertical storage, and it is too tight on the corners of the board, squishing them [-](Need to remove it at some point)[/-]. Removed it, base game and expansion in one box now.

RATING: 8

Rating = 10 due to it being a solid game, replayable, easy to teach people, & opens the fantasy world without it being too "fantasy". Will always play this game.

RATING: 8

If you want to move your friends on from party games to board games then this is a solid pick.  The graphic design and iconography is so good that you will be up and running in minutes and itâs pretty intuitive so you rarely need to reference the rules during play.  Further, it had enough decision points to amuse my group of war gamers, who adopted some strategic lines of play that I hadnât thought of. Still beat them, though.  So, something for everyone then?

RATING: 8
A good worker placement game with an excellent D&D theme.  Admittedly, some of my enjoyment of this game comes from my knowledge of the setting, having spent a lot of time in Waterdeep in D&D campaigns and computer games.  

The game itself is fairly simple but moves along nicely and always seems to throw up a close ending.  The hidden characters give extra VP conditions and these often are the difference between winning and losing at the end of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3.5
The game designers seems to have gone half way in the design. It feels like an empty game. I don't feel anything when I play this game, it lacks depth and you don't feel like at the head of a guild of adventurers. The "adventurers" just feel like a bunch of merchandise... even if you replace them with miniatures, they are just merchandise.
I will probably make a real version of this game, it's just too bland, shallow and empty.
The game was made like at 50% of what it could be. You don't feel like you have adventurers in your guild, more like merchandise that you spend or virtue like in The Village. You should not lose adventurers (unless they die) when you have some in your guild, you keep them and they continue to work for you.
Instead of cubes, the adventurers should have been cards that you get via a certain action and the cubes would be influence cubes. Each adventure would have a risk factor which would be reduced by the amount of adventurers you send, but the more you send, the less you will have for other adventures and the lesser experience they will each get.
I think this would have been a much more exciting game than this piece of half made junk that you play a couple of times and then move on to something else.

You would need to pay me to get this game.

RATING: 6
This is a bit of an odd one to me, because I've played the game three times, but never without the scoundrels expansion. I'm not a huge fan worker placement games in general unless there's some serious theme stacked on top with additional mechanics. I found myself having a delightful time with this game despite myself, but in retrospect, I realize that a lot of that had to do with the things added in the expansion. Without those additions, it would likely be another dry worker placement game for me. Also, it helps to play this with people who are really invested in crafting a story with the goings on in the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Lords of Waterdeep is a thematic worker placement game that runs smoothly and does not have any real flaws. Players compete to recruit adventurers (handled in the manner of resources) in order to send them off on quests that yield victory points. The quests add diversity by means of additional rewards that kick in on completion - such as permanent effects. Intrigue cards allow the players to directly or indirectly affect their opponents. 

All in all this is a great package. I thoroughly enjoy this one. To a considerable degree this is due to the way the theme is presented. It is that much more engaging than that of many sterile run of the mill euros (all of those medieval building construction and renaissance seafaring "themes" that are somewhat utterly generic). While none of the mechanics are new as such, they all fit into each other just nicely and produce a thoroughly enjoyable experience. One can understand the game and start playing within 5 minutes. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Also a fun one to play on iOS asynchronously. This game is rather luck based, with the primary strategic choices defined by your player card as well as what missions you have and are available, but it's still quite fun.

RATING: 10
Takes a lot from worker placement mechanics and wraps them up in a great theme, with the Quest cards as goals, and the extra twist of Intrigue cards that can really throw some surprises at the players. Play is pretty tense and *very* quick for a Euro, so there's not much time to enjoy the great artwork and theme text. But it's all beautifully done.

Will be seeing our game table regularly.

A few months later: this has become a regular go-to for game nights, has withstood a ton of play time and still seems fresh every game.

Two years later: bumping this up to my second BGG 10 rating ever. This continues to get plays and remain exciting, even without the expansion.

RATING: 9.5
Wizards have done well with this one. Even on opening the box and seeing all the gaps, holes, and slots for all the pieces an OCD wet dream. the box design truly is a work of art.

No longer contented to just wander the halls of the various caves, caverns and ruins of the D&D world we are now the ones sending unexpecting adventurers to their deaths and glory.

Resource gathering game, highly addictive and easy to get into. 

Reasonably friendly with no real vindictive PVP (outside of the expansion). 

Beautiful art work, great themes and many tributes to the RPG. 

If you like resource based games this is a must.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Pretty standard worker placement game with nothing new, but a quite good one at that. The rules are simpler than I expected, and although the board is somewhat ugly compared to the art on the cards, it is very functional.

The game goes quickly and is fairly strategic, although luck may sometimes be decisive, especially in the hidden objectives and offer of quests. If your types of quests don't show up and/or other players go for the same types, your score will suffer. And then there are the intrigue cards, which circumstantially may cause a little harm to some players and not others, or give a small benefit to a chosen player. But the mandatory quests may interfere too much with a player's plans and effectively take him out of the game, especially when played near the end. This type of intrigue card alone knocks my rating down by at least one and a half point.

Even with the rich D&D background, the game feels quite abstract, and some bad production decisions reinforce that. Buildings have just a non-descriptive name and no art, so that you have to look them up in the manual to know what they are. Adventurers are simply used as resources, gathered and spent to complete quests, and it definitely does not help that those brave heroes are represented by wooden cubes instead of the detailed plastic miniatures that you would expect from Wizards of the Coast. But being this their first foray into Euro territory, they seemly had some stupid misconception that Eurogamers adore wooden cubes and despise plastic miniatures. Well, maybe a few do, but those are probably the same who will not touch a Fantasy-themed game with a ten-foot pole, so what is the point?
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A decent worker placement game. I like that the 'buildings' come out randomly and the game play decides how many actually come into play. This should 'change' the character of the game each. I, however, did find it over all to be a 'great' game, it seemed much like other worker placement games. It did probably get an additional point from me (and may see additionally play from me) because of the relatively short play and easy to teach rules.

RATING: 7
I have vague concerns about the quests' balance, and how a player can get slightly rewarded or hosed based on whether or not their Lord overlaps with others' Lords.
That said, this is quick, clean, and very enjoyable. It is to Caylus what the D&D adventure co-ops are to Descent. That may not sound like much of a compliment to many, but I really like worker-placement, and I think that the D&D co-ops are a wonderful distillation of what is best in the genre. This isn't as good as the top-tier worker-placement games (for me, Age of Empires and Tribune), though.

RATING: 7.5
Wow, this is a surprisingly well executed worker placement resource collection game.  It strips those mechanics down into a very simple package, that works well. My first game took about an hour and fifteen minutes, that was with four players and a rules explanation for new players.  If it was two hours or more, I would probably be lukewarm on it, but its very fast and surprisingly well themed for a worker placement game.  

I don't think it will reach the level of critical acclaim that it deserves because the folks who really love this type of resource management game will be somewhat turned off by the artwork and theme.  The folks who are attracted to this type of artwork and theme will likely be disappointed that this isn't the game they were expecting.  Folks with a broader range of tastes will love it.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Sometimes, the theme of a game can carry it, even if the mechanics don't leave lots of room for strategy. D&D itself is perhaps the poster child for this kind of game, to the point that you don't win or lose, you just tell a story. So a D&D-themed worker placement game seems like it could really integrate a lot of theme into what is sometimes a dry genre of games. Unfortunately, that does not happen here. Not only are the mechanics rather bland and uninspired, they so take control of the game that there is no real sense of story or adventure. 

Players will place their workers on various spots around the board. The general choices are 1. Get Cubes 2. Get Money 3. Build a Building 4. Get a Quest. That last one might sound intriguing, but I assure you, it is not. Quests are simply ways to spend cubes for points. Money is used to build buildings (and sometimes in quests). Buildings create new spaces for worker placement. If this is all sounding familiar, it should. It's been done to death. The illustrations, cards, and pieces are all quite lovely so it's really a shame. The designers seemed so interested in balancing the game that they were afraid to add any really interesting wrinkles to the structure. All in all, it amounts to a boring game that is nice to look at. Shame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Fun worker placement game but the "mandatory quest" cards introduce too much take-that, and the game doesn't really need it.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
How funny -- they turned D&D into a worker-placement Eurogame!  There are buildings (like Caylus -- usable by all players, but gives the builder a bonus), quests (which are like contracts to fulfill), coins, and "resource" cubes (which represent fighters, priests, rogues, and wizards).  There are also influence cards, which can help players to get extra bonuses and/or hurt other players by stealing their resources.

There are only 8 turns, so it's important to realize that it may not be worth spending 5 turns to collect resources for a huge 25-point quest when you can complete 3 shorter quests for more points.  Sometimes it's worth doing a big quest if you can get enough cubes from completing smaller quests to help out.

Because of the 8-turn limit, and the rule that only 3 influence cards can be played each turn (because it requires a player to play a worker at one of the 3 places at Waterdeep Harbour), it's better to get influence cards early and not bother with them later.

The game seems fun, if a little random.  It's much easier to explain and play than Caylus, which is a big plus in my book.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fun game that starts quite easy and gets more complicated during the play. Easy to learn and teach.

RATING: 8
There is a little too much luck, but the match of an unusual theme (for that type of game anyway) and "intrigue cards" with a worker placement mechanism saves this one from mediocrity.
I find that the story telling aspect is weak, for a worker placement game that tells a better story I would pick Pillars of the Earth or World Without End, both games having stronger, more original engines in addition to a stronger story they unfold; yet Lords of Waterdeep brisk pacing and simple rules will appeal to a more casual audience, which is probably the target of this game.

In summary: a weaksauce worker placement game with an all too thin theme.

Fix: the extension that makes it a better game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Intrigue cards can make a huge points difference if used late in the game. You can basically get a card that can stop someone from gaining up to 31 points,(so far the highest score I have seen is 118) if things work out for your evil plots. I am not sure if this will happen often but in my first game I had one mandatory quest played on me on the last turn(the second of them played against me in the game) that cost me 18 Victory points taking me from 4 points from victory to last. Not the best feeling but at least the game is fun and fast enough for it not to hurt too much. 

The cards you receive at the beginning of the game and intrigue cards you draw during the game can also highly influence your chance of success, obviously good play after the game is well understood will mitigate this but if you get a few bad draws in a row you will really feel it at the end of the game if all your other moves are not optimal. 

Also if you happen to get a competing Lord card with someone else it can really lower your options as you will be directly competing for certain quests while other people have free reign over the quest they want. All told though coming in dead last on my first two games, having been a victim of a shrewdly played intrigue cards and then not reacting fast enough to an opponent competing for the same quest types I think the game is quite awesome and I am looking forward to more plays. 

Lords of Waterdeep is  fast, fun and definitely not multiplayer solitaire. You can and will ruin others plans as well as block their moves. If getting your plans stomped on in the last turns of a game bugs you stay well away from this one it has teeth.

Played a couple of two player games. This game is just fun. It plays fast enough to mitigate any bad luck and is still filled with decisions that matter. If you want something heavy this is not your game.

Just had a 3 player game I am bumping up my score. The speed of this game and the ease to teach people is just great.
