=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My family and I very much enjoy this game.  It is relatively easy to learn.  It is a game that provides numerous choices per turn, which is a big plus to me for any game.

An added item of interest is the secret "lord" that you receive at the beginning of the game.  This usually makes or breaks you in the end (with the bonus they provide), so this adds an interesting aspect, as well.

The only minor downside is there is some ambiguity regarding the text of some of the cards that you will encounter and their interaction with other cards/buildings.  Mind you, most are straight-forward and will be easy to understand, but there are others that may be a little frustrating due to lack of clarity (e.g. Zoarstar and the Ambassador is one example).

Also, it would have been nice to have more "lords" included and for them to have more unique bonuses.

All in all, though, this is a game I would highly recommend.  I labeled this as "Medium" weight, but really, this is a game that can be picked up by lighter gamers, as well.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[Initial impression: 9] Wow - finally got in a first play of this with 3 players. It is a delightful combination of worker placement & resource gathering with an added layer of hidden goals & multiple routes to victory. Long-term strategy is important, foregoing high-point short-term rewards for low value plot quests with lasting effects. Reminds me of favorites Caylus & Le Havre, but feels much lighter than either of these due to the theming. Perhaps most similar to the highly rated (but personally loathed) Agricola, due to the player-specific effects of the quest and intrigue cards, but questing through a kingdom is so much more appealing than growing a farm. I can easily see this becoming one of my few 10s if future plays remain this much fun.

Dropping this to an 8 after a few more plays. The Lord cards seem well-balanced, but some Intrigue cards are much more desirable than others, making the Intrigue-heavy strategies hit-or-miss depending on card draws. If one player is dealt the Lieutenant quest as a first card and completes it early, there goes the game. All in all, the card draws end up unbalancing the game a bit too often for my tastes. Still much more accessible and fun than other similar games, but I ultimately prefer the experience of Caylus or Le Havre.

The quality of the components is off-chart (You just need to take a look at the game once arranged inside the box to know what I'm talking about). The main board is simply beautiful, and so are every player's side board. The cards and tokens are sturdy, colorful, dreamy. The gameplay is light but deep, replayability is guaranteed by the game's modularity, and the interaction between players is frequent, but not so "direct" to make it aggressiveness. A must buy if you like board games.

RATING: 8

-With this one you are going to have an interesting  hour to spend.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
(05/2012) This is not a bad game, but I can't help but think it is nothing more than a re-themed, standard "generic" worker placement Euro, reminiscent of Le Harve and Agricola. The workers (agents) go and collect resource cubes (fighters, clerics, magicians, thieves) and/or money, which are then turned in to complete quests (to get VP and/or more stuff). You can also buy buildings, which give you stuff when someone else visits them, a la Le Harve. Unvisited buildings sometimes begin accumulating more stuff, sort of like Agricola or like "juicing" the unselected roles in Puerto Rico.

There is no novel mechanism to discover; there is nothing new here--it's all been done before. The theme is unashamedly, blatantly pasted-on. Sure, the artwork is pretty good, but whether it is D&D or sci-fi, it doesn't matter, as the game mechanisms are familiar and comfortable.

Strangely, that is where the game succeeds, in its utter familiarity. It's like the back of one's hand; it's "safe". I don't have to figure out how to game some complex mechanism; I just need to play the game and maximize my few actions, and foil the plans of my opponents. Just like any other generic Euro.

It's like vanilla ice cream. It's familiar taste that you grew up with. It's not the greatest flavor in the world--it's not Rocky Road--and you're not going to go out of your way to get it, but you know you'll like it. If someone offers you a dish of vanilla ice cream, are you going to complain? No, you wouldn't (unless you hate vanilla for some reason).

It's a solid, respectable '7', and there's nothing wrong with that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
THIS BETTER NOT SUCK

UPDATE:  DOES NOT SUCK

After a weak-willed impulse buy at my FLGS and a single play, I'm impressed.  The attention to detail on the physical design of the box and bits is breathtaking; the insert, especially, is a work of art.  Everything has a perfect place and comes out of that perfect place exactly the way you'd expect it toâin other words, you reach for the thing and touch it and it hops out of its slot and into your hand.  This, in itself, is brilliant.  Like an amusement park for opposable thumbs.

As for those bits themselves, they are wonderfully tactile and gorgeous, like the gold pieces which, while unusually shaped (squares for singles and larger crescents for fives, all with a hole punched in the middle), are also double-sided with heads and tails having unique, baroque designs.  The card art is very good and goes a long way to immerse one in theme.

This is the first worker-placement/trade-crap-for-other-crap "Euro" that fulfilled my need for a li'l somthin' extra, namely to not get stuck thinking in terms of grinding for nibs to trade for nobs and then scoring for dinguses.  The "take that" cardplay is fun in a way that anal retentive geniuses cannot countenance; fair enough, but when I played "Free Drinks!" to lure a critical wizard away from another player's tavern and into my own I learned the folly of wizards too fond of the bottleâa return play of "Arcane Mishap" caused him to detonate during a "spirited" demonstration of magical power.  I was cleaning innards and singed beard bristles out of the crevices for [i]weeks[/i].

On the mechanical side the game is quick and breezy, with occasional bursts of multi-ply puzzling to keep it engaging.  I've only played once, doing very poorly until the endgame where I managed to crawl into second place by paying attention to chaining opportunities while simultaneously dropping tactical turds into various punchbowls.  I enjoyed this very much.

There is a huge potential for variety in future plays, with more cards and buildings than opportunities to put them into play, as well as having them come out in a novel order each time.  Lucky synergies in one game could well be absent or significantly altered in the next.  How it all hangs together remains to be seen, but the obvious care, thought, and detail packed into it makes it an easy 8 for now. 

UP-UPDATE:  The second play had us all over the VP track coming into the final stretch; final score was 95-94-92-90.  Love it!

[b]After 11 plays:[/b]  Still going strong.  Yes, the "secret" scoring can be swingy, but really, it's not that secret (if you pay attention to what kind of quests your opponents are completing) and bank on all competent players getting somewhere around +30 points at the end.  Playing this with the same people means all our games have been annoyingly close... so much so I am getting sick and tired of LOSING BY ONE POINT.*

[size=7]*Especially when there's a bunch of table bumping and bag switching going on with the VP markers:  "Oh, I'm sorryâ[i]you're[/i] blue?  Where were you again?"  And BANG lose by one point.[/size]

[b]After 15 plays:[/b]  Bumping this to a well-deserved 9.  There is an enormous and non-obvious storytelling element lurking beneath all the mechanical meeple-swapping... Open yourself to it.  And then send those poor bastards to their DOOM.

[q="D&D flavor? You get out what you put in..."][floatright][imageid=1533570 small][/floatright]
The half-headed man and his apprentice sauntered into Aurora's Realms Shop to the tinkle of fine Elven bells.  The apprentice locked the door behind them.

"We're here for our money, luv," croaked Half-Head.  

Aurora startled, looking up from her ledger, eyes wide.  "But you people were just here!"  Behind the counter, a baby cooed in its basket.

Half-Head gurgled, the only part of his laugh not taken by fire or hatchet.  "That was then.  This is now."

"I-I-" Aurora stammered, "I don't have it!"

"Stab the baby," said Half-Head.  The apprentice hesitated for a split-second, then unsheathed a rude-looking dagger.

"Oh, Gods!  No!" Aurora shrieked.

"Easy, luv," said Half-Head, "you've plenty of healing potion here.  The baby'll be fine.  But [i]you[/i], you need to learn a lesson..."[/q]
[b]After 21 plays:  MANDATORY QUESTS AIN'T A THANG[/b]

I have won plenty of games where I was dogpiled with Mandatory Quests... [size=7]of course, I've lost just as many, too.[/size]

The only reason they make your forehead veins stand out as you poop yourself a little is because [i]you didn't plan for them.[/i]  Always assume Mandatory Questage and prepare for it, whether by salting away materiel or factoring an action/turn cushion into all of your plansâ[i]especially the critical ones.[/i]  Ending up in the embarrassingly pantsless position of only having exactly what you need to pull off that 25-pointer at the very end and getting royally hosed by a single small Mandatory Quest is not a design flaw or a moral failing of the person who played the cardâ[i]the fault is entirely your own.[/i]

PS.  Pimped with [boardgameaccessory=145782]DnDeeples[/boardgameaccessory].  A mandatory addition if you ask me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
The D&D is slapped on top of this worker placement style game, but in a great way.  DO NOT buy this for an RPG experience, but works amazingly well in the genre it is actually in!  

This is by far, my favorite game in its class.  Its fantastic and easy to play, quick to pick up and engaging.  It has just enough complexity in options to bring a deep gaming experience and plays better with more players.  

Highly recommended.

RATING: 8.5
I'm on the side of the fence that thinks Waterdeep is thematic. This is an ideal game weight with lots of polish and production value- a gateway game not only for it's straightforward mechanics, but also as a showcase for what can be done with cardboard and wood. Waterdeep benefits from having a back catalog of available art to fill every single card with gorgeous paintings. It's almost too good. I've added a bunch of upgrades like custom meeples, metal coins, and a custom insert. 

+Really good art and style
+Interesting choices and decisions
+Minor hidden scoring and deception
-I never get the impression the game is expertly balanced; instead relying on random draws to nullify power creep.

RATING: 9
Relaxing, low confrontation and beautiful artwork. Enough theme to invoke the feel of a D&D world yet no dice! 

Scoundrels of Skullport is essential upgrade because many of the base game's buildings are ponderously slow. Skullport speeds the game up with powerful and corrupt buildings for hilarious consequences. 

When one player easily pulls ahead by drinking deep into corruption, the temptation for others to tipple grows strong. Towards the end, immorality has touched everyone so there is a race to atone and rid the dark-blue corruption tokens. Suddenly all the shady players are bawling over each other into performing devout acts of piety. Funny and entertaining.

RATING: 8

Might raise my score on it once I try it. I think Champion of Midgard might be the next step for me in relation to a meatier game. 

Still LoW is a great solid game. Adding the expansion makes it awesome

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A simple worker placement game, where you place workers to take coloured cubes, hoping to reach certain combos that fulfil a 'quest'. This is quite a refreshing change in an industry that seems to be sharply ramping up the complexity of Euros in an attempt to extend the design space. There is some luck, white cubes are in short supply for instance, so to fulfil a lot of piety quests you'd better hope that a building comes out that acts as a white cube multiplier. Nothing very original or inspiring here, but short enough not to outstay its welcome.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Another bland worker placement game where you gather cubes to earn points. Interaction is of the absolute worst kind, blocking spaces and a massive "take that" element.

The worst part are the mandatory quest "you lose" cards which are ridiculously harsh and take away from any sense of planning that you might have had. So it becomes doubly bad - both bland and annoying.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's pretty common for people to compare worker-placement games with Caylus, whether this is warranted or not. In this case, the comparison comes from the way that buildings work; it's possible to use other player's buildings, but whoever built it gets a benefit.  It's still not "fantasy Caylus," but it is a nice, light worker placement game with some thinking and plenty of tension to it, and it's very pretty. It does seem like some of the quest cards are better than others, adding some randomness to the game. (1 play)

RATING: 6
The game has a nice simplicity to it and it's ultimately enjoyable to play, I would rate it a vote or two higher but unfortunately certain buildings and intrigue cards are too unbalanced and can break the game from the start. I can often correctly predict who's going to win just by the first couple of turns based on the first buildings purchased and the first intrigue cards played. Because the things to do are exactly the same for everyone, gather resources, complete quests, an early start can set you a step in front of the others and there usually aren't enough comeback mechanics to bring you back on top. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Plays like My First Worker Placement Game.  Has all of the mechanical similarities to the true standouts of the genre, but none of the subtle decision making or long term strategy.  The completely pasted on theme is neither a positive nor a negative, as it has absolutely no bearing on gameplay and thus can be ignored (if it's not your thing) or used to salvage the mediocre gameplay (if it is).  I honestly don't understand the enthusiasm for this game or what makes people come back to it time and again - its replay value seems pretty limited.

RATING: 8
Though the theme falls short in Lords of Waterdeep, your fighters, thieves, clerics, and wizards being simple resource cubes - the mechanics of the game are solid. Limited building space provides a rush to construct structures so you can gain benefits from others using them. But will you neglect your quests, necessary as they provide the primary function for victory points in addition to other rewards? The corruption track added in the expansion does wonders for additional player interaction, giving players an additional dimension of risk-taking.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A decent medium/light worker placement game similar to Stone Age or Agricola (but lighter than Agricola).  The theme is pasted on and has nothing to do with the game.  It is a typical Euro where you take actions to collect resources, then trade those resources in various combinations for victory points, with a few hidden agendas and special cards that can be played.  We didn't feel like we were "completing quests" in a D&D atmosphere; it could have been combining ingredients to complete restaurant orders, or running around a medieval village fulfilling a king's demands, or what have you.  Not a bad game if you don't mind pasted on themes.

I guess it would work as a gateway to Euro games for people who have only played D&D (the RPG) and games on that theme (fantasy miniature games, etc), who wouldn't be interested in a game like Stone Age or Agricola based on their themes.  Otherwise, I'd rather play a better worker placement game with a stronger connection to its theme that gives a better sense of accomplishment (e.g. Ninjato, Manhattan Project, Agricola, etc), rather than mindlessly fulfilling generic set-collection requirements.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
An overrated game because of his DnD theme which has just a worker placement mechanic and nothing more. There are much older but still better and innovated worker placement games out there which is deserved to be known but so unpopular because they haven't got a DnD hype on their back. Intrigue cards are so frustrating for long term well-thougth strategies and mandatory quests have highly kingmaker issues. Nothing to explore, nothing new and interesting. Nothing.

If you're asking a worker placement and resource gathering game, there are much much better games. Lords of Waterdeep is still a simple game (without its expansions) and lacks replayability but still could be a good game for newcomers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
[b]2 Player Review:[/b] 

Truth be told, I hadn't ventured to the realms of D&D since the likes if "Balder's Gate II". However, I feel like I had made a triumphant return with "Lords of Waterdeep". While it`s not your traditional dice rolling D&D adventure, the theme is so strong and well presented you really feel like you're there. 
The core game plays in under an hour, and managing your heroes and buildings while screwing with your partner via intrigue cards is a perfect mix. 
My only complaint is that the hidden lord system is flawed in that your partner can figure you out in about 2 rounds and can work to sabotage you accordingly. Luckily this is a problem that was quickly fixed in the expansion. 
Pick it up if you like resource management and a really impressively immerse theme. It`s just a little light compared to the other great worker-placement games out there with much more inventive mechanics. 

[b]Expansion Review:[/b] 

While the new mechanics do pretty much double the length of each session, the corruption, new locations and especially new lords, add an incredible amount of depth to an already outstanding game.
While the core game was frustrating when you knew you would loose from a poor start and a low score, I have had sessions in "Scoundrels of Skullport" where I won when 100 points behind. I played my lord carefully and managed to rid myself of corruption while increase it's cost in my opponent's tavern, and ended up winning by 3 points.
I honestly won't be going back to the core game again unless introducing a casual game to the ropes.
A MUST buy for anyone a fan of the core game.

[b]Pros:[/b]

- A great gateway game for fantasy buffs.
- Collecting house and heroes is great fun.
- The expansion adds a lot of depth and managing corruption keeps the game tense up greatly until the very end.

[b]Cons:[/b]

- The game is light and the theme, while great, wears off after several plays.
- The expansion is a great addition to mechanics, but it doubles the play time and make the game feel drawn out by the end. 

[b]2014 Rating:[/b] 7.35 [b]Plays:[/b] 0

RATING: 5
Solid mechanics, nice components, OK-to-boring solitaire-ish gameplay. For all the attempt at theme, I didn't feel like I was doing anything more than collecting sets of cubes. But then I've just never been that enamored with most worker placement games. Also, I usually don't like it when everyone has secret "get extra points for doing such and such" cards (everyone gets one of these at the start of the game), as that tends to add to the feeling of "doing my own thing, don't really know or care what the other players are doing" that I don't like in many worker placement games.

RATING: 9
I really enjoy worker placement games, and this one is one of the best. I like the theme (you play as rival lords in a Dungeons and Dragons city wrestling for power, hiring adventurers to go out and complete quests), and I enjoy the execution. The game moves at a quick pace as well, since each player takes turns placing one agent at a time, rather than playing out their entire turn at once before the next person gets to go. Definitely a favorite.

It turns out its only 45 to 60 mins, and could probably be churned out in 30 I bet with a few plays and that is a great length for the game.  

Great theme "present"(for D&D nuts), its not fully pasted I guess but close, I mean you really arenât adventuring around completing quests and definitely donât get the feel you are either even though this was the intention.  Its really a WP contract filling euro game, that moves quick, and gives you interesting enough decisions to make with how to score, and has a nice theme âpresentâ.  Iâd play again, and oddly enough would consider picking it up for good price just because its quick

RATING: 5

I don't really see a reason to ever play this over a host of other games, but it's not unpleasant and I can imagine finding myself in a group who wants to play it and just going along with it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Lords of Waterdeep is at its base a competent but uninspired worker placement Euro game. The game is so simplistic it doesn't provide the satisfaction of creating an engine, building sophisticated combos, or anything that makes modern Euro games enjoyable. The majority of the game is simply acquiring resources, turning in said resources for points, and repeating.

The game tries to spice things up with Intrigue cards. The intent is to make surprising moments and impressive plays. The result is that they ruin the game, introducing wild swings of luck and the ability for players to attack others with, unlike most Euro games, little cost in doing so. There is nothing enjoyable about having to spend precious turns re-acquiring resources or completing mandatory quests only because another player happened to draw a card and decided that should happen.

Combined with a pasted-on theme - this game could be about any activity where one acquires resources and turns them in for points - and it makes for a game I will never play again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Quinn

RATING: 9
Worker placement where you take on the role of one of the lords of waterdeep trying to build up your empire. Send your agents to recruit warriors, mages, rogues, and clerics to go out and complete quests to earn you fame and glory while establishing your foothold in Waterdeep.

The scoundrels of skullport expansion almost feels like a must have for the game and adds madness as well as spots in skullport harbor and the undermountain to place your workers (and possibly lose your sanity).

RATING: 6
Solid basic worker placement game.  I don't really understand the comparisons to Caylus - it is worker placement, and you benefit when someone else uses your buildings, and you use cubes to "build" quests.

But the buildings and quests come out randomly, there are hidden victory conditions, and the forms of interaction are significantly different.

Where does this game stand out?  It has simple rules, with essentially no space for confusion.  The randomness can help give you direction, and there are some means of mitigating it.  The amount of luck is congruent with the length of the game.  Some direct player interaction is a good thing.

In the end, I am not entranced by this game.  It is like going to the Olive Garden and ordering the carbonara.  It is not going to knock your socks off, but it'll be a perfectly decent dish capable of being enjoyed.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
2012-10-26

Initial Rating: 6.0 (October 2012)

Lords of Waterdeep is a, somewhat, light worker placement game. I do like worker placement games so I, more or less, like it but this is not a game I wish to play often.

The box of the game is very well designed with its open lids (I hope more games came like this), and the art is pretty cool. The game is hugely thematic IF you happen to know about the backstory, otherwise, much of the thematic atmosphere is lost but it is nice to have a worker placement with a fantastic theme. (I have not played Belfort).

On the good side, the game is very easy to teach, it plays very quickly and without any isue so there is almost no downtime. The game is very well done and it can be a good game to introduce to new gamers. The components are pretty and the overall quality of the game is very high.

On the bad side, the game is too light for my taste and it has a annoyingly high luck factor (due to the events, buildings, and intrigue cards) that decided our game. Sometimes you will get lucky and be able to get a good combo, other times you wonât (no matter how many times you change the event deck :angry:). Also as you can only build one building each round, sometimes (a lot of times) you wonât be able to get what you want. I felt I didnât have much control over the game, the best you can do is to put yourself in a position where, if lucks wills it, you can take advantage of the right mix of cards. 

Also there are some cards (intrigue, events, buildings) that are much more powerful than others so it is luck if you can draw them or not. 

And thatâs my main gripe about the game. Bottom line I felt the game has a lot of unfair elements without any way to mitigate them and that is awful to have in a strategy game.

Lords of Waterdeep is an ok game but not for me. I donât feel the urge to play it again, but Iâm sure I will play it in the future if Iâm in the mood. For now I prefer to play Agricola, Caylus, Pret a Porter or pretty much any other worker placement game I have played.

Current rating: 5.5
[hr]
2014-06-16

Nowadays Iâm playing Lords of Waterdeep a lot, but only on the iPad. In this format, the game weaknesses bother me a lot less as the game play time is critically reduced. Still LoW is not a game I will ever buy. Way too light for me, have lots of uncontrolled luck and most of its decisions are obvious.

Current Rating: 5.0
[hr]
2014-07-21

I played the game face to face again. This time with the full complement of 6 players (with the expansion) which was very bad as the downtime was excessive. I think LoW is best for 3 players. I have written it before, but the Intrigue cards are way too unbalanced. In every one of my games, luck has decided the winner. The game is very obvious and I also dislike the âattack the leaderâ mechanic with the mandatory quests. It is luck if you can get one of them or not.

Current Rating: 4.5

RATING: 6
What an average worker placement game.  There is nothing wrong with it but the theme is irrelevant and the mechanics are nothing special.  It's not a waste of time but far from the one standouts of the genre
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
Loads of fun. Leaves you wanting to play more. Finally a euro-style game with a rich interesting theme !! Game mechanics are incredibly simply - get a quest, collect cubes that match quest, turn in quest for points - however, the complexity is ratcheted up with the expansions and are a must have.  Further, the simplicity is where the game shines.  It is incredibly thematic, simple, but elegant fun and strategic. There is a lot to think about in terms of order of actions, blocking opponents, secret bonus conditions, the purchase of buildings that provide you a benefit if others use it. The amount of meaningful and even at times complex choices and decisions add a surprising amount of depth to this deceptively "simple" game.  A great gateway game, but also a great gamer's game. The IOS app is also a fantastic implementation of the game. While stand the test of time and is one of the greats. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Not a particularly memorableaction drafting game.  Just about every element of the game is implemented more interestingly in other games.  It's probable that I'm not among the intended audience.

RATING: 9
This is  one of the first big tabletop games that I've fallen in love with. Before Waterdeep, I had mostly played deckbuilders and the occasional game of Catan. I love strategy video games so this worked for me as well.

This game really showed me the wonders of modern tabletop gaming. It's simple and easier to set up that meets the eye. There's so much excitement at the end of the game when one of your bonus quests just barely gives you the win. 

It's a good game to introduce friends into intermediate strategy in tabletop. Play a few rounds of a lesser strategy game and then bump it up to this if you have a new group.

RATING: 4.5
Yes, I do see the usefulness of this game that it is a very easy worker placement game for beginners. But as a guy who was fairly experienced with heavy worker placement games, I was expecting more when I was getting into this game. I came into the game with the wrong mind-set, and it is influencing scoring heavily. Then again, scores that I give are subjective - and I rate them based on how much I want to play them so 5 is where it is going to sit for now.

I would have forgo how light the game is if the theme has been executed extremely well but no. Theme here is just a paste - cube pusher. You can call the cubes a wizard...or whatever but it's boring. You could have just retheme'd this game into Blacksmithing game where you collect different colored ores to forge different magical weapons to gain points. Yap, boring.

I don't see much appeal to play this once somebody introduces anyone to better worker placement games out there.

RATING: N/A
[b][url=https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/864240/2012-golden-geek-awards-nominees-announced-voting]2012 Golden Geek Nominee[/url][/b]

In Lords of Waterdeep, you take on the role of one of the masked Lords of Waterdeep, secret rulers of the city. Through your agents, you recruit adventurers to go on quests on your behalf, earning rewards and increasing your influence over the city. Expand the city by purchasing new buildings that open up new actions on the board, and hinder â or help â the other lords by playing Intrigue cards to enact your carefully laid plans. At the end of 8 rounds of play, the player who has accrued the most points wins the game.

Players:   2, 3, 4, 5
Time:      60 min
Mechanics:  [property=2004][/property], [property=2686][/property], [property=2082][/property]

RATING: 7
MG
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Although the game is themed by D&D, it doesn't have a D&D feel at all. Lords of Waterdeep goes into what happens behind the scenes of our RPG adventures. Players are patrons. Yes, WE are the ones adventurers seek when they go off hunting for excuses to loot and/or kill. In Lords, players draw the quests and send their agents off to recruit the fighters, rogues, wizards and priests to complete them. There is no combat in this game, no adventure, and no leveling.

Players have 2-3 workers (agents) to place on spaces that allow them to select quests, recruit adventurers, make money, draw intrigue cards, or play them. You can also build buildings that allow for different combinations of actions. The object is to get points. You primarily get points by completing quests (by paying cube and money combinations on quest cards), but there are many smaller opportunities to get points through actions and intrigue cards as well. After 8 turns, the game is over.

Basically, we have a quick-playing, card-driven worker-placement game. Worker-placement games give you a limited number of actions and wide variety of choices. Their strength is in the variety of actions and paths you can take, while at the same time blocking or limiting your opponents' choices. The objectives for Waterdeep are limited - you get points by completing sets of cubes (representing the different adventurer types) and money - but the particulars change every game by the order in which the cards come up. I think this is one of the better strategically light worker-placement games I've played. The length, about an hour, is just right for the depth.

RATING: 7
I expected this game to be better. It's good, in fact a really good game. My entire family loved playing it. However, something about it just doesn't pull me in.

Maybe it's the fact that you complete all these quests and the theme is such a big part of the game, but I never actually felt like I was a Lord of Waterdeep.

Actually, the more I think about it, the hidden character cards are the worst part of the game and the one aspect that is supposed to drive the tension. I would rather see more scarcity of resources, I think.

Regardless, this is a good game and really fun with 5 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I like it a lot! Definitely a game better than the sum of its parts. Nothing groundbreaking, but the overall result is pleasing. Although the strategy is not always evident, and there are some tough choices to make, the state of the game is always quite clear to the players: there is no mental bookkeeping to do and the actions have clear impacts. In other words, nothing is obfuscated in this game, it flows smoothly.

The game system has good potential for expansions due to its card nature (and the buildings), so I think future expansions can add to the theme and rectify the abstraction of the base game.

RATING: 7.5
Collect resources by placing workers as efficiently as possible to use to fulfill quest cards for victory points. Mostly this is fun, but there are potential annoyances. You get a bonus for completing a certain goal. This is hidden from others, so you may end up competing with someone for the same quest type. Fighting over who gets the start player can be annoying. The bonus card for most buildings seems too generous since they already tend to gain extra resources. Also there is the randomness of what quests come out. If you don't get ones toward your bonus you may end up behind at the end.

RATING: 5
I was initially really excited about this game. The production is good, I like the art, the rules seem straight forward and fun. The problem is that there is nothing special about this game, the mechanics all work but they all work better in other games. I don't feel drawn to playing it there aren't enough novel decisions or unique elements to encourage the choice of this game over others.

I could see RPG-types finding their way to Euros with this game, but for those of us engrossed in the boardgame community this game has little to offer. I also really don't like the hidden scoring in this game, I don't mind that it's hidden I just think they choose boring objectives to give people.

RATING: 6
Inoffensive light weight Euro with some take that cards. Combine stuff to fufill order cards, pretty theme-less, instantly forgettable.

Just not good enough. 

To clarify this game is functional, but there really is no need to play it over its inspiration. This title is pure 'product' to fill a gap in the market from Wizards. This is what I object to - as art it is creatively bankrupt and lazy. The source material is entirely disrespected and the whole production feels lowest common denominator. if this is the future of eurogames then thank goodness that there are many designers moving away from this paradigm towards combining other genres into these mechanics because this evolutionary tree is a dead end.

RATING: 5
I have played this game once now and would be ok never playing it again. It's fun but entirely too light for me. There is no theme. Don't let anyone else tell you otherwise. You could easily replace this game with any other theme and nothing would really change. Seriously pirates, space, Cthulhu, you name it. 

My main problem with it is that there is simply not enough complex strategies. The game kind of just tells you what to do. It's still fun but the most ideal decision is usually right in front of you. I don't think I will learn anything new playing this 100 more times. If you want a worker placement game you could play with your mom then get this one otherwise I would stay away.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Uneven production - beautiful art for the card faces (which I have to assume is recycled from other D&D properties) with bog-standard card backs and a dour, grey board. Terrific thematic cardboard money, with simple cubes to represent the "heroes" of the game.

Underneath the suspect looks though, the game plays as a very smooth introductory worker-placement game. Furthermore, there's very little in the way of meaningful player interaction - only the denial of placement, and some tacked-on take-that mandatory quest. The root of the issue is that there's nothing in LoD that will challenge an experienced board gamer, so there's subsequently little investment in the game, leading to a shallow (though mercifully brief) experience. 

Nice as a gateway, or as a break on those occasions where the brain is already burnt, but nothing that I'm going to be clamouring to play. The expansion adds some new placement spaces and a bit of a push-your-luck element with the corruption, but nothing that addresses the issues I have with the base game.

RATING: 5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A light thematic take on a Euro worker placement.

First, what I like about it. It plays quickly and it doesn't bog down with analysis paralysis. It would be a good teacher to worker placements. I would recommend this to a lot of people. The intrigue cards really are a neat mechanic.

But what don't I like about it? I find the theme to be very poorly implemented. The components and mechanics all just seem disjointed. I find the hidden role cards to be absolutely terribly implemented. They are almost all just different takes of the same thing and dictate too much of who will or won't win. If two players share the same extra point quests, the third player will win almost every time. Next, the quests that are available are too random, vital and they fluctuate too often to be either tactically or strategically viable - which is where you'll earn the vast majority of your points. 

I gladly will play this game with other people, but I think the game is shallow, the point swings are manic-depressive, and the quests' relationship with the hidden roles are too important and too driven by chance.

With the expansion, this is elevated to "great" though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7

RATING: 9
Well, had friends come over and caught them up on Game of Thrones S2 Ep1-3, went to dinner and then we tried Lords of Waterdeep.
Once we got through the painful process of understanding what to do in a turn, it started moving quite nicely, and in the end we all really enjoyed it and are already planning on playing it in 2-3 weeks when we meet again for more GoT.

The box set up is nice, packaging is nice, I really like the coating on the cards, has a rough non glare finish.  The pieces themselves are wood and simple and seem to be the only weakness in the packaging, everything else appeared top notch. 
So I would give it a 4.5 out of 5, and a definitely try it out award.
Playtime seems to be around 90 minutes, but will know better next time since we were slow at the start.

Oh and most importantly, I WON!

RATING: 6
Its a pure and straightforward workerplacement - I would almost call it a gateway game just from its simplicity.

Yet the expansions provided enough interesting options and spiced up the Lords with some alternative winning conditions which keeps you second guessing what they are actually running for. Its not overly complicated and there might be a slight inbalance towards the high value Quests which provide up to 40 points at once, which can lead to some lopsided results if not countered by your fellow lords.

I still like to play this and love the custom insert which comes with the game. All games should have an insert like that.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Good, quick playing worker placement/resource management game with a working D&D background. Intrigue cards help throw more uncertainty into the mix of considerations as to what to do next. Advanced buildings come out in a different order each game and some never appear in a particular game at all. So, if you like games where you know all the right moves before the game begins, then this is not going to work for you. But if you like a level of uncertainty that forces you to react ingame to unforseeable events and use your resources accordingly, then this game does that, and very well. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
Lords of Waterdeep is... OK? It's OK. It's an OK game. Mechanically, it is OK. It's nice, it's pleasant, it's pretty relaxing as far as worker placement games go.

I'm a D&D player from small times, and I was big into the Forgotten Realms books when I was younger, but the theme of Lords of Waterdeep really does feel paper-thin. Some of it works, but the mechanic of recruiting adventurers and sending them on quests really feels just like buying resources and spending them on victory points. Maybe some character meeples would help, but that particular part of the game just does not click with me.

The board itself, the intrigue cards, and the the buildings feel a lot more cohesive to me, and perhaps the theme would feel better-integrated if the worker placement were more focused on changes to the city itself rather than the quests which feel imported from a different world.

The final nail in the coffin (that's a bit dramatic, I won't refuse to play Lords of Waterdeep but I will not suggest it) is that the worker placement almost never feels weighty. There are usually a few places that are equally attractive, and there is so little tension behind the choices. I like a bit of stress in my worker placement playsâLords of Waterdeep doesn't manage to work it up very well.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
Pretty basic but good worker placement game and the perfect example of how much good components matter. If played with the components in the box it boils down to "I spend two black cubes and a white one to get two orange ones, some money and some points." When playing with the DnDeeples this changes to "I'm sending out my two thieves and a priest. On their quest they earn me some money and glory and convince two warriors to join my cause."

RATING: 8
I enjoyed this game, however I was put off by the seemingly unbalancedness of the quests. Some of the quests and intrigue cards are nearly game breaking when used in combination, and there is far more luck involved than I would like for a euro. On the other hand, it takes the D&D theme and turns it into a surprisingly fun cube pusher. I would probably play this more often if not fr the existence of Yedo, which does almost the exact same things but considerably better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
I'm not ready to rate it yet (I don't want the "newness" to cloud my judgements :) ) but I have enjoyed all 3 of my games thus far, immensely.  And any game featuring James LeBrie must be perfect, huh?

The game is simple to learn, my 9 year old boy won in his only game (3 player vs. me and the wife)!

Yet, the options are many, strategies (end game Lord?  questing? building/balanced?) varied and the outcome isn't decided until the very end.

It plays fast, both turn to turn and in total time.

It has a D&D feel in general, but is clearly a Euro.  That has NOT affected our enjoyment at all!

I have played with gamers and the family with just as good results; a real winner here!

And it is certainly easily expanded, what with new quests, hero classes, Lords, buildings, Intrigue cards, etc.  Maybe a "Dungeon" space where you can "gamble" heroes from your tavern away for some big rewards...treasure, VPs, gold, Monsters that act as wilds for questing, etc.

Could be a 9 when all is said and done...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Lords of Waterdeep isn't just a euro, it's a bone-dry, Caylus/A Castle for All Seasons/Fresco-type game. Strange, since the theme should lend a bit more flavor. Sadly, the D&D is all in the names on the cards; everywhere else, it feels like a derivative retheme of better and more involving games. It does only last an hour, which is an unusually quick playtime for this type, and it reflects the care the WotC gang put into it. But there are better games out there of this type.

RATING: 8
This game has a completely pasted on D&D theme and has no business being as good as it is.  Whether by brilliant design or lucky accident this is an extraordinary worker placement game.  Works great as a first worker placement for those new to the hobby but definitely offers enough for seasoned gamers to enjoy over and over.  Seems to play exactly long enough to accomplish everything you needed to do but never enough time to do everything you wanted to do.

The plastic insert for storage of the pieces is as good as you will find anywhere but the box is stupid and hard to store because if you turn the box vertically all those pieces come tumbling out of the beautiful insert, and the lid doesn't close properly.

RATING: 8.5
This is one of the best representation of the worker placement genre. I like the growing number of buildings. The progression of chaining quest rewards to complete the next one feels rewarding and satisfying. The endgame is also tense because you can never be sure who will win since the lords are hidden. Someone might surprise everyone especially if they are the building lord. I quite like this game and glad I bought this over Stone Age. Recommend it to everyone as a great gateway game.

RATING: 8
2015-04-18 - 8 - It's very good and I only played with two players so far. It's lighter worker placement than Tzolkin or Le Havre, but I really enjoyed it, because there is still a lot interesting choices. And the theme is quite existent here, which is another good thing. I expect that my rating may go higher after playing with more players.

2015-10-19 - 8->7.5 - The base game is pretty good but a little bit repetitive. I guess expansion might change it. Oh, and those obligatory missions are just lame.

2016-06-12 - 7.5->8 - I played with the expansion, which is really good, and I don't think I want to play without it. This game is a very solid light worker placement.

RATING: 8.5
I'm honestly fairly new to Euro games, so I haven't played a ton of them yet.  This one is a great simple worker placement game.  (The first one I ever played, in fact!) I did immediately replace the cubes with DnDeeples, though.  I highly recommend doing so, as it tends to make people actually call them, "Clerics, Warriors, Mages, and Rogues." RATING: 4
I have played this a few times now, both with and without the skullport expansion. Each time feels more painful than the last. I hate, hate, hate the intrigue cards, which feel akin to the Chance cards in Monopoly. Other than that, fulfilling quest cards offer very little satisfaction to me. And since that's the crux of the game, when this gets brought out at game night it fills me with dread.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Theme is thinly pasted on but that doesn't matter. This is a straightforward worker placement game with a nice balance of simplicity, mild strategy, and luck. Plays in under an hour, and I find it works well with any number of players.

In my opinion it is a much better designed game than Agricola. The depth and options available remain about the same, but Lords of Waterdeep is less fiddly, easier to set up and play, has a clearer score system, and is much more fun overall.

How Agricola is rated so far above this game is beyond me.

RATING: 9
Light worker placement game.  There are lots of choices, hidden VP objectives and opportunities to impact other players (or work around them).  Rating could go up with more plays.

Played this some more and the rating is increased to 9.  I'm starting to see how to put together an economic engine in this game, with plot quests and building combos that can really multiply your resources.  Other players have to decide whether to counter or maximize their actions, leading to a lot of tough decisions in the worker placement.

RATING: 10
Solid euro, this is pretty much everything you want in a game. Lots of re playability, this (along with Dungeon Pets) are the perfect games to recommend to someone getting into the hobby. And yet complex enough that veteran gamers will enjoy it just as much as a casual gamer would.

And if you have this, you definitely want the expansion Scoundrels of Skullport. Once you play with it, you won't want to play without it. 

This is definitely not what one would expect from a game using the Dungeons and Dragons license, but its definitely a keeper.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A fun and pretty good little worker placement game though resource collection is rather themeless as the colored cubes one collects tend to be referred to by their color (two purples, one orange, etc.) with little to no regard for what they represent (wizards, warriors, etc).  The random distribution of rolls before the start of the game means that you may get stuck with a roll that you can't work with given the quests that are available or become available.  In one game I played, it wasn't possible for me to wait around until quests were available that matched my roll,  I ended up completing many similar quests which were all the opposite of my characters qualities thus no bonus points were earned at the end of the game.  However, in other sessions, the quests went my way and I was able to gain many bonus points.  But I do enjoy the game and will willingly play it again.  The game plays quickly too provided you don't have a player who overanalyzes every move because he believes the world will end if he doesn't win the game (but that's not the fault of the game).  I think I prefer it with three than with four.  In summary, I'll willingly play this, perhaps even suggest it, but probably won't buy it simply because I have other games to play with themes I prefer (non fantasy).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A gorgeous worker-placement game with a very, very thin Dungeons and Dragons theme.  It's a top-notch production but at the end of the day it's a lot like Stone Age.  Unlike Stone Age, for some reason, players seem to get a bit more invested in achieving a win - maybe because of the thin theme of completing quests. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is just an initial rating, after one play late at night. LoW is a good Eurogame with a D&D theme that is practically irrelevant (unfortunately). It has a solid worker placement mechanic, though, and that's what drives the gameplay. It's easy enough that I suspect my eleven year-old could pick it up after a short explanation and a couple of practice turns, but that also limits its depth. There are a lot of choices in the game, but unfortunately there are too many of them that feel approximately equal in value. This reduces the tension significantly. The graphic design of the game is excellent. It's beautiful without being busy or distracting. All in all, LoW is a good medium/light worker placement game.

RATING: 7.5
Played this several times and enjoyed it when played, though of late when i'm in the mood there is now the steam port of the game and I tend to play that more.

It's a D&D themed worker placement game with quest cards for victory point scoring and some take-that cards as well.

You're drafting a party of adventurers (in the form of colored cubes) to complete quest goals and then gain points.

Honestly it would not be hard to peel the theme away and swap something else on top of it, but it is still a fun game.

RATING: 6

I suggest drafting, aka doubling up the potential choices, of Lords of Waterdeep and Quests at the beginning of the game to spice it up even more.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I've been looking for a light and short action drafting/worker placement game for a very long time. This is it. While it's considerably random and far from deep, it also is highly accessible and fun.

Lords of the Waterdeep is a great game to lure tabletop RPG gamers into non-adventure board games. But, on the other hand, non-geeks can find the D&D theme completely uninteresting, not to mention it can be a wee bit to fiddly, mechanically speaking, due to all the different cards.

The game's biggest drawback is, by far and large, the luck factor. It has two main sources of luck, and both are card draws: the intrigue deck (action cards) and quest deck (objective cards). While intrigue draws aren't that crucial, quest draws will frequently give games away. A horrible curse in longer/deeper games, but perfectly acceptable in a game of its weight.

Long story short: a bit of a luckfest, but fun and fast to play. Great way to introduce tabletop RPGers into the hobby.

Rating: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Optimal number of players:
:thumbsup:4
:thumbsdown:2

[size=12][b]Why I like Lords of Waterdeep:[/b][/size]
+ I like the mechanics
+ There is high player involvement
+ There seems to be decent replayability
+ The game is easy to teach
+ The duration of the game is fine
+ There game requires meaningful decisions to win

[size=12][b]Why I dislike Lords of Waterdeep:[/b][/size]
- I dislike the theme and the drab looking board.
- I would rather play other worker placement games

RATING: 10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
LoW is a thoroughly unoriginal game, I think I've seen every single mechanism somewhere before. However this doesn't matter much, as every aspect of the game is superbly polished from the easy-to-understand rules to the good looking and supremely functional bits. Another added bonus is that the game is very quick, even with five players it doesn't take more than a little bit over an hour. 

I'm not a fan of worker placement games and LoW is so straight-forward it's almost a filler, but even still I like the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Lords of Waterdeep has seen more plays in our household than any other. It can usually be had for around $30 and has a fantastic theme that will bring in rpgers without ruining its utility as a gateway Euro. Fantastic production values and lots of diversity with multiple lord cards, buildings, quests and intrigue cards. It's constantly in print and the expansion is one of the best there is. Z-man makes Stone Age and that's too bad because it's a solid game that's overpriced and out of print. Champions of Midgard is very cool, but the dice element can be a bit unforgiving randomly. Not that LoW is without its randomness, but I think it stands it's own. Plays fantastic at 2-3 if you have just the base game and equally well with 4-6 once you add the expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.9
Rating is for the Ios implementation.

I've played it 4 times now. the tutorial is good. Interface is excellent.

when I mix the AI strengths the highest AI was never the hardest opponent. When the AI strength is the same the medium AI allready offers me a challenge.

the hidden roles, but certainly the quests and the buildings that come up make sure that every game will be different. 

Scoring is close and that probably is my main problem with the game. More so that there is kingmaking in giving mandatory quests near the end. Perhaps less interaction would be better. ( There is allready plenty of it in the worker placement itself) Infact I would have preferred a single bonus system there. (The AI plays controlled and doesn't differentiate between player and other AI ; he will set back who's in front and aid who's behind)
I find this system of catching up unneccesary and a spoiled gift in otherwise an excellent game.

I am fine with the buildings giving bonusses to their owners when used.  But on the cards well it either sets an opponent back or aids one other. This will mean I won't win many games as my local group considers me the person to beat. with a single bonus system , the best  worker placement would do the trick. 

However I think the gameplay is fun and think this is a solid middleweight workerplacement game that with a great theme.
 
I suspect my rating for the boardgame itself and given my group it would be a solid 7. A bit AP prone on one player given the many options and the little moves you can do.

RATING: 9.2
This is a great worker placement game with enough complexity and variety to keep it interesting on repeated plays, and just enough chance to console you when you lose.  I like that there's a fair bit of player interaction in Lords of Waterdeep, and not too much of it is backstabbing.  This keeps each player focused on the game even when it's not his/her turn.  Rules are clearly spelled out in the well-written rulebook, and everything is easy to understand.  New players can jump into the game pretty easily without information overload before play begins.

RATING: 4
I think this game could have been conceived as a joke. Take the poster-child for boring-theme Euros - Caylus, and water its gameplay down, taking out the interesting interaction and adding in uninteresting take-that style interaction. Then, when you have the most banal lifeless cube pusher imaginable, you (very) thinly wrap a theme on it that appeals to the Euro haters, and they eat it up because they're all so starved to play a Euro game deep down. Excellent plan, really, if only because its showing all the Ameritrashers that Euros are actually fun to play, and hopefully some of them will take the training wheels off and move past this game.

The take that -effects are repetitive, and despite the top notch production the theme doesn't really come through. I felt more like merely pushing cubes than recruiting adventurers to do my bidding. Seriously, what is it with the hype???

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I played this with six players and found it pretty worthless. There just aren't enough good choices to make it feel like anything but a waste of time. It had a problem that IME is almost unique in WP games, though is also in base Viticulture: too many workers, too few *useful* action spaces. I think a good WP game should have the opposite problem: so many good things you want to do and far too few workers to do them all. There are SO many WP games where you never get to do everything you want. Halfway through the first round of LoW I figured out there were no good options remaining and wanted to pass. 

I've played it twice, with both expansions and five and six players, and found it at best completely boring. Furthermore, with Santa's Workshop doing the "pile cubes on a card to win" mechanism as part of an excellent WP game, all of the mechanisms are done better in other games. So whatever it is you like about LoW, there's a better game out there with the same mechanism. Twice was one time too many, and having given it a second chance, I won't be playing it again.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In Lords of Waterdeep, a strategy board game for 2-5 players, you take on the role of one of the masked Lords of Waterdeep, secret rulers of the city. Through your agents, you recruit adventurers to go on quests on your behalf, earning rewards and increasing your influence over the city. Expand the city by purchasing new buildings that open up new actions on the board, and hinder â or help â the other lords by playing Intrigue cards to enact your carefully laid plans.

During the course of play, you may gain points or resources through completing quests, constructing buildings, playing intrigue cards or having other players utilize the buildings you have constructed. At the end of 8 rounds of play, the player who has accrued the most points wins the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
This is an extremely well produced euro with a great deal of player interaction. A surprise coming from WOTC but hats of to a very enjoyable game from the Lord's perspective. Buildings that can be purchased dramatically alter the city in which you recruit adventurers and engage in intrigue. It seems abstract until you realize that you are a Lord above such "menial tasks" as the quests you use the adventurers to complete. Includes Scoundrels of Skullport expansion.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the very best gateway worker placement games, which can also be very enjoyable for seasoned board game players.

Don't let the theme fool you though, as this game is actually made for everyone (meaning: not only fantasy or Dungeons & Dragons fans), because the theme is actually pretty thin and disconnected from the actual mechanisms and rules.

The replay value is surprisingly high, thanks to the  different mission and action cards, the secret identities for each player (for bonus points) and many different buildings.

The components are great with love for detail, the artwork quality is great (with very few exceptions) and the rules are well-written and easy to understand.

I [b][i]highly[/i][/b] recommend the expansion [b][thing=134342][/thing][/b], which is essential for people playing this game regularly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.4
The basic mechanism is just another simplified Caylus-like resource conversion worker placement Euro; nothing special.

Then some American style fun is added:
- theme, graphic design, flavor texts
- "characters" = secret aims
- Intrigue = some "take that" effect and screw your opponent randomness and/or leader bashing

They still don't make the game great fun, but it's fun enough. It's actually strange to see it's so much a resource conversion euro that it even uses cubes for characters like Wizards, Thiefs, Warriors and Priests.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Several games, 5p.  Better than I expected, given the theme.  After hearing the rules, I realized that the theme was an after thought.  This is very much like Caylus, but without the Provost/Baliff, and buildings work immediately (i.e. no specific order that actions are taken in).  There was some player interaction, but it was mostly random.  For example, there is a series of cards that removes one cube of a specific color from all opponents stockpiles, and, for every opponent that doesn't have any, the player of the card gets some other bonus.  This will hit some players more than others, and the player of the card has little control over it (they have some, in that they can choose when to play the card to maximize the effect they wish).  I did not like THOSE cards.  There were others that targeted a specific opponent, some of which were good, others bad.  This was less random, at least, and much less onerous.  But, overall, this was a pretty good game, and should play fairly quickly I should think (with the right players).  But the theme is TOTALLY unnecessary.  I never felt, not once, that I was assembling a group of adventurers using various buildings to complete quests.  I was simply collecting cubes to fulfill victory point conditions.

RATING: 7.5
Nice pure worker placement game with some randomness, some "take that" and an inconsequential & tacked-on D&D theme. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
In general it's a good game. Some might say that it's much more easier than Caylus or stone age. Personally I think it runs well and I find caylus simply broken.

My first complain is that I would have liked to build more buildings like in Caylus. I liked the idea of making buildings that other players can use. It's just that in LOW, you can build at most (in theory) 8 buildings through the game since the builder roles is can only be limited to once per round. It does not make it a bad game, it's just not what I expected.

The second thing I did not like is the non standard flow of resources. For example, all buildings requires gold to build. But quest can require anything to fulfill them , it can take characters, but it can also take gold. And so are the rewards diversified, it can be anything from gold to Victory points to even additional characters.

I think they should have standardized the resources flow. It OK that quest require different types of characters, but it should always require characters. Maybe quest rewards should have always been victory point, gold or a combination of both.

Now the resource flow is very chaotic and resources gets converted in many directions by quest, intrigues and worker placement. It does not break the game, it just makes it very chaotic to manage.

Some people complained about the randomness in the game (random quest, buildings, intrigue, etc). Personally, I don't mind much because it offers a lot of replay value. It's true that I did not get a chance to get many quest card that matched my lord's power so I could blame the luck for that. I managed to match 2 cards while another player managed to match 7.

I would have loved that each house had a special power, or that each player draw an intrigue card at the beginning of the round. I did not have a chance to draw many intrigue cards, more choice would have given me a reason to use them.


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It's fine for what it is, but too dull for me.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
As worker placement games go, Lords of Waterdeep is more enjoyable for me than Caylus and usually provides more options for me.  It's simpler in that you just manage resources and use intrigue cards to fulfill Quests.  The biggest difference for me on why I prefer Waterdeep much more is that I do NOT have to calculate all the SEQUENCES, TURN ORDER and TIMING permutations that Caylus requires.  I can just manage my own resources, cards and aim for Quests.  This streamlines things and makes for a fun, quicker and enjoyable game with a great fantasy (D&D) theme.  Caylus is more analytically skillful, and so is Russian Railroads.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Gift from 2012 Secret Santa.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I enjoyed this one despite being pretty much a basic worker placement game.  The variance and mystery of the intrigue cards and the starting characters helps give replay value to the game as well as the variance in what buildings may get built each game.  Highly recommend constructing useful buildings as they will generate healthy rent rewards, particularly if built early in the game.  The aspect where you go to the harbor and play and intrigue card and then later get to place those workers again to take another (obviously lesser) action is another excellent mechanic that adds to the flavor of the game.  This definitely is a eurogame with a bit of Ameritrash flavor/theme.  

After my second play, I don't feel much of a need to play again.  I will do so if asked, but won't seek it out.  This is a very basic worker placement game and I would prefer Agricola or other more interesting worker placement games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I dislike worker placement games, quite a bit actually. I tend to shy away from anything when the WP is mentioned in the games descreption, but LoW had me intrigured. it was described as a nasty, thematic, worker placement game. I like nasty and thematic so I was looking forward to giving it a try at least. I must say that the game lives up to its reputation. It can be quite nasty, and it is pretty thematic for a worker placement game taking place in a high fantasy town placed within the D&D world. The components are pretty nice, and the graphic design is done quite well. The lay out of the board makes for a pretty intuitive gaming experience. The gameplace is one of the biggest selling points, and is easily understood in 10-15 minutes of rules explanation. I had an enjoyable time when playing the game, although I did find that many of the objectives from what I think were the expansions to be quite overpowered compared to the base game objectives. And you win the game through completing these objectives. But of course this is a worker placement game so I could take it, or leave it. If unlike me you are a worker placement game fan you definitely should give this one a shot. Its straightforward and plays quickly and adds some teeth to a genre that tends to be passive aggresive at best.

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Hands down the best gateway game in the most-prestigeous worker placement category, with the caveat that the game really shines with the two expansions. Similar to Splendor, I think this game has really brought a lot of people and families back into the boardgaming industry, at a time the industry and community was hurting. It's difficult to make a euro game not feel intimidating to new gamers and families, with mechanics that are simple enough for kids to understand and enjoy, while still holding the interest of more experienced gamers... yet LoW accomplishes it all. And has not been surpassed since it released in 2012! 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Playdek is going to release an app! A must have. Bought on 23 Nov, 2013. It proves that a Euroish worker tile placement game can be right on spot with a pointed theme, which can be great fun!

Each player is an adventurer with his/ her own agenda. Some will score more with certain types of adventure (e.g. commerce, piety, warfare, arcana, skullduggery, etc.), some will score for each building under control. Thus, Lords of Waterdeep is a Euroish minimax game - maximizing the resources cube you can get and the adventures require and minimizing the resources available to your opponents. Actually I quite like this game although normally this is not the kind of game I like. It is because the theme, Forgotten Realms of the Dragonlance saga, is well applied to the system, the cards, the adventures and the objective of the game. Although the objective is to win the game by gaining the most victory points, there is a lot of paths out there to achieve that. Taken together, the cards of intrigues, agents, adventures, resources, weave out a web of a believable Dragonlance universe, living up to what the novel flexes out. The card art is some of the better fantasy paintings I have seen in recent years, while retaining much of the D&D flavor.

If this game is your training wheels, I encourage you to look into other worker placement games. It's a truly lovely genre!

Innovation and theme are important, but they arenât everything.

RATING: 9
Great worker placement game.
I like that you always have a clear goal to work towards to, and because you'll complete 5+ missions every game, you can't really make a bad action that you'll regret the whole game (looking at you Giants).
Our group likes the theme because we play D&D, but it's a bit pasted on.
Only issue is that the Mandatory Quests are too strong and can significantly influence the outcome, and if you get bad starting quests, you'll have to play exceptionally well to win.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The biggest pro is that this game looks amazing.  The map and the lord cards are very thematic, interesting, and it feels very lore-ish like LOTR.  I don't think you'll beat the look and feel of the game for this price point.

Essentially it is a worker-placement game about gaining control of a city.  You are a lord who is trying to complete quests by using adventures of different types to complete them.

Overall I do really enjoy this game.  I used to think that the intrigue cards were a glaring design flaw (because they are so weak), but that was before I knew about the rule that you get to reassign your worker afterwards!  Completely changes that.  That makes intrigue WORK, but they still feel kind of pidly, like you're just trying to meddle, but don't do that much damage.  Although they can really hurt your opponents if played at the opportune time.  So they're ok.

The other thing I don't like is the idea that your lord is a secret; no one will know till the end of the game!  Well the fact is that they all (except one) operate the same: they give bonus points to some category of quest.  So you quickly figure out which quests your opponents are gunning for and there really is no mystery to it.  They should either have had more interesting lords.  Or just removed the idea of having it be a mystery for other players to figure out.

Also, I feel like the depth of this game is much less than what others claim.  Still a GOOD GAME for sure, but it really shouldn't be ranked #28 on bgg.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Pasted on theme or not, its a instant classic.

RATING: 7
Despite 25 plays, I flip flop on the rating of this game more than any other. On one hand, I feel like this instead of Settlers should be THE gateway game, and this game is one of the nongamer's favorite amongst my collection. Plus, besides the cubes, the components are very high, and while you are basically playing a cube management game, the "quests" and what not add a nice touch. On the other hand, this game gives a vibe of lacking depth (although I heard that the expansion fixes this). I feel like this game is most balanced with 3-4 players, but have the most fun with 2 because you can chain quests one after another.

EDIT: By lacking depth I mean at the time of writing I have an 85% win rate at this game, yet never really feel like I plan my turns super strategically, instead just following some basic principles and taking whatever spot I am needing of resources of at the time of my turn.

RATING: 7
Despite the horrible box cover art, and the deeply nerdy DnD theme, this is a very accessible worker-placement game.  A crowd-pleaser.  I would go as far as to even say it could be a gateway game.  

Setup is a little fiddly, but not too bad once you get it organized.  Great components, lots of fun.

Expansions add even more depth and decisions, without over-complicating the rules.

Eventually replaced for me by Yedo, a game with similar ideas, but more depth without adding too much more playtime.  Also prefer Yedo's ninja/samurai theme to DND.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
Type: 2-5 player worker placement

Best with: 4-5 players
Weight: Medium
Duration: 1-3 hours, gets long with 5
Notes:
Straight-up worker placement based on quest cards
Very little interaction or screw-your-neighbor beyond a few mandatory quests and blocking worker placement

Worker placement game with an old school D&D theme on top of it. Good for 2-5 players and it scales well across them all. The 2 player game is a bit more strategic and the 5 player one a bit more tactical as you have far fewer agents to place and collect resources.

Components are excellent. Many praise the box insert, but I find it to leave my cards and tokes a disaster if stored or transported upright at all. The game should have come with more flavorful classes instead of wooden cubes; a very large missed opportunity. Picking up themed wooden pieces that better illustrate the classes of the cubes is a must-buy if you intend to keep this game. The cards are a nice quality with that professional linen feel to their faces. Honestly, the components are fine and the board itself lays nicely flat. Setup is relatively easy (after retrieving the mess that the interior of the insert becomes) as is teardown after.

One upside is how approachable this game is; there may be no better gateway game to boardgames and pseudo-euro style games. The rules are simple, the rewards obvious, the interaction amongst players somewhat muted and brisk, and the scores are in flux until the last player's victory points are tallied at the end. And yet there can be some strategy involved once you get the hang of it, from blocking your opponents to attempting to string together a quest whose rewards feed the next quest requirements.

One downside is the fact this is a silky smooth, straight-forward worker placement game (aka cube-pusher) and can be extremely boring if you don't bring the theme of the game to life. Make some D&D jokes; absorb the old school flavor of the quests; make mini-stories about your tavern and your agents and the warriors and clerics they're gathering and sending off to the doom or glory. Without the added fun of the theme being taken for a ride by the players, this game can be a serious drag late in a gaming session or just ho-hum early on.

A second downside in a two-player game is how direct and confrontational the Mandatory Quests can be. When you're in a 3+ player game, there is some fun to be had with blocking someone. But in a 2 player game, you have no choice but to give the other player a roadblock they have to deal with, while it gives you no benefit in return. Some people aren't going to like that, but I suppose you could just take those Intrigue cards out, as they're not all that common to draw anyway. While on the topic, the Lieutenant and Ambassador can be taken out for 2 players as well. Scored early on, they can easily unbalance the game.

This game is excellent, but does suffer slightly from being pretty light on theme, light on depth, and can be a drag when the players aren't into the theme and just go through the motions of the mechanics. But otherwise, great game.

Similar games in my collection: Dungeon Petz (worker placement), Province (worker placement), Viticulture (worker placement), Carcassonne (worker placement)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
This is a light worker placement game that is very family friendly.  The game has elements of other worker placement games like resource collection, resource management, etc.  But it seems to do it in a very interesting way.  You have a secret goal that gives you points at the end of the game, and you complete quests to score points.  Waterdeep Harbor is great as it provides some opportunities for "take that" like mandatory quests, but are not game breaking for other players.  It also gives you additional moves.  

I like the game a lot and so does my family.

RATING: 4
Played twice.

Ugh.  Take the theme from D&D, use it for flavor text, and then add some bland worker placement with a bit of placement growth, and you get this game.  Play is rather automatic, uninspired, and frankly, boring.  I can see the appeal of this as a gateway game, as the mechanics are so painfully obvious and easy to grasp, but beyond that, I can't figure out why it is apparently so popular.  So many worker placement games hide their mechanics better (including some lovely gateway-style titles), and provide more options for both victory points and turn-to-turn choice.

Not interested in playing again.  Definitely never re-acquiring this.

RATING: 6
While the D&D theme is done well, this is in every other way a run-of-the-mill worker placement game. I can't point to any particular mechanic and say "that's unique". The game borrows heavily from a range of games, and it does manage to work quite well, but somehow I find the whole package uninspiring. It's certainly not a bad game, in fact it's a reasonably good game, but I don't find it to be particularly memorable, and that seems to impact on how often I want to play it.
