=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In the interest of disclosure, I must say I've been an avid Dungeon and Dragons fan for almost 15 years. That being said, I like this game. It a well made worker placement with just enough additional mechanics to add longevity and variety. The set up is quick and the mechanics are stream lined enough that you can bring pretty much anyone with basic board game understanding into a game in about 15 minutes. The games goes pretty fast after round or two, as people get the hang of it, and is pretty fast paced with experienced players. While it's certainly not the most strategy heavy game I've ever played, the game offers engaging choices and plenty of occasions to pull the breaks on your opponents.  

All in all, a solid pick.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Early opinions based on one play. 

Very good game. Plenty of good decision making, but not a brain burner by any stretch. Casual gamers could play this with minimal rules explanation; it just feels well-designed and intuitive. Illustrations on the gameboard and building tiles let you see at a glance what those spaces do. Some nice player interaction via Intrigue cards (for example, some make your opponents discard their resources). 

Really fun game. Our four player game, in which no one had played before, still took only an hour and a
half. I'm looking forward to taking this for another spin.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
No question, this is a beautiful game, and they managed to make the components functional, too. The coinage, for example, faithfully reflects the background world, and there is a good thematic tie of most quests to what you have to do to succeed in-game. In spite of this, and in spite of the very enjoyable first game, Iâm not sure about the longevity here.

Apart from the background, there is not so much happening here that would differentiate Lords of Waterdeep from a wealth of other worker placement games. What is new is well implemented, however, and makes me hope that this could keep its allure for longer: the buildings introduce interesting ways to shift the value of the adventurers around, and I love how the Harbor both limits the impact of Action Cards by making them harder to play and introduces interesting timing decisions.

After a single game, Iâm definitely not sure whither the pendulum might swing with this one, so for now it gets a lukewarm rating of 7.

Update: A couple of more games have shown this to keep its promise, so the rating is raised to an 8.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Ok, definitely not a bad game.  However if you're into the Euro mechanics in the game, the "take that" cards may not feel like they belong, like they did with me.  If you've played Stone Age, think of that, but where people play cards that make you lose a gold if you have one.  For me it just felt like people shouldn't mess with "MY" stuff.  But that's what you get when you take Euro mechanics and add a bit of Ameritrash flavor I suppose.  I like the Le Havre-like building ownership stuff going on.

It's a really simple game to learn, and I can really appreciate the melding of a theme such as Dungeons and Dragons with a modern worker placement Euro.  I'm glad it exists and glad people like it.  Just not sure I care for the "take that" stuff when I'm "pushing cubes" :)  Not for me, but I'm happy it's liked by others.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great worker placement gateway game. Intrigue cards have limited use with 2 players however
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Meh - original comment with my 5 rating after 1 play.

NEVER AGAIN - new comment after changing rating to 3 after second play.

For background, I do not like "working placement" (action drafting) games in general.  The constraints on resource/action selection just seems to serve the purpose of disrupting any real long term planning.  Lords of Waterdeep has that in spades.

I also do not like "take that" games that last very long at all.  A really short and simple "take that" is fine, but the longer it goes on, the more uninteresting it is to me.  

So, my second play of Lords of Waterdeep lasted for 5 hours.  I am fine with long games, but I would rather have played Roads and Boats, which can often be done in less time. 

This game mixes design elements I do not enjoy to create an experience that I do not enjoy and that can, in some cases, be stretched over far to long a time.  NEVER AGAIN.

1 play, 4 players 
1 play, 5 players (with exps)

RATING: 10
Essentially a worker placement and resource management game. This ticks all my boxes as a Project Manager. The fact that is has a D&D Forgotten Realms theme is just a bonus. One of the most unique and satisfying game mechanics I have ever seen in a board game. And the expansion, the Scoundrels of Skullport, is one of the few game expansions out there that actually adds more to the core game and, dare I say it, is probably a must-have. It has seen several successive plays at my gaming group and it always gets a favourable nod when recommended.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
It's everything I hate about worker placement games into one tight package.

Obvious choices, hidden goals that force you to do the same thing the entire game, "inconvenient blocking", and no player interaction.

The gist of the game is this: You get a "Lord" card that dictates your entire game.  It might be something like a bonus for a certain type of quest or a bonus for each building you have.  I enjoy games that force me not to make interesting decisions or doesn't allow me to discover the game's system on my own.

Afterwards, you're given workers to that you place one time at a time to collect different colored cubes.  Why are you collecting these cubes?  Because your quests need specific colored cubes.  What happens when you are done with a quest?  You get another one, so you can get another set of colored cubes.  Do this against for 8 rounds and two hours

That's literally the entire game.  Sure, there are Intrigue cards that players can play to hinder another player or help themselves, otherwise it's a game about collecting sets of cubes for the sake of collecting sets of cubes.  There is no engine building, no strategy to conjure, or anything interesting going on.

If you want a worker placement game with a bit more meat but still easy to teach, get Viticulture Essential Edition instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I have played this quite a few times in person and a bunch more now on the App.  I like it fine, just not as much as others for some reason.

RATING: 9
The resource game with a fantasy theme.  Fairly easy to learn, this is a fast paced game that is lots of fun.  My wife beats me every time, but I still like it!  The artwork is great, and I find the theme surprisingly easy to get into, despite the fact that "agents" are represented by differently colored cubes.  The box design is really amazing--undoubtedly the best designed box/storage-tray of any game we own!

RATING: 9
This is a superb game. It's rare that my whole group enjoys a new game with equal enthusiasm, and that coupled with how well this Euro expresses its theme and how tight the final scores were tells me that this has a long future with us.

I love that as lords steeped in intrigue, going to the docks and playing Intrigue cards is almost always a good choice; it feels right and it fits. I love that in a D&D game, the main way the lords get things done is by assembling groups of adventurers to do them -- and that quests almost always come from a tavern.

Excluding the box, with its awful (though pretty) half-lid and uselessly fiddly insert (which surprised me after the amazing one in Conquest of Nerath), the components are fantastic. LoW looks great, plays great, and is a blast from start to finish.

It's the complete package and a total home run.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Exceptional game. Probably more similar to Caylus than any other game I've played. Though, this one is not as dry as Caylus. The quests/secret roles are what really make this game shine. Lords of Waterdeep is really a gateway game, IMO. It's incredibly streamlined and simple to play. Of course, understanding the importance of plot quests and being cognizant of critical timing with intrigue cards are pivotal to success, and these might be difficult for a new gamer to wrap their head around. I was skeptical of this game for the first year it was out, particularly the D&D theme (which is rather pasted on, incidentally). But after playing it, I love it. 

Update 3/2014: Such a great game! I have more invested (in terns of money) in it than any other game in my collection. Part of the reason for such a high rating is the fact that everyone I have played with enjoys this game. It's super smooth, intuitive, fun, accommodates up to 6 players with the expansion (and plays well at every number) and can be played in less than 90 minutes. I can't really say anything bad about this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A great worker placement game. I actually love cube pusher games. And while some think that it makes for a dry game. I think Waterdeep has a good theme to it for a Euro. I mean, who doesn't want to recruit adventurers to go on quests with!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.97
Initial reading of the rules made me think there wasn't much there. Five games in and in a way there isn't and yet it exceeds. It absolutely works as a gateway. If you want the blue pill to go deeper, look elsewhere. This is a fundamental worker placement game that adds Intrigue cards for some basic flavoring. I think the best words to describe how I feel about it is that it simply overachieves.

For all of the hate this game gets, I keep going out and playing other worker placement games and end up preferring this one in the end. Yes, there are ultimately better WP games, but those games are already higher ranked games so they should be better. As a gateway? This works.

I have no real central strategy for this game. I try to "play between the lines" as much as possible, but for whatever reason, I have won this game at a 60% rate. One of my losses was by a point.

3+ players works best. I found the 2-player game lacked proper tension that I seek although many claim to have no issues with two player games.

This still feels like 85% of a game. Houses are token placeholders for colors and thus add nothing. The diversity with the lords is essentially non-existent. You have lords who give bonuses for two different types of quest, or "The House Lord." That's it.

Update: Gets more play compared to other games than I would like but has worked extremely well with other players. This is thee gateway WP game at this point. 

Rating potential: between 7-8. If the eventual expansion was added in from the start, 9-10. Currently hanging around #10 for me. I think the rating for the base game might go lower, but it will end up being such a staple in my collection it will easily beat out higher rated games in terms of plays. This one is difficult to really nail down in terms of a score. Like I said, it simply overachieves.

Update: Lowered score mostly due to finding the little things that bug. Still a very solid game and may still be  around my Top 20 for a long time. The fact that it hits with so many players makes it hard to really lower it too much. 

Update II: I might lower it a touch more(7.88), but I feel like I'm nitpicking it at this point since I have played it so much for me at least. There are a couple other gateway type WP games I am interested in, and if I ever get to play those, I might be able to better hammer out a score for LoW. Since those games have a lower rating/rank, I'm not sure LoW will go down much.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Sold 10/10/16 via Geekbay for $56 (incl. Scoundrels of Skullport, DnDeeples, and foamcore insert)


Bought at Kingslayer Comics.

Very solid game.  Too light for current tastes.  Great for an introductory worker placement though.  Theme is a bit lacking, as you're really just pushing cubes.

I'm hoping that the expansion + DnDeeples will help this.

---
Update 1/18/16.  Played with expansion at Board of Games Tustin.  3 Players.  Corruption mechanic really added a new layer of depth to the game.  DnDeeples also really added a nice splash of theme, but not so much as I was really hoping (people still called them orange, black, etc.). I didn't shuffle the buildings correctly, so we started with all of the corruption removing buildings, meaning nobody had any corruption by game-end.  

Hoping next play will be more tight on the corruption.

See Scoundrels of Skullport for new rating WITH expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Lords of Waterdeep is a worker placement game that takes players behind the scenes of the action of Dungeons and Dragons, to the scheming and plotting that takes place before the adventurers go on their quests.

In it players are secret rulers in the city of Waterdeep.  They gather together the fighters, rogues, wizards, and clerics required to accomplish the type of quests that would be played out in a session of Dungeons and Dragons.  Quests are worth points and, of course, whomever gets the most points wins.  Other actions that can be taken are to build new buildings in the city, which will benefit you when other players use them, or play intrigue cards.

Lords of Waterdeep is a fun, entry-level, worker placement game.  In my opinion it dethrones Stone Age as being the introductory worker placement game with some meat on its bones.  If you like the fantasy theme, then this is certainly one you should try.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Basically the baseline for a nice, not too heavy, well-balanced worker placement game. It has a nice variety of locations, is enhanced by some card play that isn't too vicious, and allows for a good variety of decisions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My review:  http://manualgamer.com/lords-of-waterdeep-review/

Short Version:  A great worker placement game, set around recruiting adventurers, completing quests and scoring points for plotting and scheming in the DnD city of Waterdeep.  

Each player has a hidden identity which is revealed at the end of the game, which will give bonus points depending on the objectives completed (mainly completing particular quest types).  This means that one can never be quite sure who is in the lead.  

Lords of Waterdeep is very well polished, with excellent pacing.  It never outstays its welcome and is an excellent use of game-time.

It has a low learning curve and is accessible to non-gamers, but with enough depth and variety to keep experienced gamers interested.

Combine this with plenty of interaction between players,  and a pretty theme  and we have a game that is a real real winner. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
All of the praise for this game is well deserved. 

Good: 
A good variety of planning and scheming is required to get your meeples placed in the location you are hoping for in order to succeed in your lord's objectives (complete quests, build, etc). 

While you can interfere with your opponent's plans by blocking spaces they want or using intrigue cards against them, the game never really feels overly cutthroat. 

The game has a built in insert that holds all of the components perfectly.

Bad: 
The components don't really enhance the theme. For example, adventures are represented by cubes but in the end they only feel like resources, they may as well be food cubes needed to complete quests. If you enjoy this game I would recommend looking into replacing the cubes with character meeples.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Fun, yes. Overhyped? Perhaps. To me it plays like Stone Age with the building mechanics of Caylus. And as such, I like it because itâs deeper than SA and not as long as Caylus. 

The theme fell completely flat for me though. Theyâre cubes, not warriors, clerics, what-have-you. Iâm fine with that but it does seem strange. 

The Lord cards serve as variable end game bonus, but are fairly minor and can be annoying. The building one is the only one of interest. 

Some reviewers have pointed out the Mandatory Quest problem. This is really the only true conflict and it can be huge. House rules can adjust this if desired. 

The building variability allows for replays but all the other randomness really isnât random at all and so I think this will suffer the same fate as SA after enough plays. But still, itâs fun now.

RATING: 2
12/18/12 Played 60% of a five-player game.
I had no idea what the theme was supposed to be, or what a "waterdeep" is, or what we player's were supposed to be. The four colors of resource cubes were supposed to represent... something, but it was never stated what. Its as if one took about three Euros, used one random mechanism from each, then pasted on an ill-fitting fantasy theme. Unfortunately the designers used a very boring and laborious set of mechanisms to borrow. I assume the real audience for this game are those that are familiar with the theme; which isn't me. As best as I can figure the *only* reason to play this game is if one likes the theme. Baring that its merely a boring exercise in cube gathering and blocking the placement of other player's meeples. As I have no idea what the theme is (nor do I care to find out) it left me cold. I hope to never see it again.

RATING: 4
It lost its lustre as I played more games. This definitively has the "streamlined" factor, but the nuts and bolts are a bit too obvious - the whole 4 / 2 / 1 balancing act that runs through the whole game means that the only real way to get ahead is a) Combo the right cards which means b) Draw the right cards (quests) and c) Don't get hit with the mean stuff. This makes it fine for a few plays, then it's just all auto-play with few decision points of any interest (that isn't to say it's solved or any such thing, but that the draw to consider my decisions in more depth simply isn't there while playing - hence auto-pilot).

A smooth ride, suitable for most people - even if they've never played games of this sort before - you can be up and ready in less than 5 minutes. Also, it looks pleasant and the whole comboing quest card abilities is a bit fun.

A fine game.

RATING: 8
In mijn bezit sinds 19-06-2012
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I have never played D&D in my life, but I love worker placement games, and this is a fantastic one in my opinion. You start out with a nice selection of spots to go to (and a few extra if you include the expansion), but that will expand as all the buildings in this game are additional worker spots. All players plays as a secret lord who gives bonus points for certain quest types or buildings, and the goal of the game is, of course, to have the most points at the end of the game.

The game is really easy to teach, the iconography is very straight forward. It scales really well, though I personally prefer to play with a lower player count as you get more workers the fewer players there are in the game. Though the more players there are in the game, the better the effect of at least some of the intrigue cards in the game. I think three players is the optimum sweet spot for this game, but it really works well with two (which is the player count I play the most).

If you like worker placement at all, this is the game for you.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Great game, simple mechanics. Sometimes the quest cards can really altar your luck and chance of winning. But still a great worker placement game

6-28-2013 Initial rating 6.

After playing the game some more with just two players, it is starting to grow on me. The number of actions you get to take throughout the entire game grows significantly with fewer players. This makes it easier to get an engine going and allows you to more easily link together quests. The intrigue cards become less effective with two, but I feel like the blocking has more friction than with more players.

Worker placement, recruiting men to do quests (LotR style)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Lords of Waterdeep is an introductory worker placement game that includes the basics of the genre along with the quest system, a straightforward way to give newbies a clear goal for play. I like how all of the different mechanics (i.e., the intrigue cards, quests, secret lords, adding new action spaces through buildings) fit together into a nice package. However, in the end I always feel like there should be more - something more to build, something more to do. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
My son and I play this game regularily at the local board game store.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
You get pawns, which you assign to specific locations over the board, which in turn gives you resources (fighters, clerics, mages, thieves, money, etc) that you need to complet quests (which you get at the start of the game, a few, then you also must use the pawns on specific locations on the board to get more quests). As soon as you meet the requirements of a quest, you can complete it, getting its reward (usually some victory points, sometimes you also get toher resources). The winner is the player with most victory points at the end of the game.

It's a rather simple, not long, eurogame. As many say, the theme is kind of thin, but it is there, and I like the reversal (usually you play the heroes, be it a videogame or rople play, or boardgame, here you play as the giver... not exactly, but sort of).

RATING: 6
Very smooth and streamlined introductory worker placement, as many have said before.  However, not my cup of tea, as there are a few aggressive plays that players can make to pretty much break your game (as has happened in both games I've played).  Maybe more experienced players will be able to plan for these things, or maybe some house rules could fix them, but in my opinion, a little too cut-throat for a nice easy game.  Also, (again, agreeing with countless others), it's pretty tough to get into the theme with the "resources" being cubes.  They're supposed to be different classes of adventurers, but most players just gave up on that and called them purple cubes or white cubes, etc.

Technically, a well-made game perhaps, but not one that I fancy.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
So hyped and overrated for such a underwhelming rehash of mechanics and game play.

It's yet another stupid worker-placement Euro with a pasted on theme. Maybe it's just me - I mean it's worker f***ing placement - and I just can't seem to care about putting my workers onto spaces to collect some resource which I will then spend at a later date to collect VP. It fails to feel meaningful, even with the thinly pasted-on theme of D&D and the attempt to make it more thematic with Intrigue cards.

The whole experience was one big bag of holding full of meh. I won't say no to future games, but honestly, if I am going to play worker placement at all (and it's rare I want to), I will still prefer the food-crunch tension of Agricola, the fiercely tight management required by Pillars of the Earth, or the butterfly effect and area control of Dominant Species.

RATING: 4
This was never terribly exciting and, after several plays, has started to get old. The decisions aren't that tough, so I'm pretty much on auto-pilot during most of the game. I don't really like cube conversion games that much, but forgave this one because I appreciated the theme and was impressed that it played in just an hour (once). Everyone else thinks it's themeless, and every other session's been at least 90 minutes, bordering on "too long for what it is." Although everyone I've introduced it to has enjoyed it, I simply don't find it interesting enough to view it as a keeper.

Note that we mitigate luck by by not distributing any Quest cards at the beginning of the game.

RATING: 8
I played this one not really expecting too much from it as I am not wildly enthused by D&D products these days and have played plenty of worker placement games so that I expected this to be a bit old hat. I was pleasantly surprised to find that this was nothing of the sort. The game played really well and was thoroughly enjoyable from the start. The game play is clean and easily understandable and there is enough variety to make it very replayable. The production values are very high and the theme does not feel entirely âpasted onâ (theme does matter to me).

To paraphrase the late, great Victor Kiam, "I was so impressed I bought the game". Since my initial foray, I have managed to play a couple of two player games with Mrs Fish and she enjoys it as much as me. I see this one as a keeper that will get plenty of use in the years to come. The only minor gripe I have is that there is a promotional card that is not readily available the complete-ist in me hopes that this will be incorporated into a future expansion (yes, Iâd buy an expansion for this one).

RATING: 7.9
When taken in stride, this is an interesting, smooth-flowing, light worker placement game.  At the start of the game, you are randomly dealt a personality: some are very easy to score with; others require you to get lucky draws from the large stack of objectives and intrigue cards.  If the needed cards don't appear, it can be frustrating from the first turn and leave the unlucky player with a bad impression of the game. 

2015-07-12:  There really is a good amount of lucky with the way intrigue cards & quests come out during the game.  If someone gets a 40-point quest at the right moment, that one lucky draw can swing the outcome. 

(Includes Skullport expansion)

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
An all around great worker placement game. It's intimidating to new players, but is surprisingly easy to teach and learn. Even though it is relatively simple, there are still plenty of interesting decisions to be made. 

I like the buildings element - the idea of spending resources to add action spaces to the board is cool. Opponents will want to use the spaces because they are really good, but they also help the building owner. Plot quests are cool too, as they can be nice little bonuses, or completely change how you play the game. The same applies to the intrigue cards. 

The worker placement mechanics work out well - you always have to think ask which action will be more effective? What spaces can I take now, and what can I risk leaving for my opponents to take? What is my opponent going to do next? 

However, even though there are cool combos to pull off with quests, buildings, action spaces, and intrigue cards, a lot of those things come down to luck of the draw. It isn't too bad, but sometimes it sucks. 

I also don't particularly love the idea of the hidden lords, in the sense that often, the best way to play is to just comply as much as possible with what your lord wants. Also, the lords are hidden, but figuring out which lord card someone has doesn't really make a difference.

Overall it is a solid game. I enjoy it a lot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Excellent worker placement (WP) game. The D&D theme is pasted on; but the rulebook is wonderful, the gameplay is linear without hidden traps: just sit down and fight for grabbing cubes to fulfill your quests. At the end, VPs will run like a jackpot.

If you want to start with a WP game, play this.

Rate: :star::star::star:

RATING: N/A
A nice worker placement euro. The mechanisms work well together, there is only little randomness and more player interaction than the average euro thanks to intrigues.
The Caylus-like idea "buildings are more actions to place worker to" is very neat, too.
Too bad the unnecessary D&D theme, but that might be a plus for others.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[b]Like:[/b]
-The satisfying feeling of finishing a quest

[b]Dislike:[/b]
-Theme
-Not really any tension compared to other worker placement games

It was fine I guess? I had a hard time feeling the theme though (and if you're using fantasy as a theme, that's a problem). For being an organisation that has agents to send out (which sounds cool!), I didn't feel like one. You'd think agents are there to spy or sabotage your opponents, but the only way they really interact with them is... standing in their way?

Speaking of blocking, there are usually so many quests going on, I found it hard to keep track of what my opponents needed, so I didn't play to block them and just acted out of my own interest. When I got blocked, it wasn't really because the opponent wanted to ruin my plan, it just so happened to be that we needed the same but they got to go first. I feel annoyed (only slightly though since there's many back-up spaces) and the opponent doesn't feel particularly smart.

The other way to interact are the intrigue cards. There are probably dozens of different ones, but it doesn't really matter what they do: they either buff an opponent, so you give that to the losing player, OR they hinder them, so you give that to the winning player. Not really a point in having so many different ones. Buildings also definitely don't feel like buildings I built, just more spaces to got to.

And this is probably nitpicking, but I liked it better in Champions of Midgard that the meeples are about the size a human would be on the map, so it really feels like they're walking around town. Here, the city is so zoomed out that it just doesn't feel the same.

I mean, the game does nothing bad really, it's not that I got frustrated by the mechanics or anything, it's just that I didn't really get excited by them either. Completing quests is comparable to completing routes in Ticket to Ride, but that game is more straightforward (no text) and funnier.

And why do I loose all my recruited people when I complete a quest? Are they all dead or something? This might as well been a game about being the most successful spice manager, fulfilling contracts by selling spices.

Champions of Midgard is the better game.



Comment on "Owned": my brother owns this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
This is the new favorite at our house.  Absolutely fantastic insert that everything fits into. Once packed correctly (with a touch of OCD), you can turn the box upside down, shake, and everything is still in its spot!  I love that some of the coins abide by the old money thinking of: "if I can sew it into my clothes, I can hide it" (aka, there are holes in currency...for a reason....)

Onto gameplay: you are a lord of waterdeep, which really means nothing unless the cards you get bonuses are shown...and you can pick them up....You have people to do your bidding!  You actually go on quests to get resources and victory points (I call them Ruppees) so you can quest more.  You can be a total asshat, or genteel depending on your table situation.  As someone whose played DnD since 3 (yes, I'm young),  I like the flavor and easy mechanics of this game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Fun worker placement game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Finally got a chance to try this much hyped game.  Well, bottom line is that it's a nice medium weight worker placement game along the lines of Stone Age.  I understand the Caylus lite comments, and agree with them.  It plays quickly, has more interaction than Stone Age, with a Fantasy theme that may appeal to some and turn others off.

I'm not familiar with this D&D theme, so the theme does nothing for me.  Stone Age or this title, makes no difference to me.  I did enjoy the player interaction portions of the game, but prefer the player confrontation in Carson City.

Personally, I enjoyed the game and would be willing to play again.  However, I'm not looking to own this title since I already own plenty of other worker placement games with and without direct confrontation (i.e.  Dungeon Lords, Caylus, Stone Age, Pillars of the Earth, Carson City, Age of Empires 3, Egizia, Tribune...).

I would recommend this game for folks that want a quick playing medium-light worker placement game with some light player interaction, and are OK with a fantasty theme.

If you have some of the game titles I listed above, I don't know that you really need this game.  I don't.

RATING: N/A
Type: Thematic

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
So I bought this game expecting it to sit on my shelf and get played once a year or so. Read the rules and ran a mock through by myself. The rules were pretty simple and the game play was pretty quick. Somehow I talked my wife into playing. I didn't think she was going to like it because she hates Agricola, and this game is in my opinion, slightly like Agricola. (Slightly) You use your agents to perform tasks that get you points. To my surprise, the wife really enjoyed it. We have only played it once, but I can see us playing it at least once a month. (Don't have time for more, way too busy.) She is not familiar with Waterdeep or the theme, so she enjoyed the game just based on the way it is played.

The game takes about an hour with two people and a person who has never read the rules was able to really begin playing within 10 minutes. There is a little luck involved based on Intrigue cards or just the way the quests and buildings come up, but mostly it is strategy. Do you do something good for you, or bad for someone else? With a limited number of moves and rounds, you really have to plan ahead. My wife spent too much time trying to stop me and not enough helping herself, so I managed to eek out a win. (That strategy usually works for her.) All in all, a really good game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Excellent game play, easy mechanics.

RATING: 8.5

It should be more dnd-ish "I hire 2 rogues, and sent 1 of them with 3 fighters and a cleric to get the Chalice of Destruction" or something like that.

Waiting impatiently for the expansion.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Not that bad :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I'm done with VP race eurogames that don't feature a compelling core mechanic. I'm done with what they propose, I'm done with what other people see in them that I don't. Lords of Waterdeep is your run-of-the-mill worker placement game; which saddens me, because worker placement being genre in the collective consciousness of board gamers is symptomatic of the focus on how actions are selected rather than what actions do. Mostly in order to hide that those actions are actually quite dull: gain resources, grab a card that converts resources into victory points, convert resources into victory points according to a card, build new spaces providing slightly better ways to do all the previous. Multiplayer solitaire in a big mathy puzzle.

LoW is no exception and even worse than average on the player interaction side: there is always a desirable and easy-to-determine best option, then an equally desirable next best option. Blocking happens, but as long as players are aiming to win, such an interaction is incidental, moves being only decided with the intent of optimising personal efficiency. Intrigue cards don't change much, at most they randomly hose players for working on tight resources without any leftovers, but they are diverse enough you shouldn't constantly plan around their effect and rather just accept your fate.

Perhaps if you happen to guess someone's secret identity, when choosing between two similar quests you'll pick the one that the leading player wants the most; but that's the extent of the game's appeal to me. In conclusion, if you're unsure about the whole eurogame thing, I would suggest you try Lords of Waterdeep; a very approachable entry point complexity-wise with great production values. Personally I can't recommend it, but more on behalf of its whole genre that makes me feel like I'm doing my taxes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Meh, I was initially very fond of this game. The only reason I still have this in my collection is for it to act as a gateway game for workerplacement games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
One of the best worker placement games I've played.

RATING: 7
As someone who doesn't know what's D&D, it's a lighter caylus that has three things I don't like - the use of mandatory quest to target a specific opponent, only one building can be bought each turn (and can't be built by resources!) and having to keep track of all the face-up quests your opponent control. 

The good thing is the intrigue cards adding variety and the choices as to fulfill the quests you own or spending time to get the quests that will be benefits you more. 

Also, it plays fast, support up to five players, and new players can be competitive the first time they play the game. A pretty average game at its core, but it's very easy to have this game started.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Really, this is not a bad game. I just don't want to play it. At best it is mechanically bland, and I suspect the primary reason anybody plays it is because it looks good and places little demand on the players, either competitively or mechanically.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
In this worker placement game, your workers are agents who recruit rogues, magicians, clerics and warriors  that are represented by different colored cubes. You then use the adventurers to complete quests to score VPs. Each player also has a secret card that allows them to score more VPs depending on the type of quests that they fulfill. There are also intrigue cards that allow you to throw a wrench into your opponent's plans. You can make them fulfill mandatory quests first, or get cubes for your benefit, so there is a fair amount of targeting opponents with nuisance cards. Now to be fair, I haven't played a full game, and would like to play a full game to see if the nuisance cards are that random. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Some interesting, albeit very light, decisions. Nothing groundbreaking. Zero theme (although that doesn't bother me) Fun. Plays really quick which is a real bonus. There are many games which do the same thing significantly better.  Still very very very overrated and I really can't see why.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Buen juego. FÃ¡cil de explicar. Mejor aun de desarrollar. Tienen distintas facetas del juego que permite disfrutarlo en varias formas. Disfrutamos de 2 horas de juego. Donde existia interaccion entre los jugadores por los recursos que estaban disponibles. Buen juego.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.9
1. It's a euro game. The theme is painted on. They're called clerics and fighters but they're white and orange cubes respectively. This is to be expected. It plays like a worker placements game. However, despite the painted on theme, the amount of fluff inserted into the cards, rulebook, and fluff through text and art means that it can be played completely abstract but if you do dig deeper, you get the impression that there is more going on. So it's actually cool. It's like theme-optional which is nice for a euro game which largely have no theme besides art. This is better than that.
2. It's better than how I imagine Pillas of the earth and Agricola are as worker placement games based on what I know. It's an hour instead of two hours. Once we started, it didn't feel extra slow by being our first game, but it did take 15 minutes to really learn rules and set up which is is a one time only deal. I still want to play those other games but based on watching plays online, reviews, descriptions, etc. I feel like this is more streamlined, fun, fast paced but that's a lot of speculation.
3. As a euro game it didn't leave me going "that was epic" or "amazing" it was fun, light, and accessible as an economic/worker placement/euro game. Nothing AMAZING but that's to be expected--a relaxed game.
4. Despite the previous point, I actually compared this to other euro games I owend or had played, and I realized that I THINK I still enjoyed this, even on our first game, more than any other euro I had played including settlers, carcossone, either beowulf game, ticket to ride, anything by Knizia including lord of the rings or Samurai. Truth be told, I can't actually think of a euro game that seemed to have a higher fun factor and be more enjoyable despite the fact that it didn't blow me away because it was quite relaxed.
5. I like the improved player interaction through intrigue cards. This puts it ahead of MOST euro games alone, just in the fact that it's not completely competative solotaire.
6. Just the right amount of depth. It stayed accessible without being bogged down but the number of choices, options and strategies seemed truly huge, even blowing away other deep euro games.
7. The only other euro game that felt more thematic was NInjato but this one may be overall a bit better and certainly more accessible. 
8. The components lend themselves to a real elegance and despite the tiles and cards beinga  bit delicate, they look amazing. The components, boards, cards, and tiles, make it EASY to remember the rules and the options you have.

If you like euro games but are wary about the overly bland light ones or wary of the overly heavy stressful ones, Lords of Waterdeep may very well be the perfect blend of a medium-light medium tight euro game that has satisfying gameplay and scratches the itch for a strategic and cereberal euro game without trying to be overly innovative. It is not by theme painted on alone, that this game was more enjoyable than other Euros.

Based on what I've read and played, I'd recommend this over any euro game I've played or owned so far and even agricola, pillars of the earth, etc. So far, no one has challenged me with a euro game having a higher fun factor than this--even carcossone which has more luck than this and a wonkier famer scoring system.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Definitely recommend some sort of fine system for people referring to 'cubes' instead of different classes of character, otherwise the theme is gone altogether!

RATING: 6
Now THIS is what a worker placement game should be.  I suspect this may move up to a nine after a few more plays.  One member of my game group said this will replace Belfort for them. Update: The new expansion reinvigorated my group's interest in this game.  It is a good end of evening game that everyone knows how to play without a lot of discussion so it works well as our gateway or casual game.

RATING: 8.5
This is an interesting game. For folks that just want to treat it as a worker placement game, it works, and works well. It's pretty easy to just call everything by colour and score your points.

For the folks who want to get more out of it, or who like the D&D theme, you can certainly do that too. I find it to be a lot more fun if you do. Play intrigue cards on the the other factions by name. Say you're sending an agent to recruit fighters, then read the quest out that you send them on and score points with.

The game is simple, but engaging for the entire time. It plays quickly and has a set length, lasting less than two hours with a full five players. Well worth the investment, you will get your value out of it...and your gf will probably even play it with you.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
A worker placement game that is very easy to learn, but figuring out the optimal move never seems obvious. Essentially, you send your workers to locations to gather cubes to match those printed on quest cards. The more cubes required for a quest, the more points you get.

Sounds so simple it should be boring, but the theme makes it work for me:
As one of the secret lords who rule Waterdeep, you send your agents out to recruit adventurers, who in turn go on quests on you behalf.
There are different quests, like Skullduggery and Warfare, that require different adventurers, like Rogues and Fighters. Different lords also focus on different quests.

The secret lord part is mostly a gimmick that adds very little to the game, as there is little to no advantage in figuring out what your opponent is focused on. If anytning, it actually weakens the game, as your secret lord forces you to possiby ignore 60% of the avaiable quests.

There are also buildings to buy, adding new places to visit. These are usually better than the locations printed on the board, but offer a reward to the owner. 
This adds a nice touch to the game; making you choose between a weak location, or a strong one that also helps you opponent.
It also adds replayability as the huge stack of buildings make sure that no two games will be the same.

You get a different number of agents depending on the player count, so this scales very well.

There's a really neat insert, except they made the spaces for coins and VP-tokens to small...
Also, the board has room for a sixth player that comes with the expansion, but the insert doesn't...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8
A fun, light worker placement game.  The aesthetics and components are really well done.  The theme doesn't matter at all in this game, and the fact that the theme doesn't connect in any way to player actions really hurts the immersiveness of the gameplay.  The quest cards and secret objectives do help to keep gameplay interesting.  Some of the intrigue cards are clearly more helpful than others.  Other worker placement games implement global conditions that affect all players, and I think that would help make turns more imperative rather than one player simply playing intrigue cards on another player.

RATING: 7.5
Another worker placement game which, like Ninjato, could be said to have a pasted on theme. But unlike Ninjato, which doesn't really deserve that tag, I think it's a fair enough criticism when levelled at Lords of Waterdeep. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy the game. It has lots going for it. The gameplay is very smooth, it's easy to teach and it plays pretty quickly. The aim of the game is to complete quests which you do by recruiting the required number of different adventures. The problem is, I felt like I was collecting the right number of coloured cubes rather than completing quests. That's okay to begin with but I like my games more immersive. That said, the presenation is fantastic and I need to play with three or four players to really judge it. Edit: Played with four and it worked well. Same reservations apply but other players enjoyed it.

RATING: 4
Board will build up so you'll never have any problems getting cubes but the single "get gold" and "build" spaces will snowball first players to an expected victory.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Lords of Waterdeep is an excellent entry-level Worker Placement/Set Collection game. Where LoW scores over starter Euros is probably the feature that most hardcore players despise: Each player is dealt a card in secret at the beginning of the game which gives endgame victory points for completing certain tasks. This basically outlines the strategy that player need adopt to remain competitive against the others. Great for a novice, but a veteran Euro player might find this removes their ability to choose their own path.

Lords of Waterdeep feels thoroughly play-tested, resulting in a slick production, right down to the components. Every conceivable component, however unnecessary, is included, once again angling to an introductory feel. The player boards, for instance, don't give any gameplay information, but do provide players well-defined spaces to store their personal holdings. The game board made room for reminder spaces for victory points that are added each turn to unpurchased buildings. LoW even comes with an excellent box-insert, mapped out in the instructions showing where everything is stored!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Lords of Waterdeep is an excellent entry-level Worker Placement/Set Collection game. Where LoW scores over starter Euros is probably the feature that most hardcore players despise: Each player is dealt a card in secret at the beginning of the game which gives endgame victory points for completing certain tasks. This basically outlines the strategy that player need adopt to remain competitive against the others. Great for a novice, but a veteran Euro player might find this removes their ability to choose their own path.

Lords of Waterdeep is a slick production. Every conceivable component, however unnecessary, is included, once again angling to an introductory feel. The player boards, for instance, don't give any gameplay information, but do provide players well-defined spaces to store their personal holdings. The game board made room for reminder spaces for victory points that are added each turn to unpurchased buildings. LoW even comes with an excellent box-insert, mapped out in the instructions showing where everything is stored!

After many plays it has become evident that there is an imbalance in the quests. Arcana quests are too simple to achieve for the high Victory Points and bonuses they reward. This imbalance translates to a higher win percentage for anyone with a Lord that benefits from Arcana quests. This imbalance may force a replacement of LoW.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
2-5 Players are vying for control of the city of Waterdeep.  A worker placement game where you are completing quests that require gold, thieves, fighters, wizards, and clerics for points.  An identity is passed to you in the beginning dictating what quests you will be shooting for for a bonus at the end of the game.  

In the beginning there are quite a few actions, but as the game progresses more buildings come out and add more fund actions to do during the game.

A very simple and intuitive game that plays quickly and is a gem to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Great intro to Worker placement Resource management eurostyle gaming.

RATING: 8
Wow, this game plays quickly! But in that quick of amount of time (1 hour or so) you have a lot of decisions to make. The cards bring variety to the game and there are plenty of ways to mess with your opponents. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
It has a bit more razzle-dazzle (read: thematic) than Caylus, but Caylus is the better game. In a few ways, Waterdeep is more fun -- the notion of spending resources to complete a chosen quest rather than build buildings or the castle; the secret objective; the intrigue cards -- there is that luck of the draw factor that makes card games fun. But for the same reasons, it's a less balanced game. Finally, the king-making mandatory quests force astute players to play dead, which isn't a bad thing [i]per se[/i] but tips the game slightly from the strategic. I do have a good time every time I play it though, and maybe that's what matters.

[color=#117bc0][b]Probably rather play:[/b][/color] Caylus
----
downgrading from 7.5. Nice bounded game length of 8 rounds (if a bit randomly chosen), but starting luck plays too much of a difference. Say you drew a starting role that pays 4 extra for warfare quests, then your dealt quests are both warfare quests, one of which pays 2 extra for warfare completed -- it's a lot of overpower in a game that tends to have close outcomes, and the wrong kind of luck for this type of strategy game. Perhaps it's remedied by not starting with any quests?
----
...ah, who knows, maybe this is just a pitch-perfect blend of Ameritrashy chrome and euro. Gameplay doesn't drag, and there are decisions throughout that require thinking through. The Skullport (corruption) expansion adds such a natural, yet simple depth to the game, with surprisingly well-integrated buildings, quests, and intrigue cards. It's a 9 with Skullport, and a 6.5-7.5 without.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
I know this game gets knocked by a lot of people who are veteran worker placement gamers, but I really like this game.  It was the gamer that introduced me to the worker placement model and led me to get into some more in depth versions of that mechanism. 

But I love how easy this game is to teach and play and I like the basic strategies it engenders.  The components are great, and while the theme is barely noticeable unless you work at it, I still like the connection to D&D.

There are times when I want to cook a 3 course meal and times when I just want a simple but delicious dinner.  This is the latter and I enjoy it for that reason.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
You acquire money, cubes, quest cards and intrigue cards by worker placement. Intrigue cards provide some player interaction (and unpredictability) and may provide cubes, money, and quest cards. Cubes and money are turned in to complete quests on quest cards, that give VPs, money, cubes, quest cards and intrigue cards.
This is a thematic tactical game with no strategic depth that could be enjoyed by non-gamers. For gamers I would recommend worker placement games that require and allow a bit more planning ahead.

RATING: 8.5
I'm partial with this game because I'm a longtime D&D fan, and I also adore worker placement games... The perfect combo for me!

The only mechanic I don't like is the mandatory missions (it's ok as balancing and catchup mechanism, but they are too powerful, especially in many players game when you can be asfixiated with many of them).

Apart from that, it's not an original game, but it's very straightforward and fluid, with fast gameplay that appeals to most players. It's also allows for a different numbers of players without resenting too much. 

The classic example of a game that doesn't add anything new to the game world, but does everything well.

Soundrels of Skullport is one of the best expansions of the gaming world. Really worth it.

RATING: N/A
[Rebecca]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Lords of Waterdeep is a worker placement game where your strategy has massive effects on the game.  You play the game however you want for the most part - and it's a game of come backs in my recent two plays.  Each time the winner was trailing by 20-60 points in the first half, to the point where people simply would be surprised when they moved a few VP.

There's so much to do in this game and the replay value is considerable.  Depending on the quests that are available and the buildings players have purchased can change how you play.  Some plays go for hard VP advantages with the most potent quests.  Others go for a mix of intrigue and efficient quest completions.  And then others also focus on the Lord they drew.

I myself focus on appeasing my Lord by getting the quests that give me the bonuses.  Playing against veterans they can see through your charade and may begin blocking you, but these sort of moves can have consequences for them.

I just love the strategy involved!  It leaves very little to be desired.  And players become more and more involved as the game progresses.

Each time players are sort of dawdling for the first round or two.  By round 4 or 5 they are hovering over the board, contemplating complex moves and thinking turns ahead.  Even my little brothers get a lot of critical thinking done playing this.

GET THIS GAME PEOPLE!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5

In questo gioco i Lords di Waterdeep devono cercare di risolvere Quest per avere vantaggi e fare punti vittoria. Le azioni sono sempre molto poche e qesto rende preziosa l'influenza sugli eroi o il possesso dei piÃ¹ importanti edifici della cittÃ . A mio avviso un ottimo titolo.

RATING: 8
This has an attractively illustrated board and cards, as expected of a Wizards of the Coast game, which helps immerse you in the game. I also like all the different quests and map locations, which have character, and can be a bit of fun to read out in silly voices (if such be your bag).

The pace really picks up in the last two rounds, and you have to think very carefully about your moves.

I have played 4 times, but haven't sussed out the strategy yet, as each time I have come in with a lacklustre score, despite thinking carefully about how I played.

RATING: 8
+ Skullport
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
LoW is an interesting Worker-Placement game which is easy to learn and has attractive components. There is fun tension as players compete for their preferred placements. The board is attractive and there is excellent art on the cards. After the first play it has been easy to teach and generally well received. The only criticism of the game-play has been that in the early stages it is possible for players to be shut-out (if several players use Intrigue cards aggressively).

The components are another matter. Colourblind players have difficulty - the game uses purple and black cubes which are difficult for people with normal vision to distinguish; bright light is needed. The situation is made more difficult, however, because the symbols for different adventurers (i.e. the cubes) are tiny pictures of cubes. Grrr! Not only are these really difficult to see at a distance, the colours vary - some "purple" symbols are sky-blue on my set. I would enjoy the game quite a bit more if it was not a memory exercise.

RATING: 6
One of the best inserts in board game history. Streamlined and an excellent way to introduce new players to the worker placement genre. However, this game is far too simple and the attempt at a theme gets watered down by calling everything "cubes" rather than what the theme says they represent. There is not enough variety at the end of the day, and although you can somewhat pursue different avenues to success, it's really all the same thing. This is only good as an opener, or for gamers who do not like complexity and varying win conditions, or to teach new genres to players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
[b]Lords of Waterdeep[/b]

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]This game has continued to see consistent play in my house, my wife and kids all really enjoy it. I think this game will continue to see table time, especially since my wife may choose it when it is her pick for family game night. We have also played some 2p games and also enjoyed this, the game plays very fast with 2.

I have to admit that I am a bit surprised that this is one of the family weight worker placement games that has survived the Jones Theory culling (the other being my wife's favorite - Stone Age). Since we had so many worker placement games I trade a few away to make room for other games (Fresco, Kingsburg and Ninjato were traded. Personally I preferred Fresco but the rest of my family did not agree.). 

All that said I still think it is an excellent, family weight worker placement game that I always enjoy playing when it comes out.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (9):[/COLOR]

[i]Worker placement games have always been a hit in our house.
I was initially turned off of this game, in part because I figured it couldn't live up to the hype. I finally got the game and have not regretted it at all.

- My wife loves this game, which is always a huge + for me.
- The DnDeeples are amazing an really increase our enjoyment of the game.
- I love the artwork on the board/cards. Really well drawn fantasy art, everything is easy to read and understand.
- Family friendly design; my wife and older kids found it easy to learn played really well from the beginning. This is a very easy game to teach, the only area my daughter needed some coaching with was helping her figure out how important playing Intrigue cards could be.
- Turns go by very fast, there is not much AP in this game.
- Intrigue Cards: These make the game for us, they introduce a lot of direct player interaction.[/i]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
An excellent medium weight and possibly gateway game to Euros! The game is very simple to play and easy to learn, relearn and teach. The options are seemingly endless as to what you can do on a turn. And once players start buying the building tiles, the options become even more interesting with every turn. This game has so much going for it, so many really well balanced options and really fun options, that you almost don't care about winning.

The box storage is really wonderful; however, if you sleeve the cards they no longer fit in the awesome storage tray that lifts the cards when you press down with your finger. I have gone to storing them under the box insert.

RATING: 8.8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
If you're looking for a worker placement game that plays in a reasonable amount of time, provides some variety from game, has a bit of luck, has just a touch of stop-the-perceived-leader, then this is about as good as it gets. It's a shame it's gone with cubes to represent the clerics, mages, fighters and rogues you'll be recruiting to finish your quests, instead of miniatures or another better class of components, because it emphasises that the game really is nothing but gathering your cubes as efficiently as you can and then trading them in to satisfy quest requirements. Satisfying quests earns VPs, as do people using the buildings you've built (yes, Caylus style, but at least here the buildings on offer are a random draft, not the "always the same" race to get the same buildings out first that you seem to find in Caylus). There are Intrigue cards which can be gathered and played to either hit the leader or (the more usual) do yourself good (usually some style of gathering yet more cubes). Get more VPs at the end of game if you've done quests that your secret mission dictates, see who wins. It moves along pretty quickly, finishes in the right amount of time. If you don't mind the luck (of the quests on offer, of being hit, of missing out on the worker places you want), there's a decent amount to like.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
It's a very good worker placement game. The D&D theme is really just tacked on which sort of bugs me.  If I'm playing a D&D game, there should be dice-chucking, killing monsters and grabbing treasure.  That complaint aside, this is probably my favorite worker placement game that my group owns so I still enjoy it despite the D&D theme issue.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
One of my favorites. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Impressive Fresh Worker-Placement Set-Collection Fantasy Quest-Mission Game !! Very smooth play. Not too heavy, not too light. Plays about 60-75 minutes. I would consider this to be a beer and pretzels game. Quality and beautiful game. I like the setting and feel of this game. Rather than a dungeon crawl, it's a euro about a city-hub for parties doing dungeon crawls.

Mixed feelings about the adventurer cubes. It might've helped the theme/feel to have some mini-miniatures, but then cubes would better endure the constant handling. 

I'd like to try it with 2 players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
"Solid, if unexciting, light-medium worker placement game. DnDeeples are worth buying if you own and like this game."

What I like:
- Hits a nice weight: not too heavy, not too light
- Theme is appealing, although cubes detract (the DnDeeples are great)
- Most of the components are excellent

What I don't like:
- Mandatory quests often hit someone in 2nd or 3rd place
- A fair bit of randomness, esp. w/quest draws
- The box. The insert is very well done, except for squeezing the money and VP chits in

It felt less like Caylus Magna Carta than I had hoped, because buildings here are a bit of a side show. But the game flows well, and there is plenty going on. It definitely has that worker placement feel, with blocking and competition. With 5p, having only 2 workers per round feels very tight.

Quite a different game with 2p that with 5. You have a lot more actions each turn, so you can get more done. And it is a lot harder to block someone (intentionally or not). There is no bash-the-leader or kingmaking, and the MQ's don't feel at all mean. It becomes less chaotic and more thinky, and with 2, the value and importance of buildings is far lower. 

With 3p, you definitely have more actions (like 2p), but you have kingmaking (like 5p). Overall, I guess I would rate 2, 3, and 5 about equally.

It seems to be a 90-120 minute game for us, at any player count. I don't think we can get it down to 60.

It's a good game, but currently is overrated and overhyped. With 2 other people in my groups owning it, I'm sure I'll have plenty of chances to play it, so I sold my copy. If the hype ever dies down, I might overcome my character flaw of preferring underdogs, and might raise my rating. I agree with the current voted weight of 2.5.

RATING: 8
The theme doesn't really come through despite the licence and the attempts (quest names etc) to tie it in.

What it is though is a very good WP game. Easy to learn - certainly for our group who have played a lot of these but I'm sure also for newcomers as it's very instinctive - and it all clicks together well. Finite number of rounds make it surprisingly quick, I like the staged addition of an extra worker at mid game also - just as spaces are typically getting scarce.

The production is gorgeous - all the board and card art, but also the smaller things like how all the pieces fit perfectly on the board. As for the inlay - either it's perfect or annoying having to fit everything into space each time

RATING: 9.9
Worker placement, and resource handling. Lot's of peoptle compare it with Caylus. But there are many othr games with similar mechanics. 

It's packeted in a nice D&D fantasy theme.

The box is tacky, although with nice artwork. The inlay is almost very good.

After first play I thought the game was so-so, but it grows on you.

And it gest better the more you play, so I had to raise my rating.

I have raised my rating. This is a often played game in my gamegroup nowadays. Has enough variation, and strategy to make every play fun. 

It's obvious that Larissa is good with three players and difficult with five. 

We houserule three things: 
1) you are dealt five quests in the setup and chose two.
2) with the expansion you are dealt two lords and chose one.
3) not played mandatory quests are taken out of the game in round 5 (if you have or draw new, replace them with other intrigue cards).

RATING: 7
Raised rating from a 6 as of November, 2013.  The game is a great introduction to worker placement for new and casual gamers.  I find that it builds very well off of Ticket to Ride: the concept of the route tickets in TTR translates quite easily to the quests in LoW.

This is a good game to have in my collection in that it fills that casual couples gaming niche.  I won't be pulling it out with veteran gamer groups, but it's a good one to have in reserve for a more casual night of gaming because it allows conversation and socializing while providing a fun, light game experience.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
15+ plays - A fantastic worker placement game, with a theme I like. Instead of rounding up lumber and metal, you're rounding up adventuring parties made up of rogues and priests (among others). What makes this particularly great is all the new worker locations that open up as buildings are opened. Plot quests may give you incentives to prioritise particular things, while utilising buildings may advantage your opponents who own them and gain a residual income when you do so. As the game progresses there are increasing amounts of factors to weigh up. Nice to look at, simple to setup and explain, catch-up mechanics are there for beginners, not much to complain about.

RATING: 6
A light worker placement game. There are few options each turn and you do not have a lot of workers, so the game should not last more then an hour. You are basically collecting cubes (who are different factions) and sending them on quests to earn points and other bonuses. You have a leader who will give you a bonus at the end for completing certain types of quests. Very straightforward for a worker placement game.

RATING: 8
A very good worker placement game, with a strong D&D based theme. 

My only issue with this game are the mandatory quests. I hate to receive them, and hate to play them on others even more. The simple solution is to take them out. They would have been far more interesting if they asked all players to put forward a resource to complete the quest. If enough is given, the quest succeeds and the participants receive a reward (money, points), otherwise, the non-participants suffer a penalty.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Leveraging the Dungeons & Dragons license, Wizards of the Coast has designed a worker placement game that offers something for nearly everyone. Lords of Waterdeep is reasonably brisk and is as easy to teach as it is to play, making it a fabulous introduction to the genre for new players. However, despite being something of a gateway game, Waterdeep also requires a number of strategic choices throughout, though is careful not to overwhelm players with having to make too many decisions at once. The game also includes a variety of different cards that provide a welcome taste of player interaction beyond Waterdeepâs worker placement gameplay. It also helps that the game scales really well, making it a fun and welcome experience at any table.

Light weight game with a fantasy theme.  Uses worker placement mechanics.

RATING: 7
Despite its D&D moniker, this was definitely a Eurogame, a worker-placement game in the style of Caylus, to be precise.  You place your workers to get resources in order to be able to buy buildings or complete quests.  The intrigue cards mixed things up a bit, and I really liked how they essentially let you do two things at once.  However, I didn't like that many of them forced you to pick on individual players, sometimes at no benefit to yourself--it didn't really seem to fit this sort of game.

(3 plays)

RATING: 10
This game sounds like the most ridiculously derivative stereotype of a Euro game ever. And it is! This is the kind of game I would design if I wanted to make a parody of Euro games. However, LoW has gone beyond parody, into the realm of genius. This is elemental Euro game, boiled down to its essentials; an archetypal worker-placement, cube-hoarding masterpiece.

Never once do I feel like I am gathering warriors, priests, and wizards in a tavern, and getting them to help me complete quests. That, of course, is not the point. The point is to have a silly, pasted-on theme. I am gathering cubes, to play cards which give me points, and sometimes more cubes. There are spaces where I can put my workers, so that they will get me cubes. There are cards I can play to destroy my opponents' cubes!

This game is fun as hell.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Really great. Everything about this game is solid. The design of the pieces is first rate (aside from the cubes which, literally, lack character). It simple to play and the worker placement is really rewarding. Its like a hugely cut down version of Agricola.

I'd like to see some more in depth quests. Perhaps multi-part quests with varying objectives.

Pre-ordered the expansion :)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A game I am always up for playing!  This was my first introduction to Worker Placement and it holds a special place in my heart. Play flows incredibly smoothly and the building tiles give it a ton of replay value.  I would give it 10 out of 10 but the Skullport module actually manages to improve on it!

RATING: 7
Made by an American company; this very nearly qualifies as a Eurogame, but then they added in that mechanic where you use cards to screw over certain players.  I assume they intended to use it as a balancing mechanism to make sure nobody gets too far ahead.  The problem I have found is it's extremely unpleasant to be sitting at a table and four other players have decided I'm winning too much so they're cooperating to find the best way to sabotage me.  I prefer Power Grid style balancing where the board contains natural disadvantages to being in front.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Decent gameplay, but I feel it's overrated. Combines the geekiness of D&D with the dryness of a cube-pushing Euro, stripping away any sense of story (which is surely the greatest appeal of the fantasy genre?) while leaving a nerdy residue of wizards, warriors and quests, so I'm left feeling slightly dissatisfied with both aspects. I think I would have preferred it if it had some cliched Euro theme such as medieval city building. 

I also dislike the mandatory quests - with the importance of action efficiency, it can be incredibly frustrating having one played on you at the wrong moment - especially in the last round of the game. And I'm also not very keen on the secret role mechanism as it can lead to imbalanced overlaps - for example in a 4-player game, if 3 players are collecting Warfare-Arcane, Arcane-Piety, and Warfare-Piety, the 4th player collecting Commerce-Skulduggery has a clear advantage as they'll face less competition.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Both the wife and I like it, that makes it a winner.  I haven't played it yet where I didn't have fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Straightforward worker placement with a straightforward VP engine. No surprises here, and remembering that warrior cubes are orange hardly reeks of theme, but this one appeals to me more than, say, Aquileia, which has a tighter economic/placement engine but is less forgiving.

What I like about LoWD is that the Intrigue cards may throw some chaos (and the quest draws are, of course, random) but the chaos-creation generally doesn't cause a devastating amount of damage. In sum, being effed with won't hurt so bad because you almost always have other, feasible options, and there's no rush to get things done THIS VERY TURN (which is nice). Finally, the "mandatory quests" can slow runaway leaders without much cost to the one who assigns them.  In many worker placement, such "blocks" or obstructive acts are more costly.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Not bad, not good either. You almost feel bad criticizing the game because it doesn't have evident problems or broken strategies - it's just that there's not much game there (without the expansions at least). You get a guy that likes magic related quests and stealing stuff, you try to get those quests when they seem doable.

RATING: N/A
Worker placement game in a D&D world.

Send Agents to gather warriors, rogues, wizards, and clerics. Take on quests and use intrigue cards to stymie your opponents or gain an advantage.  Complete plot quests for ongoing bonuses, and build buildings to gain the owner's benefits or new actions.

You can completely ignore the RPG theming if you so desire.

RATING: 7
A great gateway worker placement game that's easy to teach and plays very smoothly. Even though the theme is more or less pasted on, it still helps make an attractive game. 

The take-that elements and randomness of the quests/buildings/intrigue cards make for a functional "equalizer" that can be frustrating at times, but overall the game does what it's set out to do pretty well. It's accessible enough that even my stepmother-in-law took a liking to it. 

This is probably my most pimped out game which is funny because I don't even like it as much as my upgrades alludes to. The DnDeeples, Meeple Source corruption tokens, and Broken Token insert and coins cost three times the cost of the base game. I am insane.

RATING: 8
This is another worker placement game. I prefer it to most of the others for two reasons. First, there is some player interaction with the implementation of the Intrege cards. Second, and possibly most important, the board changes from game to game depending on the buildings that come into play. In short the game is more dynamic than any of the other worker placement games I have played.

RATING: 6
Fast worker placement game. Really good gateway game for the worker placement genre, with a nice 'build buildings' mechanic similar to Caylus but without the pawn that removes the spots from happening. RATING: 9
This has quickly become one of my favorite games. It is a big hit in my gaming group and we have played it many times. We don't get bored with it and re-playability is very high. I think this is one of the best games released in the past few years. Clean and strategic euro game mechanics combined with a classic fantasy theme. Highly recommended to anyone who is a fantasy genre fan. Bring on the expansions!

I suggest two variants for those who may want a friendlier game and tweak the starting quests to allow a choice: My "no mandatory quests variant" and the "smoother starting quests" variant. They both can be found in the variants forum section. We use both of these in my group and the game is enhanced and feels improved compared to the basic version.

RATING: 9
