=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
This game is a nice compromise between the feel of a "euro game" and an "ameritrash game." While the mechanics are a somewhat simplistic worker game, moving around the victory point track feels a little like moving around the board on a traditional American game.

For what it tries to do, Lords of Waterdeep does fairly well. It would go well when you want to play a board game with people who aren't board game geeks, but the theme seems a little out of place for a game like that. It's also excellent for when you want to have a conversation while playing a game, or need a game to fill in a brief gap of time.

I have only two real criticisms. The first is that the game is just too short. By the final round (#8), I feel like the game has finally found its stride, there are sufficient interesting choices, and then the game ends. The really interesting quests and building are the ones that have persistent results, and they just aren't worth building when the game is nearing its end. I think houseruling in 2 more turns, or adding an additional end condition (such as 'all building slots are filled') would amend this.

The biggest criticism I have to raise is about the Lord cards. There's a lot of untapped potential here that could have been interesting, but all the lords (with one exception) simply award 4 points for doing quests of one of two categories. One of the lords gives 6 points for each building they control (Way more interesting!). The problem with the Lord cards is they're supposed to be this big secret, but people will probably start playing their quest types fairly regularly, and it isn't very subtle. 

I'd like the Lord types to be more diverse, and to have more options added to the game that let you directly interfere with what you think another player's lord card is. Right now, the only real way to stop someone seems to be playing a mandatory quest, which usually isn't anything more than a minor annoyance. I'd like some options that would devalue what they have in their tavern, or let you pick where they put one of their agents, skip them once in the turn order, etc.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
An enjoyable game to bring out on a weekday evening after my husband is finished with work. He loves it even if he has yet to beat me. It's not terribly taxing but requires more thought than fillers. The Intrigue cards add spice to an otherwise very straightforward worker placement. I can see this being a good gateway game for anyone who is into the theme. Typically I ignore flavor text but because the theme is a bit pasted on and the cubes don't lend themselves well to enhancing that, I've taken to reading the flavor text aloud to get more of a thematic feel. I'm not in love with the game but it's solid and I won't be getting rid of it anytime soon.  In fact, I know I'll be playing the hell out of it since hubby is smitten.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
So Lords of Waterdeep is a worker placement game where the actual work you do serves only to give you resources you need to turn in quests, which then in turn give you VP and sometimes more resources, or recurring bonuses onto actions. You can buy buildings, which when used by others gives you a small bonus, but doesn't force that bonus to come from the user. Because of the limited nature of the actions (namely in them only giving you small amounts of resources, not like the accumulating resources of Agricola, being start player each turn is highly valueable. This was mentioned while the rules were explained, and it certainly bit me in the ass, by the time I was feeling marginalized enough that I needed to get start player, the material cost of doing so, namely the loss of one of my two workers, would just cost me even more than it was worth.

In addition, each player is given a hidden end of game scoring condition (for me it was completing commerce and piety; before the game started a lot of trash was talked about how piety quests aren't worth the effort, which discouraged me from putting much effort into that). I find that hidden goals can be frustrating, because suddenly you know that everyone else is trying to do unknowable things for extra VP, while you're stuck just struggling for VP in general. At the start of the game I had now commerce or piety quests, and there were none in the market, and so I started trying to get the blocks I needed for my quests. Of course, people started playing their actually good intrigue cards, which they used to pretty much take away the blocks I had already gotten (although I had only gotten those blocks because the actions for the blocks I wanted were already gone). So I got four points from my "Lord of Waterdeep" while the others got.. more. It's frustrating when everyone wants the same things, and so by going later you get no resources, so going first is only going to deprive other people of things they already have gotten.

At least with Agricola (I'm so sorry I have to make this comparison) players sorta have to sacrifice useful actions sometimes to get food at harvest, or will not take an action so it can accumulate more resources (both of these features is absent from LoD). I really felt like after maybe two rounds I would need at least three uninhibited agent placements to feel like I could accomplish something. There are probably groups I could be willing to play this with again, hesitantly, but that "hesitantly" has a big fucking chip on its shoulder.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.18
'Agricola Lite' with less random scoring is a very good description of this game.

Much easier to introduce new players to, although it has a very different theme - which is sometimes an advantage and sometimes a disadvantage; depending on the players.

Has a couple of abilities that allow you to go in a worker placement slot that someone else has already been in, which helps a lot.

Has a further advantage over Agricola in that you can add buildings (which are slots for worker placements) but you gain a benefit when one of the other players go in your buildings, even if you don't use them.

The buildings are quite key to the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.8
Nov 2014:  One of our current favorite. Tear-down and reset time are little long (see below) but this is a great resource game. The game plays different with the expansions - larger groups don't suffer the early game constraints which makes it feel similar to small group play. The challenges (in a large group without expansions) are that the last players can lose turns because no moves remain. The 'go first' position becomes much more valuable.

Broken Token Insert: you must get it... fixes set up /tear down

Feb 2017: We haven't played recently. I'm lowering 0.2 to keep my ratings current. I don't see this ever leaving our collection but when it is just gamers we will select different.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I love this game! I'm intrigued by the Euro game style, but have always been put off by the length and complexity. I respect 'em, but they're just not for my group! Lords of Waterdeep fits perfectly, though. It's light enough to easily and quickly explain to new players, and also plays quick enough to finish a game in about an hour to an hour thirty.

Even though it's a fairly simple game to learn, there's still a load of choices to make, and all of them are fun. The game feels balanced as well, with every spot on the board getting used. Some turns one spot may be highly contested, but a round or two later and a different area(s) is probably the center of attention.

The theme is excellent, though the choice of blocks for Rogues / Wizards / etc... abstracts it a bit glaringly. Instead of sending a group of adventurers as per the theme, it ends up sending back a certain number of orange / black / purple blocks to the supply to get victory points. The game could really use some figures for the classes.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Ooooh snap, a euro/D&D. The group I play games with new favorite. Play time 50-70 minutes. You can play this at work during a lunch break! And the best part is, if you are a grown man playing boardgames at work, there are not many bosses that will call you attention for being back to your desk late because they think you will murder them.

RATING: 7
I am not a fan of worker placement games at all, but I enjoyed this one because it's light and not bloated like so many other Euros available right now.

I really enjoyed the intrigue card mechanism. If you use a worker/agent to play an intrigue card, you can reuse that worker again at the end of a round to use another building/action.

Unfortunately, the board has dull, uninspired artwork.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
One of the better gateway eurogames I have played - with simple rules that can be taught in about 10 minutes (or even less), but with many interesting decisions, even though it's just a basic implementation of worker placement.

What makes it for me is the random component of cards and buildings. Each game feels fresh, because you aim for different quests and you have different resources available. And while sometimes you feel like the fortune gods are messing with you on purpose, somehow there's always the urge to play again. Not too thinky, not too hard, but definitely not mindless. 

My only criticism is the mandatory quest mechanic... Sometimes it becomes a kingmaking tool, especially when used by somebody who's already on the losing position. But that's a minor complaint - other than that, the game's a brilliant entry level eurogame.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: N/A
Phil W.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Although there aren't really that many paths to victory, the obstacles and advantages that you encounter on those few paths change with every game and can potentially even evolve during the course of a single game.  I like the fact that you don't get to see every building in each game.  I also like the fact that, even though you are initially pretty constrained in your choices, new options can quickly and unexpectedly arise from the Intrigue Cards, quest rewards, and building benefits.

I prefer the 3 player game over the 5 player game.  It is more open and less chaotic, but still maintains the tension of having to try to be as efficient, productive and crafty as possible with your moves.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I really like the beautifull design of the cards, and the storage in the box is done in such a perfect way which makes the game quick to set up, many components dont need to be removed from the box even which makes it quick to put away everything when the game is done.

RATING: 6
Great game - perhaps just a tad too light for me.
I usually quite like 'take that' in a game. This game doesn't have much, but the few Mandatory Quests that is in the game, seems just a bit too unbalanced. The persons targeted by Mandatory Quests is heavily set back compared to the other players. Especially in 4-6 player game.
Even more so, when the targeted player isn't even in the lead, but primarily targeted because he/she has the fewest cubes and thus have to put the biggest effort into completing the quest.

EDIT: After several plays I'd much rather play something else. Even with the expansion thrown into the mix the game is a drab experience

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
What a fantastic game! To some this may not equal much more than moving cubes around a board, but the theme really clicked with me. The intrigue cards can get really nasty. I especially dislike being delayed by mandatory quests, but this sort of interaction gives the game some much needed spice. I love the way the different Lords give players a different strategy to work with each game. My favorite mechanic, however, involved the way building cards create new locations on the board for all players but give the builder an extra boost each time they're used. Being able to guess your opponent's strategy can lead to some powerful moves. Overall: This was an instant favorite.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9.09
This game is a lot of fun.  It moves very quickly.  It's a nice touch that you can build buildings that become spots for worker placement (that are often more powerful than the original sports on the board).  When people use "your" spots you get a benefit.  I also like the fact that you can place in the harbor and get a benefit and then replace the game meeple (at the very end of the turn) to get yet another benefit.

I'm surprised my kids don't like it more.  Whenever I suggest it, they want to play something else.

RATING: 9
This game is an outstanding introduction to the concept of worker placement. It's SO easy to learn this game and it is just a blast to play. This is a great gateway game that will keep hardcore players' attention, as well as newbies. I love the intrigue cards that not only benefit you, but ONE other opponent, I like the Lords cards, and I love the buildings. I think it's easy for someone to start running away with the lead early, and it can feel a little unbalanced, but this game is fun every time I play it. I love this game.

RATING: 6
A nice clean, tidy, classic worker placement game.

A lot of people I know like it.

I personally can't be bothered with it. This is because the core goal (acquiring the right combinations of coloured cubes faster than your opponents) is only possible if you are constantly squinting around the table at tiny cards that show what combinations of cubes other players need to get at the time.

That ongoing math/eyestrain is dull, but the worker placement mechanisms are decent.

I prefer playing something like Caylus, which has similar mechanisms but without the bad bit and is slightly more cutthroat.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I feel like I need to play this again. I don't remember having a ton of fun the first time. It's an interesting game with a lot of strategy to explore, but it just felt flat and dull for me. Maybe I'm just not a worker placement fan.

RATING: 6

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
In my view this is a good gateway worker placement game, but for my taste there is too little meat on the bones. Owning good buildings early in the game is pretty direct way to success. The hidden identities force you to play in a certain way (focusing on a ceratain kind of quest) without adding anything to gameplay. Those side quests played on another player (who has to solve this quest first) are a cheap attack the leader mechanism, which seams out of place in Euro game. In my two plays the theme did not really capture anybody (this is rather a flavored Euro and not a hybrid between thematic and Euro game). Lords of Waterdeep is just a completely generic worker placement game with nice components.

RATING: 8.4
This game has a great mix of worker placement and resource management wrapped in an adventure game.  What really makes this game standout for me is the Waterdeep harbor.  Timing when to use this  or choosing to get what you want immediately is a key management aspect of this game.  It gives me the feeling like Pillars of the Earth when pulling master builders out of the bag when you need to decide whether to pay to use him now or put him in the back of the line.  This game might do it better.  The only thing that I have negative is the theme, although I'm glad it was there and it is interesting reading the flavor out loud, it just felt disconnected thematically.  I just didn'tgGet that story or adventure feel.  Overall, though it's just a great fun game.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Theme is glued on the surface, it's cubepushing in essence but overall a fairly nice game to bring new players into the hobby or just to play a quick worker placement game. 

After 7 plays the base game is just boring for experienced players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
+ Very streamlined worker placement game
+ Scales very well down to two players
+ Being able to use opponent's buildings is something I haven't seen in any other worker placement game
+ Adds in an extra method of blocking which can be effective if timed well (Mandatory Quests)
+ If you're an Ameritrash gamer trying to break into Euro then I would recommend this to you however Stone Age would be my more preferred gateway worker placement recommendation
+ Compared to Agricola for time, this game plays a lot faster

- Not as family friendly theme-wise as Stone Age and I might go as far to say maybe not as strategic even 
- Theme is not present, this is pushing cubes and order fulfillment with some D&D imagery pasted on
- Box is poorly designed and made
- Insert is equally poorly designed for vertical storage (I would toss the insert but the box is even flimsier without it)

RATING: 9.4
Love this medium weight worker placement game. For our group it has just enough choices and random buildings to keep this game both interesting and close till the end.

6/2/12 Ok. After a few more plays with my group this game fits my game group and their tastes perfect. After four games the buildings have strove to make each game a unique experience. I have not rated a game a 10 for a while and this one suits that number. Each game has been close and everybody was in the game. Play and enjoy.

After still more plays this game shines. We have found it easy to teach new players which is a big plus. Even now that we all know the game each one is unique and interesting down to the end. 

1.12.14 Played with the skullport expansion and this may be getting up there as my favorite game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
one of those games where i can't hardly believe my number of logged plays is so low! definitely a game about trying to balance your needs around those of others so that you don't get repeatedly blocked. there is "take-that" in the game, but it seems more geared towards inconveniencing a perceived run-away winner rather than making efficient use of resources during the game. Similar to Viticulture, Intrigue cards are often most useful in specific cases and also tend to help other players as well. i always used to wish the app was on Android, but now that it's here i never really bother. i really feel the draw of this game is in the social interaction around the table. sure, you can play serious and quiet, but even then it gives context to the blocks and counter-plays. i might get tired and move on from the game if i could get it to the table more often. until then, it's a fine worker placement game that i've played at both 2p and 5p with success. bottom line: Waterdeep is highly recommended for a reason. it's an accessible game that punches at least one notch above gateway to please a populous portion of the boardgame spectrum.

RATING: 9
The base game of LoW is an excellent gateway game for new players. It is easy to learn and play but difficult to win against experienced players. The theme is tied in to Dungeons and Dragons so it will appeal to RPG fans. We are very happy to have this game in our collection. Once you are familiar with this game, add the expansion for deeper, richer game play. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Fun quick worker placement game - basically Caylus-lite and more intuitive for new players. Scales very well from 2-5, probably better than any other worker placement game I've played. If everyone knows what they're doing, a 4p game can play easily in under an hour. Only minor complaint is that I wish there was more variety in the Lords, with combinations of bonus points for both # of buildings and a quest type, additional points for money or cubes at the end, # of completed quests, # of completed plot quests, etc.  I usually take Larissa out - she would be ok if there was more variety in the other Lords.  I also take out the mandatory quest intrigue cards - they don't provide any direct benefit to the player playing them, so they're just kind of kingmaker cards.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Played a couple of 4 player games so far and this is just a lot of fun. Is there some luck? Yep. Is there anything really new? Nope. Does it all work really well together, play very quickly, and does everyone have fun playing it? Absolutely. We knocked our second game of the evening out in an hour including setup and tear down. It's also not as scripted or static feeling as Caylus or some of the other heavier worker placement games. Good pick up. Oh and the insert is awesome.

RATING: N/A
íê¸í
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
[color=#CC0000]

I think the original theme was competing bakeries trying to corner the market on croissants in an obscure French town.  Hasbro opted to change it to a Dungeons & Dragons setting, which only required changing the image on the box cover and calling the purple cubes "wizards" instead of "blueberries".  If they hadn't put a pretty picture of Waterdeep underneath the locations on the board you'd have no idea what it was about, and frankly all the cubes piled in the middle of the board covered the pretty picture.  

This is a soulless game, though as Worker Placement goes you have enough options to make it playable without the usual WP frustrations.  Had it been a pastry theme it might have attracted a broader range of players and would have introduced a lot of places for comedic flair.  Fear not -- the opportunity to do that still exists and Hasbro might just re-release it that way to attract more attention.  As bland as the play is I'll recommend the following additional skins that could be viable:

 - Blimp factories in 1920s Germany.
 - Girl Scout cookie sales in a small, high strung, upper-middle-class suburban town.
 - Dark Age churches offering redemption options at bargain basement prices.
 - Quilt clatches fighting for space and attention at a convention, engaging in the kind of no-holds-barred to-the-death competition that only 75-year-old women that aren't afraid to die can bring.

Feel free to send me your own ideas; I'll post them to the list (with proper attribution of course.)

[/color]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
After several years of playing games, Lords of Waterdeep proves that it's sometimes better to make a game straightforward and accessible than it is to make it original and deep. I think this is exactly what I want from a light-to-middleweight Euro game these days. It's direct and intuitive, never getting caught in the weeds of engine-building and mindless activity. It's just as long, just as strategic, and just as interactive as it needs to be, and it never moves past that. There is great value in a game that knows what it's doing, and does it very well. One of my favorites of 2012.

RATING: 7.75
I think this makes an amazing gateway game to worker placement.  It's definitely simple enough for newcomers to grasp, while also including some extras beyond the basics - I'm mainly thinking of the ability to build new buildings which serve as new worker slots - that demonstrate the potential of the mechanic.  What makes it an amazing gateway game is that experienced players probably won't mind at all having to bring this out again and again for each new introduction, because it's a solid enough game to be enjoyable after repeated plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
It's a too-simplistic worker placement game with a "theme" that is vaguely and lazily applied to mechanisms borrowed from better games in what I'm convinced is Lee and Thompson's cruel experiment on D&D fans. I don't know if the fact that they designed this really speaks to some Great New Dawn of hybridized board gaming, or if it just goes to show how easily a few Euro mechanisms can be pulled from the shelf, dusted off, painted with bright fantasy colors, and tossed together to make a game.. It isn't broken or badly designed - it's just such a proud non-entity (which is nevertheless in my collection as it has bewitched many of my comrades into believing it somehow rises above other Euro games) that I find it infuriating on principle. And I am ashamed to say that I have good fun when I play it...

RATING: 8
Update: Rating lowered after a second 2 player game. The game seems to scale well, as you get more actions with less players and each building can only hold 1 "worker", so you are still blocked in your actions as if there were more players. But this game is so simplistic its sickening. Obvious choices combined with 5th grade level gameplay = boring. Wizards of the Coast are slapping Eurogamers in the face with this game. "Let's make a euro game! Generic cubes and meaningless gameplay, that's what those cube-pushers like, right?". Avoid at all costs.

Rating after one play. 

Lords of Waterdeep is your basic worker movement game. It is easy to explain, easy to get started, and easy to play. 

Each player is dealt a "Lord" in the beginning of the game that guides each player's strategy, to some extent, by giving bonus points for completing certain kinds of quests. I only looked at this card once, then kept it face down under my player mat...er...I mean my "Tavern". While I like having a secret goal to go for, thematically it did nothing for me. I don't even know which Lord I was. 

For the first 4 turns each player has 2 actions, and 3 actions for the remaining 4 turns, which consists of placing a very thematical meeple pawn on one of the buildings on the map. Buildings do very simple actions like "Take 2 Orange Cubes" (Warriors), "Take 1 White Cube" (Cleric), "Play 1 Intrigue Card", or "Take 1 Quest Card". After you take an action you have the option of completing a Quest, which you have face up beside your Tavern. Completing a Quest is a simple as discarding whatever it is the Quest card calls for, such as 4 orange cubes and 4 gold, or 6 purple cubes (Magicians). Quests give you points and possibly cubes and/or money. The usual stuff. Quests also have 1 of 5 categories which your Lord will give you extra points for at the end of the game for completing. I guess what you need to discard is connected to what kind of Quest it is, i.e discard warriors for a combat quest. Didn't really matter or grab me in any way though.

Also the map sucks.

I would play it again though, if with non-gamers or girlfriends or whatnot, but if anything else is available...yeah, no.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Looks complex, but is surprisingly simple. Players always seem deterred at the explanation phase, but immediately demand to play again by the time we finish.

RATING: 6
I like D&D, but the more 'Wonderful World of Dungeons and Dragons' the theming gets, the more my toes curl. Waterdeep really takes the biscuit in that regard. This game would be so much more tolerable with even just a generic fantasy theming, if a more interesting theme or background couldn't be found. 

Anyhow, as a WP euro, its OK - it clearly rewards players who know the cards better (as do plenty of games, but there's something that feels very arbitrary about that here), but it's OK. I think in general, if I am going to play a Euro, I want it to be a really good euro, or else really quick. 

Impressive but weird production values. The success does kind of surprise me, but it is well-earned for the effort that has gone into this.

RATING: 7
After my first play I was a bit underwhelmed. The theme is really really pasted on, I can't imagine anyone feeling like sending out adventurers instead of just gaining some colored cubes. There was very little interaction between players. Meh. On my second play, however, things went a little better, so I raised my rating from 5 to 7. Maybe we had a few more interactive intrigues, maybe the players were more fun or in a better mood, I don't know. Or maybe it was because this time around we had tiny meeples instead of cubes to push around (my friend's game had been "pimped" in the meantime). 

I still prefer Sons of Anarchy for my worker-placement fix, since the theme is much stronger, as is the player interaction (added battles and negotiation). And I don't even like the show, and this is probably also something that pushes most people away from the game. I almost never get it to the table (some don't like "games with photos", some aren't interested in the show, some may find it too violent). 

Lords of Waterdeep is at least a nice enough worker-placement game that my friends are actually willing to play.

RATING: 8
- 1 Promo Karte
- 1. Erweiterung
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A very smooth worker placement game where options expand greatly throughout the eight rounds of the game. Everything is very easy to follow and explain and the flavour is provided through the artwork and presentation.

The gameplay however could be be perceived as a rather soulless cube accumulation and cube currency game. How strong your perception of this might be will depend on the distribution of the buildings. Cube generation buildings are rather dull if too many come out, especially early in the game. The buildings that make the game interesting are the ones that allow you to perform interesting actions, like copy the action of an opponent's agent, or trade two cubes for any three. I'd have liked to see more of such buildings in the game rather than run the risk that the game is swamped with cube generation buildings. Buildings that alter the rules I find to be far more interesting.

Quests also provide some variation, but not enough. There are different classes you might be aiming for (to achieve a victory point end of game bonus), but it's the ones that provide a permanent effect that are the more interesting. There's not enough of these and their permanent effects are not interesting enough. To keep the game simple and smooth flowing  you wouldn't want them all to have permanent effects, but again, ones that change the rules or give your opponents a bonus are more interesting than straight out cube and coin swaps for victory points.

Intrigue cards provide an extra layer of player interaction. They are nicely weighted in that they don't hit your opponents so much that they destroy their game. Yes, mandatory quests can really mess another player if played right near the end of the game, but this is the right level of interaction as players should make contingency plans expecting to be messed with. (I enjoy a drop or two of player added chaos, but this might not be to everyones taste.) I'd have liked to see more variation and no card duplicates. They're a nice gamble element when deciding if you want to pick one up over something else. The method in which they're played being limited and giving that agent a second use afterwards is very elegant.

A fine effort that could be played with gamers and non gamers alike. Simple rules (don't let the size of the rulebook fool you), reasonably quick playing time, good interaction, nice bits. Rather engrossing and enjoyable, but could have been tweaked to make it into less of a cube pusher for victory points game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
Worker placement in its most basic form. The typical Euro of getting cubes and money to exchange for victory points. It would be nice to have miniatures instead.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.75
Excellent light-medium worker placement game.  The variable "Lord of Waterdeep" end game scoring was interesting without being all important. You definitely don't need to have intimate knowledge of various cards to win.  And while I love Agricola's mechanism of adding more workers for more actions, I appreciate this game's (relatively) fixed number of workers throughout the game.  An excellent game all around, with interesting choices that can be played with any group.

5/16/12 - while the game scales very well from 2-5 players, I find that I enjoy the 4 or 5 player version better as it makes the game tighter and seems to force a little more use of other's buildings.

RATING: 10


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Purchased at May '12 Atlanta Game Fest. Players organize D&D-like adventures by finding quests at the Cliffwatch Inn, recruiting rogues, fighters, wizards and clerics from various locations in Waterdeep, and completing your quests for victory points. This is a short and fast worker-placement game. Theoretically this game should be playable in under an hour but I haven't seen it yet. It's not a terribly deep game, but there's some good variety to opportunities. These opportunities include acquiring/playing intrigue cards and constructing/using buildings (which are extra locations for people to place workers). Several nice mechanics here, although, as I've said, it's not terribly deep.

The theme doesn't come across as strongly as it could - often, we'd forget that those were actually supposed to be adventurers, but they could have been goods used to fulfill contracts.  They did a good job.  The art is wonderful.  The mandatory quests might be a bit over-powered, especially if you get stuck with a couple and others don't get any, but it's still an enjoyable experience.  I wish there was more incentive to build buildings, but it was a good time.

RATING: 8
Upgrading this to an "8" after my fourth play.  This is a great, simple game that shines with 3-5 players.  It can be explained in 10 min, and is thematic enough to give players a sense of purpose in the game.  The variety in buildings is great, making every game slightly different.  Looking forward to buying/incorporating the expansion.

This, like Fresco, is one of my current go-to gateway games.  I'll pick Fresco if there are more women in the group, Lords if there are more men.

Boosting to an 8.5.  Every time I play it, I like it more and more.  It's so simple, yet so entertaining and it's NEVER failed me on game night.  People love it.  The only downside is that 5 player games can take a long time.

8-20-17:
Downgrading back to 8.  While people always seem to enjoy this game, there's so little "strategy" to it, and the winner in some ways might as well be randomly determined.

RATING: 8
Lords of Waterdeep -- Played three- and four-player.

Four-player felt too hurried to really accomplish much.  (Only two workers per turn for the first half, then three.)

Three-player was more satisfying.  (Three workers per turn for the first half, then four.)

At three, this rates [u]very[/u] high on my list of worker placement games.  I'm hoping an expansion will improve the game with more players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
It's Ticket to Ride of worker placement genre. Easy, accessible, varied and with a little splash of theme that makes all the difference, even if it's as thin as it is. Atmosphere kinda works (not in the immersive way, but in "it's neat" way. What makes the game and what LoW brings to the WP genre is huge variety for such a light game. Tons of quests, intrigue cards and a lot of special buildings means that this game is as much of a ride as possible while being a WP (there's little optimisation and understanding of the system, as there's no system, nor actual engines). It definitely succeeds in what it wants to achieve and I'll see if it has any staying power with me (not fond of WP genre). The game is way way better for a family type game than Stone Age - better theme, more ride, less thinky.  

Graphic design is top - evocative and functional. Though I wish icons on quest cards would be easier to see across the table. 

Second game: Now I've won, but. The game took forever and shown problems of WP games - they are linear. You need to do A to do B to achieve C. Of course you also need 3 other plans if the first one wont go through. So you put an AP person somewhere in this chain and it will be a pain. This one needs a group that takes this a light, simple game, not a challenging one. 

EDIT: I think I started with this game around 7.0 rating and now it's way way down. I still think this game is as good as I thought initially. One of best worker placement, the most accessible one, for sure. I just am fed up with tolerating this genre. It's incredibly dumb and boring.

RATING: 8
Theme adds nice to the game color, but nothing at all to the game play. It's a worker placement / set collection / mission fulfillment game, and it's good.

However, it's easy to gang up on a player and completely screw him, which is frustrating. The attacks are just too powerful. These can be mitigated by a) allowing "forced" missions to be completed together with real ones, and b) opening a resource market that allows people to buy cubes that they're missing. Or just take out the forced missions; seems to solve the problem, which is what I did and I'm perfectly happy about it.

RATING: 8
A friendly version of the multiple-options style games like Hansa Teutonica. It does have opportunities for interaction/interference too, but basically is a classic worker placement game with extras thrown in. I really like it.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.25
#36 on my Top 100 Games of All Time (2015)

This game is fun, easy to understand, and plays in about an hour. I've heard many people refer to this game as a "Caylus-Lite", and I would agree. They have extremely similar mechanics. This one doesn't have the same strategic depth, but is more forgiving of new players and more fun, IMO.
It's suppose to have a D&D theme, but that just feels pasted on to me. I usually just refer to the cubes by their color and not their character, but it's the mechanics that draw me into a game, not the theme. If theme is your thing, you could probably get into this game even more.

Acquired: February 2013 - CSI

RATING: 5
This is a fairly basic, straight-forward worker placement game: place worker, get resources, convert resources to points; break the rules from time to time with special cards.  That's about it.  There is nothing new or novel here, but it's a good introductory worker-placement game.  The theme may appeal to some, but it's not really well-applied within the game.  I'll play this game when it comes up in the rotation, but there are so many other worker-placement games that I'd rather play...

RATING: 9
A very fun very quick worker placement game.  The game balances enough tension for the best position but never leaves a player without an option to place where he/she can gain some benefit.  A game that brings fun forward and easy enough to introduce new players to worker placement and also a nice way to finish a heavy gaming session where there is enough time for a non filler game but you don't want something real heavy.  Add in the D&Deeples and the theme takes effect as people stop referring to things as cubes and say wizard, rogue, fighter, and cleric.  This game verges on great.
----------------------------------------------------------Jan 2017 - I was wrong this game doesnt verge on great it is great.  If you want o get any D&D fan or Lord of the rings fan into euro games this is how you do it.

RATING: 8
While I own this and the Scoundrels expansion, I haven't managed to get people around the table to play it yet. The IOS version is great for solo play though and worth taking a look at if you're curious and can't guarantee players.

EDIT Jan '17 - Finally managed to get it on the table and it absolutely delivered. Very easy to teach and simple for new players to pick up and enjoy. Lots of fun and competitive without that being off-putting. Just a great game all round.

RATING: 7.5
This one is fun. It's a worker-placement Euro, but the D&D theme makes it feel like I'm 18 again, throwing dice all night long (without the sleep deprivation that comes with throwing dice all night long). Some people say the theme is pasted on, but I'm starting to take issue with that complaint when it comes to worker-placement games. Just about any theme is a valid choice, when placing workers who subsequently do something for you is concerned. In this game, it's building parties to complete quests. I think it works well!

RATING: 2
All style and no substance. Takes mechanics from much better games and melds them together into a sword-wielding, brain-dead, luckfest of an abomination. Too few meaningful decisions to be called a euro, and too dull to be Ameritrash. It's a horrible, horrible game.

RATING: 9
The amount of stuff in this game can be a bit overwhelming at first, but it's a quite easy worker placement game with plenty of options and strategies for accruing a winning number of points. 

The mechanics work, regardless of thematic considerations and the game has been popular with people who have no idea what Waterdeep is, or anything about the lore.  

Certainly best around the 3-4 range, but perfectly serviceable at 2, and for some extra time at 5.

RATING: 8
On the surface, Lords of Waterdeep looks like a sprawling RPG-esque board game. In reality, it is quite a basic worker-placement game that doesn't fully utilize its theme. However, I still think this is one of the best introductory "Euro-style" board games on the market. It's quite simple to understand and the theme doesn't get in the way of those that might find the game too "nerdy." The production is basic, but good (especially the insert) and overall it's just a great game. It's unfortunate that Wizards doesn't have as much faith in it as I do.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.9
Played this once and loved the feeling while playing it. The various options available on the board for the most part felt like they would all give you some real benefit but there was always a question of what your overall strategy was and how that would influence your decision based on which actions were in your best interest.  Trust me - it was much more engaging than my description !

RATING: 6

There is still not enough interaction, and its all about exchanging those cubes for VPs like in so many other games (we played with the small DnDeeples, but we still kept referring to them as the purple, white, black and orange thingies/cubes).   That is not FUN!

That being said, the game is still on my wishlist, because it's short, light, and maybe the best game for introducing new players to WP games.

RATING: 10
Family favorite. Some known combinations are automatic wins, but the game is balanced enough for you to be able to win no matter your goals or methods, as long as you manage your resources well. Occasionally, the combination of poor luck of the draw for buildings, quests, and intrigue cards simultaneously will cause significant stagnation in a game, and correspondingly low scores.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A tidy, taut, confusion-free worker placement game.  Not too challenging, but still a fun experience.  I especially like the graphic design and artwork, which is very clean and elegant.  Very nice components.   People will balk at the thin cards but I don't have a problem with them.  The game comes with a nicely designed insert that actually accommodates the game's components in a highly organized fashion.  All in all, I am impressed with this production.  Repeated plays have inspired me to increase my personal rating from a 7 to 8.

RATING: 7.5
Complexity: Medium
Players: 2-5
Expansions Owned:  Scoundrels of Skullport

D&D-themed Euro game.  I like Lords of Waterdeep - it has this sense of elegant simplicity about it.  Place meeples, obtain cubes, get victory points.  There's not really any major economic engine to master, but some might consider that a plus.  Good intro into a more thinky type of game.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is a great worker placement game set in the D&D world.  The components are top notch - the box is designed to hold everything very well.

While it seems pretty lightweight at first there are some subtle strategies that definitely increase your chances of winning - like knowing when to play intrigue cards versus buying a building versus just gathering adventurers to complete a quest.

All in all, a game with a fair amount of replay value.  Lots of fun for 2 to 4 people - not one I'd recommend for 5 though as it can quickly get frustrating with 5.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A great worker placement gateway, but it's not nearly as clever and interesting as it could be. 

The secret player roles don't add anything, because they're all just the same "collect these two types of quest" (except the builder character, which is obvious to everyone by Turn 2), when they could have offered differential powers and meaningful specialized goals that meaningfully affected gameplay. The faction backstories have nothing to do with anything, but they could have offered rivalries and the pursuit of goals the other players sought to oppose. Once you "claim" a quest, nobody else can send an adventuring party on it, which thematically makes zero sense, and misses opportunities for my adventuring party to try to beat up your adventuring party. Quests trigger instantly and automatically when the right combination of cubes is assembled, but those cubes are then lost and few if any lasting effects come about, but there could have been a mechanism to resolve the degree of success or failure on a quest, or a way for "your" hired adventurers to gain experience and become more powerful, or for this quest to give you artefacts or clues that unlocked the next quest or gave your adventurers better abilities. There's no arc or narrative, in a game that pretends to be meaningfully linked to a D&D campaign world with 30 years of backstory. 

Overall, Waterdeep is not as good as Stone Age, which is a real shame, because it could so easily have been so much more.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 4
There's certainly nothing new here. It's a generic worker placement game, of which the world probably didn't need yet another. Still, for an introduction to the genre, it's okay. RATING: 6
3 4
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Played it and didn't care for it. Randomness is good in games so long as it plays a purpose (usually to keep the game fresh and ensure no "guaranteed" strategy ever arises). It feels like the randomness in the game just overwhelms the impact of player choice. Your lord of waterdeep is random, your building selection is random, your quest availability is random. You get nailed with "take that" cards, the worst of which are the mandatory quests. These can serve to further disadvantage players attempting to catch up to a leader. The game also scales VERY poorly to more players, as the supply of cube-generators only increases insoumch as players buy more of the random buildings. 

I was concerned that perhaps my playthrough was not representative of the game in general, but was informed promptly by fans of the game that it wasn't that unusual and that the game simply wasn't for me. So I suppose if you like choosing specific people to screw over Ameritrash-style, games that don't scale well at all to the number of people playing, the ability for runaway winners to sabotage people attempting to keep up, and too much randomness to meaningfully interact with, this is the game for you. Otherwise, if you wanted a good worker placement/role selection game, I'd point you to Agricola or Puerto Rico or countless other fun games that do it better.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Another great introduction to worker placement for new players. Can be made more accessible to serious gamers with the addition of Skullport.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
1 play, 3er

A nice, simple worker placement game with a very very pasted on D&D theme. Nothing new here, but it takes a few mechanisms from some games and puts them together into a solid, quick-playing game!

You are apparently using your henchmen to build and use various town buildings in order to put together parties of fighters, wizards, clerics, and thieves to send on quests which earn you glory or reputation. Or something like that, anyway. Really, you're placing workers in various locations, most of which give you cubes or cards. You spend various cube combinations to complete mission cards, earning you VP (and/or money or some other special bonus). 

Despite the lack of theme, though, the game works quite well. It's not as deep as many other worker placement games, and those mandatory quests are pretty darn annoying, but the game was still a lot of fun to play!

--- Summary ---
- 9 rounds per game. Players start with x workers (varies with player number), and get 1 more at turn 5. Also, each player gets one end-game bonus card (bonus VP for specific in-game actions, e.g. building a bunch of buildings, or completing quests of a specific type, etc.)
- there are 3 available buildings on display in the builder's area
- the board has several predetermined locations where you can:
... get some combination of: cubes (white, black, orange, or purple); quest cards (complete for VP/other rewards); intrigue cards (action cards, various effects on you and other players); money
... build one of the buildings: place it on the board with your ownership marker; it becomes a new location where workers may be placed (building owner earns a small bonus when another player uses the building); immediately add a new building to the builder's area
... become first player next round (turns then go clockwise)
... play an intrigue card

Game flow:
- at the start of each turn, add a VP chit to each building in the builder's area 
- in turn order, place a single worker on a location (pre-printed, or a built building) and immediately take that action; after each action, may complete ONE quest
- after players have taken all their actions, the workers in the 3 intrigue spots move their worker, in the order placed, to a new location and take that action

Most VP after 9 rounds, including end-game bonus cards, wins!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
My next favorite worker placement game behind Agricola.  It has a lot going for it.  Different quest, Intrigue card, and building effects to give the game variety.  Perfect length to give the game a sense of urgency.  And a great theme to boot (albeit kinda "pasted on").  It doesn't have the variety and depth that Agricola does but this is still a great game and it is the perfect introduction into the worker placement genre for less experienced players.

I do have a problem with some of the balance of the game though.  Despite what anybody tells you the builder lord (who gives you +6 VP for every building at game end) is overpowered.  I also wonder about the pricing of some of the buildings.  Aside from that this is a well-made thematic game.

RATING: 6.5
A worker placement game wearing a dungeons and dragons coat: the perfect game for my husband, the D&D Player, and me, the Euro Gamer (btw, he likes Euros, too, which helps). Played with two this was fun, the theme is not very immerse but gives the game a great look. I am curious to see how the dynamics change with different player numbers since you will have fewer agents to deploy while playing the same number of rounds. My hunch right now is that the max of 5 might be pushing it...
Played now with 3 and I have even more doubts it would be good with 5. Additionally, I have to say while I like the game it is lacking a little something to make it truly great, it lost a star point from after the last gaming session and is down to 6.5 now (which is still decent).

RATING: 5
The one thing that struck me the most is that the theme, for something as rich in flavor as D&D is, is really just tacked on. Normally I wouldn't give two shits, but there seemed to be wasted opportunities there.

That being said, it was enjoyable. For some reason, a 5 player game didn't seem that cutthroat, but I also had the advantage of that one quest that let you double up on a square, so I didn't really care if people "blocked" me, and it was everyone's first game, so the passive aggressive blocking inherent to such games wasn't really part of anyone's strategy. I think there's also the case where everyone has certain biases as a result of their Lord, so the guy who wants Warfare and Commerce quests probably won't rub up against the guy who wants Arcana and Skullduggery quests or whatever. As a result I noticed that people were biasing pretty heavily towards a certain type of quest and thus the resources for that, especially if they got an early quest that gave them more VPs for that kind of quest, so there's overall less competition for certain resources. I, for instance, got Khelben Blackstaff, who favors Warfare and Arcana quests, and as a result, very rarely needed money or clerics. I would need such resources on occasion, but for the most part, it was mostly a non-concern for me if someone else took the building before me.

RATING: 6
As worker placement games go, this one is fairly light, and it rarely felt like resources were so tight that I needed to go on exact spaces in order to achieve my ends.  This resulted in very little player blocking, which, depending on what your gameplay style is, could be a positive.  This is what I would consider a gateway game, and although the theme is somewhat pasted on, the additional flavor text on the cards definitely adds to the feel of the game.  However, I would have liked to see more variation in the objectives of the Lords.  That being said, as there are limited numbers of things that can be achieved, I don't see any way of providing more variability in objectives.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This game is nearly as good as the hype.  There is a bit too much luck which cannot be mitigated to score higher than an 7 with us, but the brilliantly tight theme knocks it a full point upward to a solid 8.  Just make sure you call the cubes by their class name and not just "orange," "black," etc.  As such this is the first truly crossover game I've seen that bridges Ameritrash, RPG and Euro.  The components are pretty good, but the one thing it's lacking which would truly bring it up to an 8.5 is miniatures--if the game had included small 10mm scale figures of each class, rather than euro-cubes, the overall feel of gameplay would actually further improve.

the fundamental gameplay is worker placement, with a goal to run a changing "engine" based on quest cards.  There's a bit of take-that involved in the Intrigue cards (which also will work to slow a leader, and they are easy for the other players to work thusly since it does not slow their quest-development much at all).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
This game tries to bring both the Euro and Ameritrash paradigm to the table. The result is a highly interactive worker placement game that fills a niche.

Unfortunately, it is really not my cup of tea. No manner how well you planned your turn/game anybody can come in and break your plan. When it's your turn to stop/help an opponent, it's very to gauge who's leading/trailing without reading everybody's tinny printed active and plot quest that I would basically just pick someone at random. Add to that turns that only gets longer as the game progress and a useless bugged last turn and you have me quite turned off.

This would need to be a lot shorter for me to work. Take that mechanic and strategy don't mix too well over long play time.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A good effort from a publisher not known for games of this sort. Dungeons and Dragons... worker-placement?!

Unfortunately, there is nothing original here, and nothing to set it apart from other resource-conversion euros except for unnecessary randomness and direct screwage -- its nominal theme is so poorly reflected in the mechanisms that it might as well be about fulfilling orders for bouquets composed of different colours of flower cube. The saddest thing is actually that it's [i]so[/i] generic a euro: it would have been more interesting had the buildings and cards been wildly different, but most of them are different flavours of tedious cube acquisition and conversion.

There is more luck involved than many worker placement games; having the right quests turn up at the right time can be extremely advantageous. The intrigue cards, which provide opportunities for one-off bonuses and direct attacks on other players, are likewise not created equal: you will feel cheated when you waste an action to collect a bad one.

Don't get me wrong: it's a good game. It's not particularly original or particularly interesting, but it plays quickly, flows very well, and the buildings and quests add variety. It is easy to both learn and teach. If for some reason I had to choose a light, inconsequential worker placement game that I could get done in 75 minutes, this would be high on the shortlist. (But why would I ever want to do that?)

RATING: 10
I always enjoy this game.  I have the physical game and the iOS version on my iPad.  I have probably played close to 500 games of this on iOS and I STILL enjoy playing it.  Part of the reason is the theme.  I like the D&D theme, the artwork, and flavor text on the mission cards and intrigue cards.  I realize this is just a veneer for a basic worker placement/euro type of game but it is still pleasing to me.  My favorite part is how there is strategy and tactics embedded in this game.  You should pay attention to what other people are trying to do and occasionally stall them some.  I also like how some of the missions provide lasting benefits for the rest of the game.  This makes choosing which missions to invest your limited actions into very important.  Add in the buildings which provide benefits to the owner and you have a very interesting, but not overly complicated, game with thoughtful choices. I sure prefer this game to Stone Age which I found to be extremely dry and boring.

RATING: 5.5
Quick and fast worker placement game that is fairly decent. The primary issue I have with the game is the sheer randomness of the quests. Some quests give lasting powers that can result in a completely lopsided match if someone starts with them. Outside of that it is fairly decent, just wish the game was longer by a turn or two.

After playing it again I've come to the conclusion that early plot cards can determine the winner fairly easy. All the action spaces are fairly balanced so the deciding factor comes down to who can get the right plot cards that work with their lord. Having a synergy between the two just makes one person a run away leader. I'll play the game again, but I'm wondering how it would be without any plot cards at all...

EDIT: After house ruling it so that no Plot Quests can be given for your two starting quests and removing some Lords that are seen as overpowered, the game is much better. Combined with the expansion it is a decent game (7ish) overall. This is the rating for just the base game though which is forgettable in my eyes.

RATING: 5
A decent worker placement game offering a nice variety in terms of "quests" that give future bonuses and a variety of buildings to build for different effect. Rules aren't the best, but much better than most WotC games, and it all plays well.
Consider the rating a 7 if played without the mandatory quests (see below).

Two complaints: 1) The mandatory quests - these are awful. Too much random hosage, too mutually destructive. We've just been leaving them out. 2) The 'Lord' cards. Its not that I mind the idea of having victory bonuses; I like it. But why not an 'Agenda' or something? The only point I can see to making them "lord" cards was to get an extra dose of sexism into the game, which I suppose is to be expected from D&D, but which I still don't like.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Straightforward worker placement game that attempts to introduce Euro mechanisms to D&D fans. The aim is to complete quests by collecting adventurers (invariably represented by coloured wooden cubes) and gold from different buildings on the board. This is done by assigning your agents to the buildings. In most cases, once a building has been selected by an agent, no one else can select it for the rest of the turn. Originality is introduced in the way of intrigue cards, whereby you can make life more difficult for your opponents by taking resources off them or assigning them mandatory quests to slow them down. There's also a hidden objective aspect to the game involving the eponymous Lords of Waterdeep who reward extra victory points based on the types of quest a player completes. As a gateway to Euro-style games this works excellently, and there is strategic depth behind the simple gameplay, but beyond the theme and high production values 'LoW' doesn't really bring anything new to experienced players of worker placement games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Love it a lot! Theme D&D a bit unnecessary though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Laura's Rank (3/15) â 3.5 out of 5. Pros: Lots of strategy involved. The components are good quality. There is a lot to the game, but it is not an overly difficult game to learn. Cons: Not always going to want to play this because it is a little bit more mentally intense, so it's not really a conversational game.

Ryan's Rank (3/15) â 3.5 out of 5. I really like that there can be some good strategic gameplay. I wish the theme was a bit stronger because I like fantasy. I don't think I'm very good at this game, so that might affect my rating somewhat. As Laura said, it's simple to learn but has lots of good decisions. I think it would be better with more players, but still an enjoyable 2 player game.

Overall Rank (3/15) â 7.0 out of 10

RATING: 6.6

RATING: 7.5
This game really surprised me. It's a solid worker placement game that is quick to learn and easy to be competitive at. It's not extremely complex, but that's a strength, since I can play this with a group that might not want to play a heavier WP game. Apart from a couple of flaws (mandatory quests, I'm lookin' at you), this is a darned fun game that has just enough theme to please the fantasy/D&D fans, but not so much as to turn off those who don't know, or care, where Waterdeep is or who the Harpers are.

RATING: 8
Fun worker placement game. The quest cards and buildings add a good degree of randomness to spice things up. The game moves fairly quickly and gets more tense as the end approaches (there are only 8 rounds to play). It plays in about 1 hour or so, making it easy to bring out. 
   However, it feels like it lacks enough depth and strategy to make it last. An expansion will be coming out that will hopefully add enough depth and variety (and a 6th player)to rectify this. Also, the D&D theme is neat, but fades away once you get playing. That's too bad, and I wish there were a way to evoke the theme more.

RATING: N/A
#Players: 2-6 (Expansion)
Time: 60 mins
Mechanic: Resource Management, Board Management

Become a shadowy lord attempting to seize influence in Waterdeep. Send your agents to buildings to hire troops, earn money, or perform intrigue actions. Complete quests for additional resources or points. After several rounds the game will end and the player with the most points wins.

I have the expansion for this which adds corruption and a 6th player.

RATING: 9
An easy to get into worker placement game which scales extremely well from 2 to 5 players. We don't really know anything about the D&D universe but we still enjoyed it really much, although, the theme is admittedly paper thin. The abundance of quests and intrigue cards, the several buildings and the hidden goals you get in the beginning of the game make up for a huge variability. We just find ourselves getting back to Lords of Waterdeep over and over again - and if it is not what describes a great game I don't know what is.

RATING: 6
Neat enough, nothing special. Mandatory quests are a weak mechanic: they waste the card-player's tempo; they codify kingmaking; and they arbitrarily limit the card-target's decision space. And that isn't the only mechanic that seems sloppy. I mean, would you ever play without "Open Lord" if given the choice? Balance isn't begotten from the happenstance of failing to draw a given card.

RATING: 7
Enjoyable. About the level of theme as Pillars of the Earth: all the spaces have themed names, but that's about it. I think I would have felt more engaged if the cubes were meeples and the odd meeples were anything else.

Maybe a bit on the high-randomness end. A bit of Caylus, a touch of Stone Age, but all in all it seems a competent design; and I'm not inclined to cut WotC any slack. Getting the 6 point per building lord with the 4 point per building power is probably broken.

Has a lot of stomp-the-apparent-leader, and an interesting delayed effect playing intrigue cards.

2-5? I've played 3 and 5. I don't think 5 is bad, just different. Tighter.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Everything, absolutely everything about this product is solid.  It's VERY easy to teach, it plays out of the box, theres next to no set up time.  The components are excellent quality, the artwork is fantastic and the insert... innovative, functional and genius.  I love worker placement games, this might be the best one yet.  The Dungeons and Dragons theme actually blends seemlessly with the gameplay making for a delightful experience.  While it lacks some of the things I love from other titles, this has CONSIDERABLY less play time.  After 2 games of it you can blast through a full game in well under an hour.  Its highly replayable as well do to the questing system (which keeps you constantly engaged throughout the entire game).  Shockingly it plays well with 2 players as well as groups.  I can't give this enough praise... the only draw back I see is that theres not an expansion to add some new mechanics (like unique player abilities for the houses) and some stuff for more serious gamers.  Perfection.  

People who don't like this one or consider it a basic worker placement game are missing the point entirely.  This is a light but serious euro game... you can get anyone to play... with no set up time... out of the box in under an hour... with a theme that doesn't feel tacked on.

It's much better than any Dungeons and Dragons board game has any right being.

RATING: N/A
An easy to learn, well organized game with deep strategy and agonizing decisions.

Lords of Waterdeep draws on worker placement and resource management mechanics that experienced gamers will be familiar with, but the real strategy in the game involves managing your priorities. 

Waterdeep calls for a delicate balance of playing boldly for immediate benefits and setting yourself up for long chain reactions that can change the dynamic of the game in your favor.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Daniele
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
Clearance at B&N

I would play this game anytime. I am sort of split on the expansions.

Yes, it basically is a block pusher. But the theme is as good as you could get for a block pusher. A "behind the scenes" D&D theme is really fun. Collect the necessary people/cash to complete missions. Secret bonuses, worker placement are key. The construction of new building with new abilities and owner rewards makes this game shine.

I do like the expansions and the addition of corruption is starting to grow on me.

Love the insert...hate the box.

RATING: 8
I've played some somewhat rushed lunchtime games (which really just ended up being teasers and made me get my own copy), and a couple of times at home for a full game.  I do really like it, although I tend to want to be too nice with Intrigue cards.  My husband likes it too, and we've even managed a 6-player game with the expansion.  2 players is quite a different game from, say, 4 (and 6 is crazy long! but we were taking our time and having fun).  With more, it creates more pressure in getting to the buildings one really needs, and player order starts to really count.  It's great to have such a different experience with the same game.

RATING: 8
Extremely good well thought out game. Congrats to WotC for making more of their licence and R&D budget. Basic elements of Caylus but far less dry with varied goals to pursue. An element of hidden role adds strategy plus a small amount of screwage but this is a small feature of the game for those usually put off by that.
However its big win is that a for medium complexity game it is only an hour yet it is such great fun to play. It's only April but I suspect that this will be my game of the year. Outstanding.
Oh also tremendously good value. I would normally expect this to be Â£10 more and I might have swerved it at that price.
Hmmm after a few more plays I've reduced my rating from 9 to 8. It is a very cleverly implemented game with great theme, but it just seems a little too dry without that spark that truly great games have. Maybe I need the expansion!

RATING: 5
A game that clearly was one of the first of its kind, due to the high rank but pretty tedious and uninteresting gameplay. Lords of Waterdeep is the most vanilla and unengaging worker placement game I've played. It's still functional, but the take-that mechanics, boring actions to take, and repetitious actions, not to mention the potentially game-crippling hidden role cards, make this game alright, and fine in app form, but not a game I would ever purchase physically.

RATING: 7
Lords of Waterdeep has been described as a very light Caylus and the description is accurate.  Worker placement and cube conversion as gaming mechanisms have run their course, and despite a valiant effort to provide a rich theme, this title is bland.  The very strong build space is nearly always picked first, making initial turn order critical.  Lords of Waterdeep is lighter than Caylus, much easier to get to the table, and much less satisfying.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I do like:
 - it is easy to start with not experienced players due to simple and straight-forward rules
 - well scaling game, no need in a "dummy" player for 2 players game
 - both direct and indirect player interaction due to intrigue cards, mandatory quests and building ownership bonus
 - you can't do anything really wrong that will spoil you the rest of the game
 - building and quest variety provides plenty of replay

Things they could have done better:

- Faction leaders need more variety. Or maybe it would be better to give people more specific bonus for having that leader (get +1 warrior when taking warriors, etc).
- Lack of theme. The flavor text for quests cards matching types of adventurers/resources to gather seems being the only thing that reminds "you are in Waterdeep".
At least some more thematic meeples for adventurers instead of simple cubes are needed.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
First impression: I would never turn down a game of Lords of Waterdeep but I would never request it.  I'm glad I know people who own it but have no interest in getting a copy for myself.  There's nothing I don't like about it but there's nothing about it that I love.  It may only be one "wow factor" away from being a great game (perhaps that's forthcoming in the expansion?).  As is, it's engaging and very approachable, just not at all memorable.  

UPDATE 1: Like Pillars of the Earth, this one has a short shelf life -- it's had sharply diminishing returns after a positive first impression.  I was hoping it would be a system with some depth to be explored, but the depth is pretty much explored before the end of that first game.  It needs more drama, more intrigue, and more dynamism.  The Intrigue cards, Quests, Lords, and Buildings should provide variety but fail to adequately do so.  Hopefully the expansion helps in this regard.

There is also a complete disconnect between the theme and the game.  I'm not hiring thieves, clerics, wizards, and fighters; I'm collecting black, white, purple and orange cubes.  This makes the game feel much too dry of an exercise for something with the Dungeons & Dragons brand.

Positives that don't diminish with repeated plays are that it has a very good aesthetic (apart from the too-small VP icons on the Quest cards), games last as long as they should, and it's a very clean design.

UPDATE 2: I actually like the game more on the iPad.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
A bit too luck driven based on which cards turn up, but I have a soft spot for the original IP.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
To be honest - this is the first game I did not want to like. After all, evidence that this was a game with a pasted on them were too big. And I thought mixing a worker placement/resource management game with random Take that elements would not go well. Because usually the "Take that"-elements in such games results from how your opponents placed their workers. This placement can be crucial and screw your plans.

However, despite the totally pasted on theme, I found that this game is running smoothly and that the balance is maintained even with this double impact "Take that"-mechanic. It's fast with a lean rule set and quite enjoyable. It sure copies some here and there and has a feel of Le Havre - a game it doesn't stand a chance against - but overall it's a good design.

Chris
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
This game has a common but utterly fatal Achiles heel: The Winning Strategy. Certain Quests and Properties are just so overwhelming superior in their ratio of difficulty::Reward that a player who knows what they're doing knows to snatch it up immediately. From there, it's just a matter of who knows the game best, or how dumb luck breaks in terms of what quests/properties drop on whose turns if everyone knows what to look for. The worst part is it's not even THAT complicated... You'll know in and out how to win (and thus why you're losing if someone beats you to it) at all times by your 5th game or so. People really talk this game up, and I don't know if they're slow or the people they play with are or what, but it's just a source of grumbling and eye-rolling with people I play with. Bogus RNG: The Game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Worker-Placement Games

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I wish I liked this game more! In many ways it's good fun, and the way you compete for quests (i.e. projects on which to spend the resources your workers gain) as well as the resources themselves is good. However, it has a number of issues which prevent it getting a better rating from me.

1) Play time and turn time. The beauty of the worker-placement mechanic ought to be that it makes play smooth by reducing the number of decisions for a player. Place worker, resolve, start planning next move while everyone else takes theirs. Waterdeep really undermines this you have have a move which goes as follows;

- Place worker
- Decide which of your Intrigue cards to play
- Ask each other player whether they wish to take an opportunity offered to them by your Intrigue card
- Resolve a Quest which you are now able to resolve because of the benefits of the Intrigue card you played
- Choose an additional Quest from the menu

This means turns can end up much longer than you want.

2) Lack of theme
There is Dungeons & Dragons chrome slapped all over the game, no doubt about it - everything in the game has a generic fantasy-sounding name drawn from the glorious fantasy mishmash that is the official D&D multiverse.

However, there is nothing in the way the game plays that feels at all D&D. Once you've got the idea that you're collecting wood, grain, wool and wine rather than rogues, warriors, priests and wizards, there is nothing (apart from the slightly silly polysyllabic names for everything) to make you feel you're in the D&D world. 

3) Luck of the draw / secret roles.
Each player gets dealt a secret role at the start of the game giving them bonuses to certain sorts of quests. I don't hugely like this feature because it railroads you in one direction a bit too much and tends to diminish the amount of strategic depth.

What's more the selection of quests on offer is relatively limited, and the selection of buildings that produce more than the standard number of each resource (sorry, character class) is also fairly limited. So if you are lucky that the quests on offer to you fit the random role you have which fits your initial/early deal of quests which fits the buildings that are dealt, you have actually quite a big initial advantage. Too big an advantage, in my view, for the level of depth and investment in the game...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Really good introductory Worker Placement game. Pretty easy to teach to new people. I watched the TableTop episode, and discerned how to play this. I was able to teach the novices in my group, and one went on to then beat me. 

Make sure to reassure the new players that they will understand after a the first couple of rounds. There are quite a few pieces, and if they watch the setup it can look daunting. 

Another thing for the game, is the box it comes in. Not enough praise is given for the way the insert is designed to house the components. Everything has its spot, and is easy to get back out for the next play. It helps with the setup, but the teardown is just a bit more. It is worth it though. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Great game! Easy to teach, quick to play and it stays fun. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What I like:

This is really just a very well made medium/semi-light worker-placement game. It's balanced, good-looking, has some cool upgrades and I love that you get to build new actions for you and others to use (while you benefit from it). 
-Playing time hits a very nice sweet spot that other similar games usually are unable to get their games down to. 
-The added theme is just a bonus. It actually made me feel quite immersed despite just being a worker-placement game. 

What I dislike:
-The lords. Don't understand why they didn't make these more interesting. I guess having them all (almost) do the same makes for a more balanced experience, but a game of this weight and randomness can definitely allow itself to include some more variety in this regard. While we're at that, what's with the one odd-ball? The builder?? It's so weird that they decided to include just one who is different from the rest (and might be slightly better)
-Sometimes you might want something a bit more heavy
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This was one of my first worker placement games. The whole family enjoys it.
