RATING: 6
Facinating phenomenon. Not a bad game by a stretch, but consider me part of the crowd who does'nt understand the hype. 

Worker Placement for people who don't dig euro games too much. Pleasant way to pass the time, but only barely scratches the gamer-itch. Not enough control over the strategy to excuse the glued-on theme. Not enough fun to excuse the randomness.

The 6 is for the fact that my gaming group always can agree on this, a value not to be underestimated. Used to be a 7, but I feel little in control when playing this game. Seems to be fooling anyone else though.

People who say that this game is actually highly thematic are the same people who enjoy Michael Bay movies.

RATING: 8
Worker placement generates adventurers (warriors, rogues, clerics and mages). Specific combinations fulfill quests for which you get VP. Intrigue cards add a bit of randomness including some limited interaction. Simple rules yet a very fun game. There are a couple of missed opportunities that no doubt we will see if there are expansions: a) the 'Lord' cards (grant extra VP at end of game on condition) are all rather similar - only one awards points for something other than specific combinations of quests completed; b) the game booklet takes time to describe the different factions (colours players can choose) but they are all the same - how about making it so they all have different perks?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
For a while, I found this game too simplistic as a worker placement and with a silly pasted-on theme. Then, I got the expansion and the DnDeeples, and my enjoyment is growing and growing. It's about the perfect weight and play time for my medium-gaming family and many friend groups. The theme continues to be silly (hey, I love DnD but this cube-collecting exercise is nothing like DnD)...but you can take advantage of the sillyness and play it up. (Like the DnDeeples, as we now begin to anthropomorphize our cubes, calling them "guys" and being more invested in their use)

What is pushing this over the edge into a top game for me is the Skullport expansion. I love the added decisions with the corruption...how much can I take and still benefit? how much can I remove before the end? For me, this added mechanism is fabulous. For my wife, she is more meh on it. I was more meh on Undermountain, as it adds very little to decide upon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
Everything that is bad in the industry.

It is the most uninspired euro I ever saw, they played it safe to the highest degree, generic mechanics mangled in a generic game.

In a genial marketing scheme they forced a paper thin generic fantasy theme in and called the resource cubes warriors and clerics and so forth, that had resulted in the laughable perception by many that this game is super thematic, after all anything with a guy with a sword in the cover is.

To guarantee maximum appeal to the lowest common denominator they squeezed in some ridiculous munchkin style take that cards.

No meaningful decision is ever needed, all moves are patently obvious and the game is decided by luck and who people decide to attack. In 2 years the people who fall for this sort of scheme will have moved on to the next hotness and this mess will be forgotten.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I like this game and for me it could be on my top 10 if one detail doesn't exist. Unfortunately it has one thing that I really dislike: some intrigue cards are only useful to destroy one of the opponents game (they give an annoying quest to an opponent) and nonthing in return for the player.

RATING: 8
I played the iOS version quite a bit. I have the physical board game but haven't played it yet. It's really an odd game that mixes Euro-style worker placement gameplay in with the D&D Forgotten Realms world. Though I think the original intention was to get D&D people to buy a Euro-style boardgame, it actually is a great intro into both Eurogaming and the Forgotten Realms world. Some people may be turned off by the heavy fantasy theme but the production of the game is great. It has a beautiful game board map and artwork. Great game play that isn't too hard to pick up.

RATING: 6
The game works and requires a moderate level of planning.  Your secret victory condition is a random determinant of how you will focus your gameplay and if you get builder then the experience will be extremely monolithic.  The game capitalizes on the D&D reference without providing any connection to the adventure aspect that most people associate with the game.  In the end Lords of Waterdeep is a bland Ameritrash version of a Eurogame style that is implemented better in Alien Frontiers, Puerto Rico, and many Martin Wallace designs.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A decent game to serve as an introduction to worker placement but it gets stale quickly.

In my opinion, the shortcomings fall into several camps:

* Tacked on theme. This could certainly be said of many Euro games and worker placement in general, but I felt LoW was even worse than most. The theme is entirely superfluous and it basically feels like I'm just shuffling cubes around. Again, not unique to LoW but certainly still there.

*Very few bad moves. It just kind of feels like you'd be hard pressed to "screw up" your strategy. Bad moves are pretty obvious: don't stock up on 5 wizards when you don't need them for quests. But beyond that, sure. Just toss an agent on any available space. Collect shit. Convert it to VP.

*Very strict relative values for different resources. Basically, everything in the game is geared toward 2 black or orange being equal to 1 purple or white. In a way, it almost feels like all of the quests, buildings and intrigue cards are too balanced, to the point that you're just making moves of equal value in every turn. Seriously. It seems like well over half of the intrigue cards are "Take 2 cubes of ___ color and pick an opponent to take 1." I've played games where that's the only type of intrigue I get, which I find extremely boring.

*So little variation in the role cards. Basically, all but one are "Score +4 VP for these two quest types." A decent portion of the game comes comes down to the randomness of "do one or two people overlap with your quest types?" I don't think I've ever lost when I've had two quests all to myself. I get them easily and have less competition for the cube types that are most in demand for those quests.

I wanted to love this game. I really did. But I just don't.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Lords Of Waterdeep is a very straightforward worker placement game with beautiful components, a strong fantasy theme and some take that elements (the mandatory quest cards). Not yet sure whether that last aspect is a blessing or curse, but it certainly gives the game a unique ameritrash/euro hybrid feel. My first play was quite a relaxed and entertaining experience, but with two players it did not offer the level of suspense as, say, stone age (another family worker placement game). With three, the game was much better - easily up to par with other family level worker placement games.
UPDATE: My last two player game was great - filled with suspense and very interactive. We made a house rule to prevent receiving a second mandatory quest until you played one yourself.
UPDATE: When played with the expansion, this game is almost perfect. Raised my rating to a 9.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Remove all the chrome and this game is quite simple and at its core, this is a basic worker placement game with a D&D theme tacked on to it. Players allocate agents over various landmarks around the City of Waterdeep to collect resources which they will then cash in for victory points by fulfilling different objectives. Place workers, get cubes, spend cubes, get VP. Sounds familiar? Still, the game does what it was designed to do well. It is a great introductory game for the worker placement mechanic along the lines of Stone Age. The only drawback is that players not steeped in D&D terminology and lore won't get all the references and it is tough to see how collecting cubes could "save the Harpers from imminent death and destruction". That said, you could play this game entirely ignoring the flavor text and just focus on the icons of cubes and colors. I enjoy the game as a casual player, while simultaneously wishing it could be a little more advanced. 

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

the design quality is awesome,the price is good and that's all..!

RATING: 6
The gameplay is more engaging than Stone Age, but the theme is just . . . not . . . there.  I'll gladly play LoW, but I believe that interest will lessen once I've had a chance to finally play games such as Agricola.  So far it seems really over hyped.  If it remains to climb in the ratings (it's currently well within the top 50) then I would say that was definitive proof of how inaccurate BGG's ratings are.  The game is so detached from its theme its ridiculous.  This is in part due to the idea of "recruitment" instead of resources.  When you play a typical worker placement game you're getting something like wood, brick or stone.  In this game you're recruiting "wizards" etc.  They're cubes!  

I find this to be a stimulating game for 4p and 5p and I would never turn it down at those player counts.  But at 2p there are simply better games such as Agricola All Creatures Big and Small.  Throw in the utter detachment from its theme and to me that says the game does not warrant its rating.  This one, while good, is over hyped.  Period.

Because of that I have to lower my rating.  I just can't contribute to the warped ranking here on BGG.

RATING: 5
This didn't grab me either.  The game just seemed to be more worker placement but in a lighter game.  The new job buildings came up randomly, the quests were pretty random, there was a bit of screwage, nothing really stood out.  Troyes does everything this does but better (my jury is still out on the super combos).

Sadly, the theme was pasted on and the game felt like collecting four colors of cubes and selling different patterns off for points.  The lousy Harpers took a day off and had me deal with the Zents.

I think this game would be improved by some sort of team play via a group defence mechanism, like Troyes or The Republic of Rome.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I don't like take-that which can be targeted at a specific player versus the whole table. Sure, it is a viable design choice used to rein in the leader(s) but too often it gets employed as tit-for-tat as opposed to targeted for optimal play and that never fails to depress me. Of course, a devil's advocate would point out this is a problem with the players, not the game. But when it happens, I find the experience just ruins the gaming fun for me, so I'd rather not play games where the potential exists. (Further, with the secret goals, it just targets the perceived leader and so adds nothing to balance.)

Lastly, while I love worker placement, the variance in the Intrigue cards really mitigates what I love in worker placement: brutal-no-wiggle-room strategy+tactics.

RATING: 5.5
Take a halfway decent but completely standard themeless worker placement game and throw in a bunch of player-targeted effects and you have Waterdeep.  I enjoy worker placement so I still like the basic gameplay, but it's extremely basic and brings nothing worthwhile to the genre.  The individual player bonuses isn't so much an interesting difference as it is a way to force you to only go for certain quests (the bonus is simply too great to ignore it much if at all).

It's strictly better if you remove the Mandatory Quest cards and I strongly recommend it.

RATING: 8
Oct 2017: 
Rating -2 (to 8 from 10).  Still a good game, still a great gateway.  However, as we've moved on to some mid-weight WP (Coal Baron and Yedo), this has lost some of its appeal.  We bought but don't really use/enjoy the expansion (other than allowing an extra player).  The base game plays just fine without and works better as a gateway/intro to WP without.  If we want something meatier, we reach for another game that has a stronger theme and more interesting mechanics.

Original (Jan 2017):
My new favorite game!  I wanted to try a "true" worker placement after enjoying Via Nebula.  Wavered between this and Champions of Midgard, which some say has replaced this.  So glad I went with Lords of Waterdeep because this has instantly become a favorite for me and others I play with.  The rulebook makes it look deceptively difficult - it's really not that hard to teach and the rules give lots of detailed examples to avoid confusion.  I play with some AP-prone people and even they, for the most part, don't take excruciatingly long to take their turns with this game.

+ Scoundrels of Skullport: A great expansion!  Two modules.  Undermountain adds a 6th player and a new board with 3 new spaces to visit.  It keeps the same mechanics so you can still use it with new players without adding additional complexity.  New quests and lords add some new twists.  The second module, Skullport, adds a new resource, Corruption, as well as new places to visit.  This one definitely adds more complexity to the game so is one you'll want to save for more seasoned players.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
I ignored this game for a long time.  The D&D title, the bland colored board, the gateway game label, nothing about it really excited me.  But man was I wrong in the best kind of way.

It's certainly not a heavy, thinky Euro, but it hits a really sweet balance.  It's easy to teach with slick iconography and a game that grows as you play.  Every game feels different as you try to maximize your secret end game scoring with the quests and buildings available to you to find little mini-engines to create while hampering your opponents plans.

I'd probably rate the base game closer to a 7.5, but with the expansion there is a nice added layer of depth and TONS of replay value.  The game is really fun when you can combo buildings with passive quests and the expansion adds much more of that along with the excellent corruption track.

My only real complaints are that the game feels like it starts to drag and it's harder to pull off a plan with 4 or more players.  Also, there are occasions where you just get a boring setup. A string of bad buildings and no quests with fun ongoing effects.  If you don't get any fun combo's that create little engines, the simplicity of the games core mechanics stand out and the game can feel tedious.

Base Game: 7
w/ S&S Exp: 8

RATING: N/A
Through your agents, you recruit adventurers to go on quests on your behalf, earning rewards and increasing your influence over the city. Expand the city by purchasing new buildings that open up new actions on the board, and hinder â or help â the other lords by playing Intrigue cards to enact your carefully laid plans. During the course of play, you may gain points or resources through completing quests, constructing buildings, playing intrigue cards or having other players utilize the buildings you have constructed.

2-5 (best 3-4)

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Overrated game.  It has nice artwork, but it's really a very weak Euro.

The theme really feels pasted on.  In some games, this is ok, but LoW tries so hard that you just want it to stop.  There is no way that you feel pious by taking white cubes or feel like a warrior for taking red.  The theme is about the worst I've seen in a game.

The balance is bad.  If the person to your right always goes out of his way to be first player, then you always get to be second player for free, which is huge.  You should have no problem beating the person who is always last.

I like the idea of adding quests to a Euro game, so I do have to give some points here.  But the quests are a bit unfair.  Some are clearly designed for the early part of the game, and others are clearly for the end.  One person is going to get lucky, where all the quests he wants come up at the right time.  There's no mitigation of this luck.

It's not a terrible game.  The designers clearly know a bit about making games.  But, it's extremely overrated.  I would never ever buy this, as I seem to have plenty of chances to play it anyway.  It seems to be one of the first games that D&D players jump to buy, just because they think it will bridge well their two favorites styles of games. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
this or Yedo
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've only played this game with the expansion, so my comments are based on the complete package.

This game is like a perfect chicken sandwich -- it's a well-understood idea, with basic execution, but at the end of the day, it is still immensely satisfying.

There's nothing new here, as it is yet another worker placement game with cubes you turn in to gain VP, all with a thin layer of theme that will be forgotten within minutes of the rules explanation.  But under all that, it's a very polished game.  The buildings, quests, and intrigue cards provide just enough variety for repeated play.  The actions on the board are just superbly balanced, in a way that hearkens back to the older, simpler euros of the late 90s and early aughts.  A very impressive design.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This is a well-made, D&D themed worker placement game. 
 Production quality is very nice (e.g. the very unique money tokens, the large meeples, and the use of some D&D stock art on the cards.)  The game is simple enough for anyone to pick up, but there was enough depth to make us want to play it many times over.
Only have 2 piddly complaints:  They should have added a few more Lords with different victory conditions, and they could have integrated more of the various stories/quests from the Forgotten Realms series (Drizzt, perhaps?)
Anyway, this is a great break away from the traditional farm-based worker placement game, and we've really enjoyed it.

Kijott iOS-re a jatek es azt kell mondjam, szinte vetekszik az asztali kiadassal! Mar a kezdo AI is jol jatszik, remek a tutorial, konnyen attekintheto a jatekter. RATING: 9
PERMANENT PLACE IN COLLECTION

UPDATE: After 5 plays, I've upped the rating of this game from 7.5 to 9. It's easy to teach, deep enough to be enjoyed by regular game players, streamlined, plays differently each game, is interactive, thematic and - with the wonderful DnDeeples - it's a visually beautiful game too. I can't fault this one in any way. I'm so glad I traded for it. It's incomparably better than Last Will, which it replaced. Believe the hype, this game is excellent.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good, worker placement, cube pusher game with pasted on Dungeons & Dragons theme (the different coloured cubes are supposedly warriors and mages etc. - for me they were oranges, charcoal, snowballs and plums - which you use to build buildings and complete quests). Very much like Caylus / Caylus Magna Carta without the road and provost but with added intrigue "take that" cards and secret goals for additional victory points at the end of the game. Plays very smoothly and quickly - almost too quickly as you do not get to use your "engine" for long.

Almost like a (meaty in a fast food way) filler for gamers and the worker placement 101 game to play with non-gamers, casual gamers and newbies.

RATING: 5
The game has a nice feel to it.  It's a light worker placement game, where players want to build up an engine to allow them opportunities for better opportunities later in the game, so it's not particularly original, but it does what it does pretty well.  I'm a little bummed that a lot of the interaction in the game is randomly drawn from a deck, and that they can also wind up being interrupts at crucial points in the game.  I prefer the interaction to come from the worker placement aspect of it, so I would almost always prefer to play Stone Age over this.  At least there the information, while random, isn't thrust on you at the worst possible moment.

1 play: 4 players
1 play: 5 players

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Perfect. Perfect. Perfect. This is our go-to game. The absolute best 2P worker placement game for couples. God, do we love it. It is easy to learn, quick to set up, always varied without feeling random, rewarding even if you lose, challenging but not exhausting - you name it.

It is hard to put in words why it is so great, I guess it is the right ratio between competitiveness and lack of competitiveness: Yes, it matters who gets to chose where to  place the workers first. No, it all is not lost when you go second. 

The game also feels "productive" rather than "destructive". The worst you can do to an opponent is to have them build a small thing on the side (which ads victory points) before moving on. 

The expansion adds the complexity some people crave it. It is almost too much for me. The base game is just so suave and perfect as it is.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
It is beyond me why this game has such a high rating on BGG. Everything about this game is so uninspired and generic and boring. It takes one of the most overused mechanic in board games - worker placement - and strips out everything that makes this mechanic interesting in other games like the provost in Caylus, or feeding of Agricola/StoneAge. It takes also the most generic overused theme and barely paints it over the game (just putting text on the cards doesn't make the game thematic!). It does not offer any interesting choices nor interesting player interaction. Yes the Intrigue cards are there for player interaction but most of them are just take some cube from someone or just slap mandatory quests on to someone. 

It would have been understandable if this game had come out a decade ago when WP wasn't a thing. If intro to worker placement is the only redeeming  quality of this game then even in that case there are better games likes StoneAge which are more thematic, more fun and give a more complete experience of worker placement. Also worker placement isn't such a complicated concept to grasp that you need to ease people into it using an intro game, especially a boring one such as this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
My first run through the rulebook left me thinking, "That's it?". The worker placement mechanics and basic economy of the game are so simple, there was no way this game would hold my attention for a single session, much less multiple games. You don't even have to struggle to gain more workers like most games of this ilk, it just arbitrarily gives you another worker half way through the game.

Well, I guess this is why they say you can't judge a book by it's cover. Despite the inherent simplicity of the game, there ends up being a signifigant amount of fun to be had. I think there are a couple of reasons for this. One, there is just enough player vs. player interaction in the intrigue cards to keep everyone involved. Two, the mission cards are so well done that players rarely see that they are trading three white cubes and a black one for five orange cubes and 12 Victory Points. They see three holy men and a rogue with a good conscience infiltrating a keep and freeing a squad of five freedom fighters. The theme really comes through thanks to the logical relationships presented between the quest titles and their rewards.

Truly jaded Euro gamers are not going to be tempted by this title, but for new players to the genre and open-minded veterans with big imaginations, Lords of Waterdeep truly is greater than the sum of its parts.

Variant: When playing with a snobby Euro fan, always refer to the hero classes as the following: Fighters = Carrots, Wizards = Turnips, Clerics = Reeds and Rogues = Boars. Then watch the aforementioned Euro snob struggle with attacking the game for being themeless, all while simultaneously trying to defend the clearly nonexistent theme by making you call the cubes by their correct names. It never gets old...


=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Enjoyable but shallow (compared to other worker placement games on this list), also feels way too kindly in how it treats player interaction. It has cards and systems specifically for messing with each other but it's like a nerf battle compared to Caylus or similar's all out slap-fight.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
6 might be a little harsh on a 10 point scale - solidly a 3 star game out of 5, at any rate.

It's not the worst worker placement game I've played, but it's also far from the best. There's just enough direct player interaction to allow leader bashing (heed the "Take That" mechanic in the description), which led to a lot of frustration from the former leader. The random quests and rewards make me feel like I have less control than I do in something like Agricola - that is, I don't feel like a bad hand in the latter dooms me as much as not seeing quests that match my bonus in this game.

The biggest issue is that there is WAY too much going on. Human beings can only keep on average about 7 things in working memory at a time. There are so many ways to score points here - and so few barriers to making any given move - that it's very prone to AP. Comparing to Agricola again, if I don't have open spaces in fields, I can immediately dismiss any action involving taking animals for that turn. There's not really a comparable narrowing process here, and by the end of the game we'd built so many building that there were literally about 20 reasonable choices and the score was close enough it seemed worthwhile to try and squeeze out an extra point or two.

Ultimately I think the game is more mental effort and time consuming than it's worth, though I still wouldn't call it a bad game. The components are well engineered for streamlining play and the decisions, if a little too open, can be interesting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
There are a lot of allegedly "themeless" games or those with "pasted on themes" and often this isn't a problem for me as long as mechanically something interesting is happening. 

Waterdeep falls into the same class as Splendor in which nothing is happening. About the most interesting thing it has to offer is placement spaces the allow delayed re-allocation at the end of round, a common feature of worker placement titles of the era. No amount of chrome, lore-text or art can prevent this from being a completely flavourless experience.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

There's a fair bit of chaos with the "Intrigue" cards that can heavily influence the game.  But the game plays fairly quick so the impact of the chaos isn't an evening-buster.

RATING: 7
Not every worker placement game has to be 100% calculable, sometimes it's cool to have an ace up your sleeve and surprise your opponents. Well, this game allows you to do just that. There is a lot of take that here, but this is what separates Lords of Waterdeep from other typical euros from this genre. It's simple, but demanding. Can't wait to check out the expansion.

The only thing I'm not sure I like yet is Mandatory Quest mechanism. They really slow down someone's progress and feel ultra mean, especially when all players try to bash the leader.

RATING: 7.7
I agree that it is kind of like "Yedo-lite".  It is certainly a pasted-on theme, which is OK b/c I'm not thrilled with the dark D & D theme.  It can become a "cube pushing" type of game, but it is still very enjoyable!  I find the decision making between the quick, low-point value quests and the longer high-point quests an interesting dilemma.  The expansion pushes this from an "alright" game to a "good game".  Nevertheless, once you acclimatize  to Waterdeep, the next step is Yedo, which is an excellent game.

RATING: 7.252
This is a very forgiving and fairly simple worker placement game.  Each turn, you will make choices on the best places to send your agents... but it is about the -best- places to send them, there are no 'bad choices' that will cause you harm or ruin your game, just choices that are more or less useful.  If you want to play a worker placement game with someone who has never played worker placement before, I would recommend this game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.3
The #1 game in my collection of 30 odd games thus far. Can play with only 2, best with 3-4, 5 might be a bit too much as it limits your worker amount. The expansion Scoundrels of Skullport is a must-have and I couldn't imagine playing without it. (Would write a longer review on it some other day since I just joined the site).

I don't get how this is only #45 overall (which you could argue is really high). To me it's one of those overlooked games that needs more attention. I feel that this is a 10/10 game from start to finish and it's our gaming groups favourite too. Every game is so different and I've never had a bad game of Waterdeep with our group. And I doubt that one will never come, it's just that good of a game.

EDIT: 04/17 Dropped from 10 to 9. :( The love is fading. 9 without the expansion, with expansion a lot better.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Wow, after 1 play I really like this game.  Tempted to give it a perfect 10 score because there was nothing I didn't like, but needs a few more plays before that.  It's worker placement like Caylus, Agricola, or Pillars of the Earth, where you choose an action and others are subsequently blocked from that action.  But with all the buildings in play, there are always good options open.  The added dimensions are the Quests and the secret Lord of Waterdeep goal that each player gets.  The secret goal makes it impossible to guarantee the winner until the final points are tallied.  There's a good bit of interaction too, and for a change, the interaction is often acts of benevolence, where you help another player of your choice (as opposed to robbing from him - though that happens also).  It's also fairly simple to learn and doesn't take too long if you can stop players from overanalyzing their moves.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I was talked into trying [i]Waterdeep[/i] based on the advertised 60-minute playtime, only to regret my decision 90 minutes later.  Our game may have been unusual, but there should be an official rule that any game of LoW that lasts longer than an hour should end instantaneously - with everyone losing.

There's no real connection between theme and gameplay, which is most obvious in the fact that [i]Waterdeep[/i] now holds the record for the dullest flavor text of all time. I don't want to violate copyright, so I'll share a few of my own contributions to give you a sense of flavor:

[i]Gee, your licey beard sure looks itchy.

My boots are muddy from the dungeon floor. Please advise.

Cackling witch, please pass the porridge.

Our quest is nearly complete, so prepare to nap shortly.[/i]

Note to Wizards of the Coast: I specialize in narcoleptic prose, and my resume is on its way.

[i]Update:[/i]

If anyone is still playing this game in a year, I will be absolutely shocked.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A very good worker placement game in a fantasy setting. Similar to Caylus in that you can buy buildings and get a bonus if others use your buildings. You collect various character cubes (Wizard, Cleric, Rouge, Fighter) as resources to complete quests which give you victory point and sometimes bonuses. A little bit of "take that" player interaction but it tends to just slow you down and not take you out of the game. Good game.

RATING: 9
I really like this game.  It offers great depth and strategy for a game that is dead simple to set up and learn.  Its also a quick AND satisfying play with decent medium weight strategy mechanics. 

Great components.
Plays great with 2.

I like fantasy themes but I didnt care that the D&D theme was minimal.  It feels like you're playing sneaky bastard rich people who are running a city.  It didnt bother me that it didnt feel like there might be dragons or orcs outside town.

Really fun.

bumping to 9 after plays with more people.  This is very quick to teach but definitely takes more than one play to master.

Back to 8 after noticing imbalance depending on player count.

the expansion is SO good.  it fixes the player count imbalance by introducing new lords.  rating is going back up!

RATING: 7
A great intro to worker placement. I generally try and make any fresh meat go through this one (or stone age) at least once before moving them on to something heavier.

Personally after a number of plays it definitely starts to get a bit stale, and while people say the expansion can fix that the already borderline too long play time doesn't need any encouragement from an expansion.

I may be being too harsh, but for it's length there are other things I personally would rather play. However I'm always down to join a game or teach someone this if they're just getting into the hobby :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
There is conflict with other players and you can specifically set out to harm other players but the harm you can do is limited so the game doesn't feel very harsh. More often, you have to choose one other player to *help* and that tends to keep everybody competitive until the end as you will typically help the player who seems weakest. We played with 4 people and our final scores were consecutive - something like 79,80,81,82! Everybody had a chance of winning until the final turn.

Unfortunately, I have a pretty bad case of "build buildings built on places Oh my I really like buildings" syndrome, which I'm told is not the best attitude to have to score the most points. 

I generally have a bit of an aversion to games that require some forward thinking and strategy, but I really like this one, it was the first worker placement game I've ever played and I do bring it up more often than others when I feel that my partner's board games evenings quota has dropped too low.

RATING: 7.5
I'd played the iOS version a lot before we got this to the table, so it was very quick to get going. Really enjoy this - was a little unsure how well it would work at 2p, but I loved being able to complete more quests. We played with the mandatory quests left in (I have seen a lot of people remove them at 2p) and it didn't cause any issues. I also liked how the Intrigue cards that give you 2 cubes and another player 1 cube work differently at 2p - in a game with more players it feels like a way to catch up to a runaway leader (or just hold them back), whereas at 2p it felt more like price to pay for the benefit of the Intrigue card. Just like using the opponent's buildings, there was a lot of weighing up the options - is the reward worth it if it directly benefits the opponent, too?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
D&D is a very strongly flavoured theme, that has been applied to this game very thinly.

This game might very well have portrayed competing Renaissance fresco painters, and I know I'd enjoy it much the same. The theme here doesn't excite or depress me, but I'm sure it will draw in players who otherwise wouldn't touch this style of gameplay with a 10-foot pole.

The city board is nicely illustrated, and functionally arranged. The art on all of the cards is decent.

LoWD plays fast; is simple; a whole bunch of fun; and is complemented by some interesting decision-making - that does not paralyse players with too many 'meh' options.

Feels fairly tight and certainly winnable by all moderate players for much of the game. A very competent design.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Received from Gina for Christmas 2012. Thanks Sister in Law!!!

This is a solid worker placement game.  The resources and actions are tight, it plays quickly and the components are great.  There might be a bit more randomness in the card draws (particularly the usefulness of the hidden roles) than some folks like but trying to find the best time to play intrigue cards or complete a quest was entertaining.  Thematically the game manages to make all the actions and results make sense even if there should be more to adventuring than simply assembling a proper team (though I appreciate there not being an additional layer of randomness added for questing).

Thanks to that nice thematic integration and great art/components combined with engaging game play this is quicly becoming my go to intro Worker Placement game of choice.

RATING: 9
This is an Euro-game in an Ameritrash packaging. What that does to us? Well we had high expectations of it. Most of the time Euro-games just hacve a theme pasted on, while Ameritrash-games have a great implementation of the theme. Euro-games play fast compared to Ameritrash-games. What if this was a game that plays fast and is able to take you into the theme?

Well, before we ordered this game, we knew that wasnât going to happen. We read about all the shortcomings on this one. But we also read enough to know, that we would enjoy this game. After we got this game with Christmas, the first surprise was the size of the box. It was huge! We expected a medium sized box, like games of the Alea Big Box series. But the box was even bigger than a TTR-box. When we had a closer look at the box, the first disappointment appeared. The lid of the box didnât even reach down half-way the box. Ofter opening the lid, I noticed two corners of the box werenât taped together. Ouchâ¦. Big, big mistake in my eyes. This way there always will be a (very) small opening between the two pieces of cardboard. An opening that makes it possible for dust to get inside the box. Then we looked further and noticed the, high-rated by other people, insert of the box. And indeed, we have to agree with them. This is a very nice designed insert. Everything just fits as it should. Everything is staying in place. This is an example for many games. Only one remark about this insert. At the bottom side of the playing board, in the agents-pool, there is space for a sixth agent. Rules speak about a space for a future expansion. If there was is expansion to come, the space on the game-board only would make sense, if it became possible to play with a sixth player. Why isnât the insert of the box prepared for that?

Playing and explaining this game is easy. It comes down to place a worker (agent) and perform the action that comes with the placement. After that complete a card (quest) if itâs possible. Thatâs all there is, collect cubes and use them to get victory points. Oh no, I said that wrong. A player has to hire rogues, fighters, clerics, and wizards to fulfill quests. And thatâs the biggest problem of this game. The implementation of the theme is poor. I donât feel like I have to hire adventures. Itâs just collecting colored cubes. The only thing what reminds of the theme while Iâm playing the game, is the moment when I look at the boxfront. Why arenât plastic, Â½inch minis inside the box that represent the adventurers? Minis like in the Dungeon Petz box. Why isnât a bigger miniature inside the box, that represent the different lords? Miniatures like in Claustrophobia? That would be great to the implementation of the theme to this game.

Probably it sounds like we didnât like the game. In the contrary, we enjoyed this game very much. We liked the mechanism of the intrigue cards. We liked the different buildings that players can build, and the benefits that comes with them for the owner. We like that there become more possibilities to place workers when there are more buildings build. We like the plot quests that can give you benefits during the game. We like the materials that are used. They are of high quality components. Minor thing in game play, is the fact that 8 out of the 9 lords, give you bonus-points for completing quests. We would like to see more variation in that, because there are more ways to collect points in this game.

As said, we enjoyed this game very much. Fantastic family game. Plays great with two (we can set this game up and play it with two in about 45 minutes), and most important, it is fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
My definitive go-to gateway game for introducing the worker placement mechanic. It is not overly complicated, there are simple choices that yield fun rewards. The joy of completing two or three quests in one round is balanced by the horror of watching that last gold-producing location get taken by the preceding player.

Overall, I very much enjoy this. My only critique is that I feel there could have been more creative lords. (This is remedied in the expansion, but is still apparent.)

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
After 2+ plays: There's not much new here.  It's a fairly bland worker placement where you collect resources and turn them in for points at a pretty set ratio.  Too many of the buildings are just strictly better version of the original spaces, such that they provide only new spaces for when the extra worker comes in the fifth round, not new interesting options.  The mechanism for playing intrigue cards is also neat, but the cards themselves are mostly bland - either a generic turn-saving action or thoughtless take-that.  

After 5+ plays: My opinion is slightly improved.  Some plot quests can add a nice twist, and I've discovered the game is significantly better with 2-3 players than with 4-5.  Bumping rating up from a 5 to a 6.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Good light worker placement that is actually a step easier that Spyrium due to the latter having quirky ways of getting money and some other rules.

RATING: 7.5
I played this wrong the first several games, but after I learned the actual rules I preferred my incorrect play method. This is a theme-heavy worker placement game about completing quests. That's an awesome concept and it is fun to play, with a low barrier to entry. The main problem is that the largest quests are easily identifiable as the best reward-to-cube ratio, regardless of which leader you have. If you are dealt a 25 pt quest at the start, you have a large advantage.

To mitigate this imbalance, we play without any starting quests. If you want a 25 pt one that is sitting on the table, you'll need to spend an action and your privilege of access to the favoured buildings in order to get it.

Despite that minor issue, Waterdeep is a great game, and one of my preferred worker placement options.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game has been said to be too simple, too light. It is certainly not a heavy rules game, and it is certainly not difficult to grasp. However, there is considerable depth and just amazing replay value here. I can play it 100 times and I'd probably end up seeing a different strategy unfold over the 8 turns. At the start of the game, you're open - do whatever you want. By round 3, you have a couple of strategies to attack...by round 7 you're clearly set on one and you have to attack, attack, attack on those quests to fulfill your need for victory. I love this game. My wife and I played it twice in the first day, can't wait to get it to the table again. Just a beautifully designed, wonderful components and thematically interesting worker placement game. It's above Dungeon Lords only because this is shorter and easier to set up and put away. Has the best insert ever made, as well. Definitely a 10!

RATING: 6
Lords of Waterdeep is a pretty good worker placement game. It's simple, the theme is awesome, and it's easy to learn. None of the mechanics are too stand out, but overall the game is above average, as attributed by the score I gave it. I play this with less heavy-gaming inclined people and it's a hit, and I enjoy plays of this as well.

RATING: 8
worker placement, well done
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This is an amazing worker placement game. It is simple enough that I consider it a gateway game, and it has been a hit about 90% of the time I've introduced it. The hidden objectives keeps things interesting all the way to the end, the quests help to focus new players on how the game works and what they should be doing, and I love the interaction and "take that" provided by the intrigue cards. It is simply an incredibly fun experience.

RATING: 10
This has become our go-to game this year. It is a great worker placement game with low weight and lots of opportunities for meaningful decisions. I play it with hardcore strategy gamers and with casual gamers. Everyone has fun, even if they get stomped.

RATING: N/A
R
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
The definitive 'Euro' board game. This is just thematic enough to keep me interested, and I don't mean the game has nice pictures and art. The quests and cards, flavor text and mechanics alike, all fit the idea of a powerful leader vying for control in a D&D city. It works, and it works well. 

Edit: 12/24/14
Finally found a Euro I like better. What a glorious day!

Edit: 1/6/15
It's amazing how quickly this has fallen in my estimation after playing other games. This really is bare bones.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Very boring and highly overrated.  I've only played it once, so give that whatever weight you wish.  It was a three-player game and, without knowing the rules, I could sit down and competently play.  So, it's a "been there, done that" sort of game in the worst way.  

If I had to pick a redeeming feature, it's that it might serve well as a gateway game.  But, at the same time, why bore new players?  Why not introduce them to gaming via a better, more delightful game?
